When I went they had been looking for me and I can't really remember, they could tell me exactly how long they’d been looking for me because Wake County had notified Johnson County that they had been looking for me. But I was out using and running the streets and doing what I wanted to do, and I didn't stay at one place long. So they couldn't get up with me. But, I went to be STD tested and they had a picture of me, my name, Social Security number, and asked was that me? And I said yes, and they said well sit down, we have something to tell you. And I wouldn't sit down. They said – you're HIV positive. I denied it, I raised Cain, I put some people out. I said I'm not going nowhere until y’all test me right now. They took me around the corner, drew my blood, told me they’d get back in touch with me. I know that y’all got the machines or whatever y’all need to let me know right now that y’all didn't make no mistake. About 45 minutes later she came back and said – yes ma'am.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My husband died I said – Lord, okay, I got HIV so you know there ain't going to be no more men. First of all I'm too old to learn somebody else. And I don't want to say – I have HIV, is that going to be a problem? Because I don't want nobody to know. So therefore I'm not going to be in a relationship no more. So being alone is my (crying) biggest, biggest thing. I have to take care of my self now... I really would like (crying) to be in another relationship, I don't want to die alone. But if that don’t happen, just having friends. Me and you go to the movies, we’ll meet and go to the show, just being able to get out; I don’t get out. I ain't got no car, my daddy’s fixin’ to buy me a car and I know what that’s going to cost, that’s going to be some problems. And I know it but I'm not going to tell him not to do it.

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I was dating this guy, I was crazy in love with him, and he did bam. I was always curious and I wanted to try, and he didn't want me to at first but then he finally let me try it. (Wanda: It’s speed) It gave you a rush. You shoot it in your vein and it gives you a rush. I could have got the HIV from unprotected sex or also from sharing a dirty needle, because we did share needles, we didn't use a separate needle. I don't know when I got it or who I got it from, I just know that I was positive

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: ...before her [her daughter], I had an abortion, actually I had two abortions. And my mother forced me into the first abortion and, we had a nanny, and she found that I was pregnant and her mother had went away to one of those islands, St. Thomas or Bahamas or Puerto Rico somewhere and came back and came in the room and got me and was punching my stomach…you pregnant! You pregnant! She was going to beat that baby out of me, girl! Ain't no babies coming in here, I ain't finished having babies yet myself! She wasn’t lying…she set up an abortion for me and I had an abortion. And then a couple years later I had another abortion. After that abortion I fell in love with my daughter’s father who passed when she was five months old; and then I wanted to have a baby, and I couldn't. I felt God was punishing me. Every month I’d tell him, I'm pregnant, I missed my cycle…next thing I know, here comes my cycle. Why, lo and behold and this is just how it happened. We laying in the bed one day, side by side, and he turns over to me, he say – guess what? You pregnant. I thought I could beat the brakes off of him! I done took him through this all this time, telling everyone I'm pregnant…and I'm not pregnant. So why would he want to do this to me? Play these mind games. I'm already suffering, I'm pregnant…I'm not pregnant. But lo and behold, I was pregnant.

taking charge of health and wellness.text: Taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: When I met my daughter’s father because I wanted money for the drugs…I got on drugs rightafter Richard Pryor, we knew about freebasing, Richard Pryor caught fire. I learned then what freebasing was. A couple of people were doing it. Since I was the kind of chick that always said – you know what? I’ll try it once. So I tried it. And that’s when I started selling myself. I was giving it away, nobody wasn’t loving me, I didn't love myself. So I did that. And I became pregnant but I didn'tknow I was pregnant.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: I became a somebody two or three years ago. That’s why I could put the makeup on, I could dress up the outside; but did it match the inside? No. I just got there. I just got it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: Well, you know how they say you reach rock bottom? So my daughter told me, she’s like — mom, I love you to death but I’m not going to be here to see you kill yourself. So either you get yourself together or you’re never going to see me or your grandkids again. So, that rang a bell, ding, ding, ding, it rang a bell. I was like you know what? I think I’m ready to do this. She goes – but you can’t do it for me mommy and you can’t do it for your grandkids; you have to do it for you, you have to get better for you before you can do for us.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: Well actually like I said, I stopped but I did it for me, I didn’t really do it for none of them, I did it for me. Because you have to do it for you before you can be there for anybody, for anybody else. But my oldest daughter, she was really, really...and I could really see it in her eyes, like she wanted me, she goes — okay you have the virus, okay I’ve known people with the virus, I know people with AIDS, they can live long lives and long and long and long! She’s like — I just want you, because that was her worst fear of losing me.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I was diagnosed at Brookdale Hospital and I always say that they almost killed me before they healed me. I always say they almost killed me before they healed me. Every time I used to come to the clinic I used to always cry, cry, cry all the time. But now keep my appointment, I come to the clinic faithfully, even though I know what I’m here for, I do not stress about it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: Since I’ve been on medication I’ve never missed a dose of medica-tion. Because you know what? It’s always in my head that if I miss one dose, it’s going to take me back to when I was diagnosed.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I’ve never had any side effects but the fact that I was going to have to take them every day, that was my issue. I don’t like taking medication.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I don’t know how to tell [D] because I’m...I don’t want him to think because you’re HIV you’re going to die. I had to correct a lady one time in a clinic because she said —  do you have AIDS? And I said no ma’am, I have the virus. Why did I get so mad? I had to recently see my doctor because I was getting scared because if I have an ear-ache, I’m already thinking...see I’m losing weight, a lot of weight and I asked her if I’m going downhill. And she said Cookie — your T-cell count is undetected, your viral load is sky high. You ain’t going to die from that. [VIRAL LOAD IS UNDETECTABLE AND YOUR T-CELLS ARE HIGH] She said so high, so it woke me up. I gotta get out of this funk. I really have to get out of it. I just take medication and now I’m drinking protein.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: The difference I’m trying to make is to realize that I am HIV. There’s a lot of things that you can do to lift up your spirit. I always take my medication like clockwork. Maybe not the same time because some-times I don’t eat during...but I take it every single day. And I want to be able to live with it. I really think I’ve been so in denial, that’s why I let my body go so bad. I just didn’t...but now I have that spunk, like somebody lit a fire under my butt because I really, really want to live. I’m not embarrassed anymore. I’ll go talk and speak, but I got to  learn also how to tell my 15-year-old and I don’t even think I want to. Because [D] feels I’m all he has. His mother’s his other mother; I’m his mom. I’m his light, his God, I’m everything to [D]. Little does he know that that’s what he means to me. And sometimes I feel like I should let him know, give him the awareness because every time I look at him...maybe in groups or something where there’s other children that he can meet, because one-on-one from me I wouldn’t want to just tell him, no. I want him to see that other kids are coping with their parents with it. But I still really, I don’t know about [D], I feel like I’ll hurt him.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: I felt pain. I felt betrayed, I wanted to actually kill him, which I tried. I changed my mind and I took a turn to the better and I started seeking help. There were no medications then. After a while there came a medicine by the name of Hivid, it was the very first one with AZT. And so I took the initiative to take care of myself. But before I did that I went to crack. I threw him out. I went to crack, I went to heroin, I went to prostitution. You name it; I did it all. But I lifted myself up spiritually and I accepted the Lord in 1993.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: I empower other women to stay on track in Star Health Center. I’ve been with them since 1992 and I worked myself up getting knowledgeable with HIV and took trainings and so on, certificates throughout the years. What I do now is I empower others, let them know that they're not alone. And I can share and I can relate because I'm walking their shoes.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: HIV is just one of little thing of many. I don’t focus on it. I take my medication like I'm taking for a headache. It has become part of me, my medication. So it’s a ritual that I have. They're next to my bedside, I take it in the morning and I take it in the evening. But it’s a ritual because I take that bottle of medication to the kitchen with me so I could take the morning, then I take it back to the bedroom so I can take in the night. So I would never find that pill bottle in the kitchen in the evening because it’s a ritual I do. Where this has focused me on being adhered to my medications. This is how I help others also.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: I got back there, got my baby, got in the cab, went back to the shelter and I never got high again after that. I really started to pay attention to reorienting myself to live in an active world. Because people are going to drink, they’re going to drug; the thing is, you have to choose not to. I had to reprogram myself to learn how to do that. Eventually it worked and I gave birth to [J] January 22, 1992.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Loretta
list.extract: For me it didn’t feel like a death sentence. For me it was like I wasn’t going to die. I was going to continue to live. I was going to fight no matter what. I was going to keep on going no matter what. And I’m still here today.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Loretta
list.extract: Because like I was just explaining to you guys, there was a time when I couldn’t tolerate it. I couldn’t tolerate it, and I just wouldn’t take ‘em. And I told my doctor – until I get better with it, there’s nothing that she could do, she could tell me and change the pills and do whatever, nothing she could do until I get better with it and that’s what it took. I’m much better now with the medication and taking the medication and managing with the medication. I thank God for it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: When I first found out I was in denial. I wouldn’t take no medication. They only had AZT back then; I declined it because people was dying. Now I’m on a regimen that is working, I’m undetectable, I want to live now. I was self-destructive when I first found out. Now I just want to live another 33 years (laughter).

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: You don’t have to die of AIDS ; take your medicine, go to your doctor’s appointments, do what you have to do to make sure your numbers are right, and you don’t have to worry about nothing.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I’m comfortable with myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die as long as I take care of myself. It just means taking better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life...I’m a much better person now, stronger, confident, just you know ready to help whoever I can... I’m okay with it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: Thank God today I have been to groups and all kinds of educational programs, stuff like that. I learned so much about it. Yeah that is one thing, once I did find out about it, after a while, long about I’d say probably two years after I found out I think, I got myself together and I started pursuing to see what this HIV was about and how can I deal with it and live longer and that’s what I’ve been doing up until now. I just don’t feel like telling everybody about it right now, I’m comfortable myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die long as I take care of myself. It just means tak-ing better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life. Really if I look at it, you know, because I still would have been out there doing what I was doing probably, I don’t know. I’m a much better person now, stronger, confidence, just you know, ready to help whoever I can...I’m okay with it. It’s just letting people in.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: Cope with it? Now it’s like nothing. It’s like if I have diabetes or…I know I have to take medication for it, I’m undetectable, which is good. It’s like nothing. I don’t feel like I’m going to die or it’s a death sentence. Well, I never did feel that, I never really felt really sick.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: My T-cells, nothing has never went down that low. I’ve always been active, always been able to do for myself. Never had to have no—I’m not going to say I didn’t get the flu or whatever, you know that’s common. But as far as my HIV status, no. I’ve been able to take care of myself, do for myself.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: I’m like okay, I got to questioning my faith and like okay, you been to church all these years, apparently you’ve got all this or whatever and so you still around for something. I started doing a little bit of research, I’m real good with computers and I started doing a little bit of research, and I heard about the Radiation Center, which was, they had a women’s group in there, a women’s support group. So I started going to the women’s support group at Cook County Hospital, okay?

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: [MY MOTHER] was like—well Sister (that’s my nickname, Sister) no use in keeping it a secret; it’s something you gotta live with now. You should just tell the rest of them, they’ll be understanding. And me knowing the type of family and sisters that I had, I knew that they would handle a problem, if anything they would be catering to me. I told them and that’s exactly what it was. They were catering to me, still ‘til today they—Sister, what’s your cell count? Because now they are more aware about it, especially with one of my sisters being a doctor. I’ve never been hospitalized before, I’ve never been sick, very seldom have a cold, my T-cell count always have been in the 800s, undetectable, even the herpes breakouts that I usually have on you know my bottom part, I don’t even have them that much more.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: HIV definitely saved my life. I knew enough to know I didn't want to die, you know? And that meant getting clean, getting sober. I had one attack in my body like it was a hungry lion and then I threw drugs and alcohol in the mix and my body was like – girl! I'm going to quit on you if you don’t stop!

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: It was actually through Northwestern. Because I said – I can’t afford this medicine. And they said all you have to is pick it up. And then after every so many weeks I would go in…my ears got black, and people kept saying – have you been to the Bahamas? Because I was really chocolate, and I liked the color, but then after they adjusted it, my nails are white again.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: So I was up all night calling places, and it just so happened that Julie Washington, she works at the Core Center, she was my substitute for my counselor, but she wasn’t even working at the Core, she was working at County and somewhere she saw my name. She was just coming to see if it was me. I call her my guardian angel. She walked down that hall and I said – Julie, I need your help, I gotta go into treatment, they said I can keep my baby! (crying) You know and she was like…she called some place and they found a place that day for me to take Madison. They came and picked us up and took us to Haymarket.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: So God was allowing me to get my mind right. (crying) (inaudible) I was about to take, and I was ready then. Treatment opened up, because I was scared, I didn't want no more and I wanted to give my son a chance! And I stayed in Maryville for two years, I went to Haymarket, I stayed there for 18 months and I was scared to leave because I just didn't want to have no more. I moved into a program where they monitor us, you know? They subsidized my rent, then I had just got active into, after that I begin engaged in my medical care, wanted now to take care of my HIV. I began to educate myself about what it is that I had.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: I mean the pain, the emotional pain was far worse than the physical pain. and I just asked God to just – stop. Just stop (crying) the pain. And that’s when I asked him to help me to come in, and God whatever it is that I have to do I will do it, whatever they tell me to do, whatever…I'm going to do it. And when I feel like using I'm going to pray to you, you say that you are God…I need you to show me that you are God. ... And I delivered Madison and I'm telling you when I asked God for help, things just started happening. I had already had two children in the system, Jada and Jaylen, and they were already terminated from parental rights. And it was the lady from DCFS came and she was like – well, I'm going to let you take your baby but you have to get into treatment.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: I didn't know anything [about AIDS when I was diagnosed]! All I know was that it was like a deadly…I did know this, it was a virus and it was a deadly virus. And I did know that it was a gay man’s disease. But I really didn't care at that time, you know? I didn't really care because I was just still out there, you know, in the street. All I cared about was getting my fix and then oh – I’ll get treated tomorrow. But when I got to the Fantus Clinic I started learning about it through group, you know. I started listening to what my doctor was saying and I didn't even know that if your T-cell count fall below, back then it was 200, then you had the AIDS.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: I talked to anyone, you know, and I learned mainly from gay, gay men about this disease. What I did was I started working as a Certified Nurse Assistant, so mostly all my patients back then had AIDS. They had Kaposi’s sarcoma, you know. It was all kind of, it was a gay man’s disease back then. But what they didn't know was that I was diagnosed with HIV, they said AIDS. I was adhering to my medications. I took control of what I was supposed to do.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Life after diagnosis has changed, for the better. It may have taken me many years after 1989 to get my life back in order. I eventually got back on track. The want and need to go back to school is what my desire was and that’s what I did. I did not let my HIV status stop me nor did I let people stop me.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: Hey we’re still here. I got more appointments now that I'm getting older of course…oh check this out, check that out!

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: I’ve had abortions too, so you know I'm on both sides of the card there you know because some will say okay, I'm a killer and then at the same time I have given birth. But then I’ve given birth with not the intention of getting pregnant, it happened and trust me, I was looking for options to get out of them, both of them. I wouldn't trade them in now, but that’s a turning point. I don't think I could take anything back in my life that has brought me here today. So in other words some have made it, some haven't.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: There’s a new ‘women and children’s clinic’ at the county, it was like six months old. That was February of ‘89 and they started that summer before, July of ‘88. And so I eventually found my way to the Radiation Center, but not before going to a couple of different addresses because he really didn’t know how to tell me where the hell it was, somewhere in there. So after making a couple of calls, after going to where these people would tell me which was all the wrong places, I finally got through and they told me of a health educator and he was the one to get in touch with to get the testing done. And I remember I kept missing him.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: [MY SON HAS] given me two more grandchildren and they’re fine and his wife is still fine. It goes on like that. Yes, little close encounters like that kind of wake you up. Once all the drugging and the alcohol, I finally got rid of all of that, you know WIHS and the clinic and the people you meet, you learn something from people everyday.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Racheal
list.extract: I never really become a woman in Chicago until I got clean off the drug. That was August 10, 2010. When I surrendered and I was powerless over drugs. I’ve been clean off drugs ever since then. That’s when I became a woman. And I started living my life as a woman. Now I’m married, I have a home, I pay bills. I go grocery shopping. I do things that normal people do.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Racheal
list.extract: I wasn’t surprised that I tested positive because of the lifestyle I had lived, but I was still hurt. It wasn’t like it was a shock because of the lifestyle I had lived. But it still was a painful moment to me. And she let me sit down there and she said you can go ahead and cry. And the first thing I thought was – it’s a death sentence, I’m dying…not knowing what I know about HIV now, I thought I was going to die, and that’s been seven years ago. Now I’m here, I’m living here, I’m undetectable, my T-cells are great. I’m as healthy as a horse.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract: I started doing some research, and that’s when I found out about an organization called TPAN on the north side. It was an organization that was headed up by a gay group and... wonderful guys. So after work, I would drive up to the North Side.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: Then I got introduced to WIHS through the Core Center. And WIHS is just great, they’re great to us. I get tests that I need to actually have anyway and all the Paps and that, I need that because I had problems with my cervix in the past, so I need that. I get what I need – medical attention. They’re very friendly and very nice to us, generous with us, you know generous with us, personable. It’s been a great experience being in WIHS. I love this project, I’m glad to do it. I’m glad to share my experiences, if anybody has an interest.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: It was to the point where they were going to put me on the street. It was either straighten up and fly right, and I hit my rock bottom, finally. I got busted buying drugs, and I’m sitting in the cell waiting to go to court and I’m thinking – this is the second time. And I’m thinking – what if I get a little time or something, because you ain't gonna get off maybe like you did the first time, and I thought, what if something happens to my mother because she’s already up in age and had a number of strokes and stuff. So I said to myself – well, you know what? You need to do something differently, so that doesn’t end up happening. And the only answer was I needed to get the strength to stop doing that stuff. So what I did was I just slowly backed off of it. I lied through my teeth and said I wasn’t doing it, but it was the weirdest thing, I looked at it like dieting. If I could get $200, you could bet I had 20 rocks in my pocket and would smoke them in a day. And I just backed up. I slowed down. Just like you cut your food portions, I cut and I cut and I backed up and I backed up. And I prayed to God for strength, or to the higher power, because I didn’t necessarily believe in a God but in the possibility of a higher power, and I prayed for the inner strength, and somehow I had it. I went to a couple of meetings. I couldn’t go to a lot of meetings, I could barely walk. I was as big as a house, 338 pounds, I could hardly walk from the bus stop…

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh yes, I have problems getting my medication now because…the amount, okay if you make a certain amount of money then you don’t qualify for this program, but the medicine is so expensive that my insurance won't pay for it, so excuse my language but you're damned if you do, and you're damned if you don’t, that type of situation. Work and you make money and then your insurance don’t pay for the medicine. Don’t work and you can get all of these things but I'm living in poverty. Like now I can't get any, the social workers are trying to get me assistance, we’re trying to get my medicine. Well, I can't get it because they can't help me, because the amount. I make more money than what they require...Um, in a way because people can't go to the doctors, they can't afford to go to the health, to get medical treatment. A lot of people that don’t have money, let's put it like this. If I had $100 to put food on the table for my kids, but I needed that $100 to go to the doctor, what do you think that person will do? They’ll take that $100 and feed their children. Because that $100 probably could feed their kids for the month, if you're living in poverty. I'm not going to take the $100 and go to the doctor when I know that I have to survive. So yes, it’s a lot of people that are lacking care because of money.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: They do. I think everybody who knows me, knows (laughter). I'm very open with my status, though it was not always that way. When I first got diagnosed I kept it from my family for a long time. The first ones who knew in my family was my Dad. The day that I got diagnosed I told my Dad, I just didn't want to be by myself with it. It wasn’t, I didn't have embarrassment, it wasn’t that type of feeling, it was more fear if anything. I'm so open about my health and everything that I felt like it was something the family should know so they can be there to support you. I didn't tell my children for, I don't know, at least three years. So you know, that part was scary. My mom, my sisters, just that experience was, it was surprising because the responses were different than what I expected. So now everyone knows because I'm extremely outspoken. And I don't know, it’s okay, almost like it’s not there.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: It was up to me to take matters in my own hands or leave it alone and live my life. I planned on taking matters in my own hands. I wanted to kill him, I made a vow with myself that I would, and even though going through counseling eventually I just started to lie – like oh I'm not going to hurt anybody, oh I'm better now. Because I definitely had to get counseling. What I did was I planned – I'm going to find this man and kill him so he won't do this to anybody else. I’ll deal with the jail time. I even got a will prepared for myself so my kids would be taken care of. It just never happened and I'm thankful that it never did. I didn't see him until I had forgiven myself and forgiven him. I did that in 2004. I went to a church encounter for women and gosh, I just laid everything down, all my anger, all my hurts from childhood all the way up…I had to forgive me for making different choices that put me in harm’s way, forgive people for hurting me. I just had to get it off of my chest.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Once I embraced it because you hear – ok you're HIV positive. For some people, you have these feelings of oh my gosh, you're just still in shock. Some people can be in denial; I was never in denial, I was still just in shock. One day I was able to accept it. I was just like – deep breath, okay, it’s a part of my life. There's nothing I can do. I can't go get a shot and make it go away, I can't take medicine and make it go away. It’s always going to be there, on paper they’ll always have that December 13, 2001 I was diagnosed with HIV. I just embraced it and said you know what? What else can I do? Cause I can't allow this to weigh heavy on me because I have too many other responsibilities in life than to worry about this one thing.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: That’s another reason why I advocate, because there are people who are not like that. There are women who won't speak up for themselves; not because they don't want to, because they can't. They don't know what to say, how to say it. So they need somebody there for them. I don’t mind being that person. I had to do it for myself, although I had support to encourage me and empower me to do it for myself. Now it’s a no-brainer for me, I just automatically do it. So when I made that decision to take the medication I even remember sitting on the edge of my sofa, holding this pill and looking at it and I'm like – hmm, when I swallow you it’s going to be for the rest of my life.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: The only reason I started taking the medication was I got a case of shingles and the Complera that was prescribed to me got rid of the shingles. So it was good and bad. Good it got rid of the shingles but bad because then I kind of sunk in that I have HIV. As long as I didn't have to take the medication I was like – okay. I don’t have it. It’s just in my body. But when I had to start taking medication, it was a different feeling...I sure do! I was on my way to Miss Kitty’s funeral and I had that pill in my hand and was talking with my older play sister Violet and was like – man, I got to take this pilgrimage. I was crying. I don't want to take this pill, I don't want to have to do this the rest of my life. Why I got to go through it? And that was kind of a Debbie Downer moment. But I got over it real quick.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: I guess HIV is still (having happened to me) is still a meaningful experience in that basically it kind of just having to deal with it, again you're going to learn a lot about yourself, a lot about the people around you, who’s really for you and who’s really not. Really if you're going to take care of yourself, I thought I was resourceful and knew a lot about survival, but yes, to a whole other level have I had to learn about survival and resourcefulness from having HIV just in terms of being a working person without health insurance and making too much for Ryan White or ADAT and having to find medication, things like that.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I'm a (crying) good person, because of WIHS and people like you and ID Clinic, I'm living with a disease. I have a disease; the disease don’t have me anymore. It’s a part of me but it ain't got me by no means. I’ve been undetected for five years and I was diagnosed in 2010. So I think I did pretty good.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: When they gave it to me I could be at the dope house, call my friend up – I forgot to take my medicine, can you bring it to me? That’s how serious I was that this is not going to beat me, I'm going to beat it. And now as I look back over my life, I wouldn't change a thing, nothing would I have changed. Because what I got now is way, way better than what I had then. My children love me, my family still loves me, but most of all I love me! And if I can love me, who cares what people think or people say?

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I was told at, [diagnosed] I was at this place called Durham Center Access. I had gone there because I was homeless, I didn't have anyplace to stay, and they happened to be doing HIV testing and I had no idea I was HIV positive. It didn't take them long to let me know that I was positive. I was a little stunned but I mean, it didn't make me crazy or anything. I just knew I needed to find out what I needed to do at that point. That’s when I asked them what I needed to do and they told me I needed to start going to the health department, the EI Clinic, that I could get some medication and get some help there. So that’s what I did. Since I found out I was HIV positive, I have no problems at all, I am doing very well. It doesn’t bother me. You know what I'm saying? And I had hepatitis C, I'm rid of that now, I got in a Duke study and got the free medicine and all that. I'm real grateful.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: HIV’s not going to kill me. Like you said…I feel the same way. I got it, it don’t have me. It don’t have me.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: He knew in ’89 that he had AIDS. But it wasn’t his responsibility – it was mine to protect myself.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I was on drugs, a lot of different sex partners. They looked like they didn’t have anything, nice guys I thought, but just didn’t think about   protection.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: In my opinion… I think when there's the list of things, the reasons or ways to get HIV, I can check every one of them. So I don’t really know. But I'm sure if I wasn’t using I might not have been with a few of those guys, you know? I don't know. I think it was heroin use, IV drug using. I think that was…but a few of the people that I did have sex with also used heroin and also had HIV. But I didn't really know that they had HIV until I started getting clean and I started really getting educated about it.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: Okay, when I contracted HIV I was, okay I was using drugs. I got involved with this guy because, what happened was, my husband had passed away and I was really mean, I was really bad to this man, and he was really good to me. He passed away and I didn't do nothing, I felt so bad. And then I said – the next man I have I want to be really good you know? But it didn't work out like that because this guy, he knew he had the virus, he didn't tell me, the mom knew she didn't tell me you know, and she kept saying just don’t have no babies, you’re getting tooold for that, because she knew that he had the virus. How can you not tell me? I didn't have it. So this man, whenever I went out he would have girls in my house, he used to be a lot with this girl that had AIDS in my neighborhood but I never suspected that he was, you know, doing anything with her. So that’s how I contracted it.

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: A specialist girlfriend of mine called me from Evanston, everybody knew we were getting married, this guy and I. And I came in from church and she said – sit down. I went – what’s up? She said, the guy you're engaged to is dying from AIDS. I went – I'm not engaged to him anymore. And then she said – well, you were with him for over two years and you said you stopped using condoms after you became engaged because – I thought he was safe. But he wasn’t. So um she said – get to Evanston Hospital, and I got out there and they knew nothing about this virus, and at that time you had to wait like a month for results. And when this young intern came in he looked at me and he said – Delores? I said – what? He said – (whispering) you’re going to die. I automatically started hyperventilating (deep breaths).

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: I’m from Canada. My dad came to visit me for two weeks. And he told me, he said – there’s something about this guy is not right. I had a big rock on my finger, it was all good, you know! And he was a professor at Northwestern, and I went – yes! My ship has finally come in. But he lied to his family, he lied to me. And then people were calling me saying they were lawyers, we could sue his estate. I never did because it was too much of a stigma. The Evanston newspapers wanted to interview me, I didn’t want no one to know. But now it’s not a death sentence, and I don’t care who knows.

list.subject: Mae
list.extract: Finally we went to about the third or fourth doctor and as soon as we got there he said – what’s your problem? So we told them this, this, and this are his symptoms. And he said – have you been tested for HIV? And we said – no! I didn't even think of that and I thought, let them test him, I know that…how could that be? We were living, we had our two kids…that would be the furthest thing from my mind. I thought he had cancer…

list.subject: Mae
list.extract: He was past the HIV stage and his count was 12. The doctor basically said you know it’s just a matter of time. He could last two weeks, he could last two months, but he’s not going to last long.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: But if you're living your life and you call yourself doing good and doing everything you're supposed to do, and something happens, you're like no, that ain't me! I don't know how that happened. Because all I knew was the drug addicts and the prostitutes and the people who was shooting drugs were getting HIV. And then when it hit me and I wasn’t doing any of that, I'm like – oh my God, this is wrong, this is not happening. And then when I got tested again it still said the same thing. I'm like – why me? Why was I the chosen one? Why he didn't tell me? And I don't know if I could have been better prepared to say yes, I will stay with you or I will leave, I don't know. He took that choice from me. The choice that he took from me, I wish he hadda told me, I don't know if I would have left. I really don’t. But the fact is – I wanted to know. Because he took a portion of my life.

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract:
1989, I received a letter from my husband at the time from his office…Yes, my husband had gone in and was diagnosed with a skin disorder and when they did the blood work I guess something else came up, and that’s when I got a letter from his doctor’s office stating
 that they wanted me to come in for some blood work. And I thought it was in relation to the skin disease that he was going to be treated for.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: I met my husband and we fell in love pretty fast. I believed the man loved me, don’t get me wrong. And he’s not without problems because he was probably, well, I know actually, I figured it out. We got married fast, we fell in love fast, we were married within a couple of months. I figured out that he’s probably bipolar. We were married about 11 months, and he got beat really bad. He liked to go to the bars and he was willing to fight, too, just like the other goofballs. He ended up in the hospital and I asked for a psych eval, which they said – we can’t do that just because you want it. Then they started suspecting HIV because of the dementia and all the brain damage…they felt there was something more going on. So they took the test and he came out positive, and they also figured out that he was bipolar in the process. At that time I took the test and I was negative.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract:
We still married before things got bad because I felt like nobody would want to be with me, why would I be with anybody else? We're going to get married; he wants me, nobody else ever will want the woman living with HIV. So after the wedding is when he told me, through an argument, because I asked a lot of questions like – how did you contract this? Were you doing drugs, were you promiscuous, were you having sex with sex workers undercover, down low…what's going on? 
	The argument ended in – yes, I knew, I already knew I was positive and so what? Now what do you want to do because you already have it, there's nothing you can do.

list.subject: Claristine
list.extract: And, so he said Monday I need you to go to that appointment, don’t forget, can you rearrange your schedule? I need to know if you're going to go.  I said – I’ll be able to go, I can get somebody else to work at the daycare.  Soon as I come in the lady had this thing…before I get in the door she trying to put this in my mouth, what is this?  He was just sitting there like – oh God…that’s what he was doing, like – oh God.  She said [C] [her husband], I know you had your wife to come up here and you didn't tell her what she was coming for.  He said it was my job to get up here; it was y’all job to tell her. There she is, now tell her. The lady said, Mrs. [J] , can we please swab your mouth?  I said no, why?  So she told me, she said – we want to test you for HIV.  I looked and he had his head down like this. So I said, go ahead.  I let them swab my mouth.   But I knew by the expression on her face that I was positive.

list.subject: FB
list.extract:
Tammy:....Did you ever run the streets? 
FB: No. 
Tammy: Dang! She shouldn’t be here….Do you know how you contracted HIV? 
FB Yes, I do. 
Jennie Do you want to tell us the story? 
FB My husband stayed in the streets, like I say I was working 10, 12, 16 hours a day in the factories. And he would run the roads. He was doing street drugs and this that and the other. Like I say, I never thought the first time, because he never told me he was out there for, just out getting drugs, but evidently he brought the big boy home. And I told him, I said – if you ever go back to prison, I'm leaving. So when he went back to prison I filed for divorce and left. And then I got to getting sick and it had to come from him.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract:
Here’s the other thing. So because I grew up seeing how men treated women, I treated men the same way they treated us. So I always had more than one. 
 So that brings me to how I got HIV. I think I was going through another depressive episode, wasn’t on medication, I was like in nursing school, probably using sex as my drug of choice at the time, had like four partners. So then when I found out I had HIV I didn't even know which one it came from, although I pretty much had a sneaking suspicion; I narrowed it down to like two of the four. I was like, It’s definitely one of these two clowns over here

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: They gave me an HIV test without my consent, and I know it’s because I bit that nurse. When they came back to the room later on they said – Miss Wanda, did you know you was HIV positive? What! And immediately I thought you all did something, they did something to me, they nailed me because I bit that nurse, they done shot me up with some HIV (laughter), somebody else’s blood. Girl, I thought that for the longest time! Yes. And then, but I remember I had a friend back home up in Maryland that used to go mess with this girl who died from AIDS, and we had sexual encounters, but he’s walking around like nothing never happened. And he’s still trying to hook up with me today! Like he don't know. I'm more than sure that’s where I got it from, but I never let on to him that I have this and I think you got it and you need to go get it checked out…I never said a word to this day? I'm good with it, but then I'm not.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: He knew in ’89 that he had AIDS. But it wasn’t his responsibility – it was mine to protect myself.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: And somebody knew somebody who knew somebody who knew somebody who knew my husband, because I got married in ’90, and that’s when I found out I was HIV positive. But he married me anyway. I did the programs, I was clean and everything; in ’91 I went right back, I lost my daughter to the system. Got my daughter back in ’92 a year later, got her back but in the process of getting her back and going out to Amityville, Long Island to visit her in the foster care and the programs and stuff, I picked right back up, using.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I was diagnosed at Brookdale Hospital and I always say that they almost killed me before they healed me. I always say they almost killed me before they healed me. Every time I used to come to the clinic I used to always cry, cry, cry all the time. But now keep my appointment, I come to the clinic faithfully, even though I know what I’m here for, I do not stress about it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I have years from childhood stuff that I hold in, hold in, hold in. And I didn’t know, I didn’t know, until I started releasing, releasing when I went to see...first when I was diagnosed, a little later on, the feeling didn’t hit then, but when the feeling hit that took me into be depressed...I used to always cry all the time, I didn’t know why I was crying. And I remember when I was first diagnosed I told them that I needed a support system, so they had sent me to 57 Willoughby Street and I sat there almost a whole year and I never talk or nothing.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: For me to be diagnosed it was like a relief to know what was wrong with me, because I suffered. Before I was diagnosed I suffered. They was treating me for asthma, giving me all kind of asthma pumps and stuff. This went on for two months, giving me all types of asthma pumps and when I go to the emergency rooms they give me a treat-ment and send me back home. Meanwhile everything I did, I’m gasping for breath, gasping for breath, gasping for breath. This went on for two months.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I was diagnosed in 2010. And only I had an HIV test one time because I got tired of them asking me to take a HIV test. I think it was like in ’85 or something. No, my youngest son was born in ’89so it probably was about in ’90, that’s the last time I had a HIV test and it had came back negative. And I think it was in ’85; that’s when you had to wait two weeks.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: No, no. Even my brother, my brother was recently in the hospital, he was in ICU because he said they said he had a lung infection. I told my brother, I said—do they know you HIV positive? He told me—I’m not HIV positive. And I know he is! Because I remember when he was first diagnosed and sick in the hospital.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: The first person I told was my youngest daughter. Even though she grown, the first person I told my youngest daughter because that was the day that I had took the test. I never forget, I was in Brookdale Hospital and I took her in the bathroom and I told her, I said — you know that they found out that I have the virus? — just like that. And I had started crying. She said —  Mommy, we’re going to get through this, we’re going to get through this.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: What it was that they was —‘cause all I was thinking—‘something’s wrong with my pregnancy.’ I wasn’t even thinking about the HIV test, at all. So when I got there I’m like — what’s the problem? She said — Oh we tested — You remember you consented to the HIV test. ‘Yeah, okay.’ She said, ‘Well the test came back positive.’ And I’m looking at her. I didn’t say anything, I just looked at her. ‘What?’ She said—test came back positive. ‘How is that possible?’

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I met someone and I knew he was a drug dealer and I went out with him and I never thought nothing of it. And I wasn’t diagnosed until I left Beacon and came to Queens because I was checked in Beacon and I was fine. So when you switch to another state you got go to a new clinic...The doctor said — can I do an HIV test? I said yes, you can, because I’m fine. ’91. When she came back and told me I was HIV— because back in the days I thought you were just dying. I didn’t read up, I should have, and I started to cry and I told her —  ‘now what? You don’t want to touch me?’ Oh God, that doctor hugged me so hard.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: Well, throughout the years I was always a stable, positive woman. I never was aware, never went into any type of community, I was very naïve when it came to HIV and AIDS. I was married to a man that gave me three children and everything went well, but him and I were divorced; this is my first husband. Then I met this second man and this second man actually had the virus. A very good man, now don’t get me wrong. He didn’t drink, he didn’t smoke, he was a hard-working guy. But he was a single guy that lived with his parents and apparently he used to get sexual favors from women and in one of them favors that he got from somewhere out there, it gave him HIV and then I found out by getting sick and losing weight and constant diarrhea. I went to get tested and that’s when I found out. This was in 1989, so I’ve been positive going on almost 30 years.

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: Because if you don’t take your medicine you won't be okay, period point blank. And it took a long time for them to even recognize women in anything when it comes to this disease, and then to focus on what works for us. Because what works for us is not working for men. You understand? Because I had two children before they even told me – ask me about being HIV positive or taking an HIV test. But they test them other two children I had and they never told me one way or the other with them, but I know that they're not, because time goes on. But I’ll be here for you baby.

list.subject: Loretta
list.extract: Well, really, I never knew I had it, I guess through someone that I interacted with ‘cause I didn’t even know I had it. I went to what do you call those hospitals, those clinics... [CAROL:Health Station?] Yes, I went to the Health Station. And lo and behold they told me I had it, and it was like a pile of bricks dropped on me. And I was alone when I found out, no one was with me, and it was like a pile of bricks just fell on me. But I dealt with it.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: That’s when I was incarcerated and I just so happened to take the test and it came back positive. I was incarcerated. I think they was trying to find out who has it in the penal system or not, and that’s how I found out.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: Yes. When I was at a halfway house it was disclosed; the attitudes and the snickers and the stares behind my back, you could just feel it, you know? Nobody...they would clean the toilet after I used it. You can’t catch it like that.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: When I first found out I was in denial. I wouldn’t take no medication. They only had AZT back then; I declined it because people was dying. Now I’m on a regimen that is working, I’m undetectable, I want to live now. I was self-destructive when I first found out. Now I just want to live another 33 years (laughter).

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: Oh, I was devastated but also I was actually still coming down from the high, because I got locked up, I was high when I got locked up. Have to go through the bullpen and all that. I was coming down, so really it wasn’t registering, I didn’t know what the hell they was talking about (laughter) until I seen pamphlets and stuff about it.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: I was raped by a trick, who had HIV. I was raped in 2000, but I didn’t find out until 2003 when I was incarcerated, in jail, on Rikers Island.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: matter of fact, well I’d been incarcerated like go to Rikers Island, I’d go for like three days, 7 at the most. And I was 37 years old and the judge gave me a one to three. She said — I’m not going to give you city I don’t understand you wait so long to get a record, I’m going to teach you a tough lesson. So she sent me upstate. I was in Beacon Correctional Facility. This was in ’96. I had long dreads in my hair. Long dreadlocks. Anyway, the judge said she going to teach me a tough lesson and she did, okay? Just so happened I said — let me take a HIV test. I took the test and it came back positive. I was like devastated. But matter of fact prior to that, well my sister she also suffers from gland problems, my glands kept swolling up, swolling up, and my ear was hurting, made everything hurt. So I went and had a biopsy done and that’s when I found out I was positive

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: Felt like somebody took the floor from under me. There was noth-ing I could step on, I was just whew, like getting on an elevator and going down!

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: They test you in all these places but the thing about it that they never told me – there was one time that I got tested when I was in program and they gave me my diagnosis in a closed, in a sealed envelope. And I brought it home and then I couldn't read it, and I was scared to ask anybody to read it because then they would know if it was positive or not. I kept it, I held it, so then this one guy that I started going with, I finally got the nerve to ask him to read it and then when I went to get the letter…I couldn't find it. I don’t even know if I was positive then or not. But when I went to detox and I came back, that was in January, I was still in the methadone program but I stopped using everything else. And they offered the test again and I took it, and that’s when I found out, and that was in March of ’91.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: The first person that I disclosed to was my mom. As soon as I found out I had HIV, they said they would do the test and they did it. When it came back that it was positive again, I called my mom and said, “Mom, guess what? I'm positive. You positive? What are you talking about? I said I'm HIV positive. Oh, okay. You just gotta take care of yourself, that’ll be the lifestyle that you live, you gotta take care of yourself you know? Try not to get sick. Because I had a brother that died of AIDS and now a lot of people are living, people aren't dying like they were back then.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: I was never a street worker, I never had to get out there like that. And when I did graduate from high school I went straight into start working. I always have had good jobs... I was doing good things but bad things at the same time. Basically all my jobs that I did have, they were good jobs. That’s how I lost them, because of the drugs, because I would be tired and call in—I can’t come today. And then in 1992 I was feeling like…I lost my mom in ‘99 but in ‘92 I was feeling, it was around the time when Magic Johnson got diagnosedand everyone was kind of running to the little neighborhood clinics.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: And I went to the clinic in Englewood... and the only reason that I actually went though at that point was because I was feeling, I was cramping and I was like well, because I had just had a period you know. I’m like – something ain’t right. ... [ J ]ust so happened in the midst of me drinking and drugging and not paying attention and being unaware of what I’m doing, there was a condom in me. And that’s why I was cramping. And when they took this condom out of me they told me that I had HIV, gonorrhea, syphilis, and herpes.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: [MY MOTHER] was like—well Sister (that’s my nickname, Sister) no use in keeping it a secret; it’s something you gotta live with now. You should just tell the rest of them, they’ll be understanding. And me knowing the type of family and sisters that I had, I knew that they would handle a problem, if anything they would be catering to me. I told them and that’s exactly what it was. They were catering to me, still ‘til today they—Sister, what’s your cell count? Because now they are more aware about it, especially with one of my sisters being a doctor. I’ve never been hospitalized before, I’ve never been sick, very seldom have a cold, my T-cell count always have been in the 800s, undetectable, even the herpes breakouts that I usually have on you know my bottom part, I don’t even have them that much more.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I ended up in the penitentiary with my youngest daughter with a friend, my second diagnosis in five years, still not knowing what it is that I have. Got out of the penitentiary and there was a DCFS worker waiting for me at the gate. And he told me that if I thought I wanted my kids back I probably wouldn't get them back because I had HIV. But he brought me to the wrong place, he took me to the Fantus Clinic at Stroger Hospital. And that was his mistake, taking me to the Fantus Clinic because not only did they educate me about HIV, they educated me about my rights concerning HIV and you know, that nobody could take my child simply because…there were people trying to.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: This was ’85.  And the doctor came in and started asking me about my life and my habits.  And he came back and he goes – your baby has HIV so I'm pretty sure you have it, too. He walked away and I let him.  It was just like everything else in my life, nobody explained it to me, nobody told me anything.  So after a week or so in the hospital they let my daughter come home, she was better.  Her immune system had kicked in, kicked mine out, she is not positive.

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: A specialist girlfriend of mine called me from Evanston, everybody knew we were getting married, this guy and I. And I came in from church and she said – sit down. I went – what’s up? She said, the guy you're engaged to is dying from AIDS. I went – I'm not engaged to him anymore. And then she said – well, you were with him for over two years and you said you stopped using condoms after you became engaged because – I thought he was safe. But he wasn’t. So um she said – get to Evanston Hospital, and I got out there and they knew nothing about this virus, and at that time you had to wait like a month for results. And when this young intern came in he looked at me and he said – Delores? I said – what? He said – (whispering) you’re going to die. I automatically started hyperventilating (deep breaths).

list.subject: Mae
list.extract: Finally we went to about the third or fourth doctor and as soon as we got there he said – what’s your problem? So we told them this, this, and this are his symptoms. And he said – have you been tested for HIV? And we said – no! I didn't even think of that and I thought, let them test him, I know that…how could that be? We were living, we had our two kids…that would be the furthest thing from my mind. I thought he had cancer…

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: When I had him I was never given prenatal care and then on top of that I was shooting drugs, I was drinking, I'm surprised he came out a perfect baby like he did. But the thing was, when he came out he had drugs in his system….So when I got to the hospital he was gone. But before they even did all that, they released me and kept him because they had to let him detox. Before they even did all that they came in my room, the doctor, fully gowned I mean from head to toe looking like astronauts and told me I had AIDS. They didn't say nothing about HIV positive, and did I want to talk to a chaplain? And you know if you have to talk to a chaplain, that means, you know, you don’t have long to live. It could be today or tomorrow. That’s because they didn't really know that much about HIV or AIDS you know?

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: commercials were coming out and I know I had done drugs in the past and I was drinking and I know I had multiple partners with no condoms and those commercials on TV were, all they had to do, they were just missing saying, “Marta!” To me, they were directed to me, and I remember yes, just kind of sitting there. I was like oh okay, I’ve got somebody talking down on me, I gotta go get tested. And eventually I took myself in to get tested and once I was tested, since I kinda, you know the checlist kinda goes off yeah-yeah-yeah... you are Positive. The result came back. And I remember that rush of sorta numbness but yet trying to get it back.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: But if you're living your life and you call yourself doing good and doing everything you're supposed to do, and something happens, you're like no, that ain't me! I don't know how that happened. Because all I knew was the drug addicts and the prostitutes and the people who was shooting drugs were getting HIV. And then when it hit me and I wasn’t doing any of that, I'm like – oh my God, this is wrong, this is not happening. And then when I got tested again it still said the same thing. I'm like – why me? Why was I the chosen one? Why he didn't tell me? And I don't know if I could have been better prepared to say yes, I will stay with you or I will leave, I don't know. He took that choice from me. The choice that he took from me, I wish he hadda told me, I don't know if I would have left. I really don’t. But the fact is – I wanted to know. Because he took a portion of my life.

list.subject: Racheal
list.extract: I wasn’t surprised that I tested positive because of the lifestyle I had lived, but I was still hurt. It wasn’t like it was a shock because of the lifestyle I had lived. But it still was a painful moment to me. And she let me sit down there and she said you can go ahead and cry. And the first thing I thought was – it’s a death sentence, I’m dying…not knowing what I know about HIV now, I thought I was going to die, and that’s been seven years ago. Now I’m here, I’m living here, I’m undetectable, my T-cells are great. I’m as healthy as a horse.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract:
1989, I received a letter from my husband at the time from his office…Yes, my husband had gone in and was diagnosed with a skin disorder and when they did the blood work I guess something else came up, and that’s when I got a letter from his doctor’s office stating
 that they wanted me to come in for some blood work. And I thought it was in relation to the skin disease that he was going to be treated for.

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract: Because here I am, a white single female, heterosexual, having contracted it through my ex-husband, so where does that leave me? So that’s why I’m very in favor of getting the knowledge out there to the young ones, because for every…I think statistically, for every one person who knows that they are HIV, there’s 100 who don’t know. It’s important. But I think in general the public knows it… because every once in a while the news will report— it’s no longer a death sentence and all that, but it’s a lot more complicated than that.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: I met my husband and we fell in love pretty fast. I believed the man loved me, don’t get me wrong. And he’s not without problems because he was probably, well, I know actually, I figured it out. We got married fast, we fell in love fast, we were married within a couple of months. I figured out that he’s probably bipolar. We were married about 11 months, and he got beat really bad. He liked to go to the bars and he was willing to fight, too, just like the other goofballs. He ended up in the hospital and I asked for a psych eval, which they said – we can’t do that just because you want it. Then they started suspecting HIV because of the dementia and all the brain damage…they felt there was something more going on. So they took the test and he came out positive, and they also figured out that he was bipolar in the process. At that time I took the test and I was negative.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: I just felt so comfortable with him. I always felt I belonged to be with him. No matter what happened, and believe me, a lot of things went bad, I always felt that man loved me. And I love him, he’s the love of my life. I can’t be with him, I haven’t seen him in two years, I can’t have nothing to do with him anymore. I had to draw lines up. Because he won’t stop with the drinking and things happened, I live with my family, I have to be there for my family and I can’t have the two intermingling. And of course everybody hates him because they know he gave me HIV eventually, which is wild, because I maybe had sex with my husband maybe twice in one year. Not because I didn’t love him, because I love and find him attractive, but I had my own issues, physical, or whatever, menopause, so I just couldn’t bear the pain. But twice in one year…and I got HIV. I got very sick and my friend said – I’m going to take you down to Cook County Hospital, my friend Donny, and he said you better have that tested because he knew my husband had HIV already like eight years, and that’s pretty much when I separated from my husband. I told him to stay with his mother. I was homeless, sleeping in a garage. I ended up homeless and broke. I wanted my husband to try to get into rehab or something, and his family…forget that. They’re all losers.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: I was diagnosed in June 1992, June the 4th. At the same time I was diagnosed, two or three days later, my nephew got killed….All the emotion and everything running around, but when this was diagnosed with me, I was mad as hell. I was mad as hell because I felt that God had traded…but when things happen to people, they think of all crazy kinda stuff. That’s a human. You think – why did this happen to you? You might be a good person, you might be a bad person. But I was mad as hell.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh, my prayers, I made this prayer when I got clean. I said –God, if I ever use any illegal drugs I want you to take me out right now (laughter) because that was the worst two-year stint of my life. It was only two years but it was the worse. I think living with HIV was better than being on drugs...Um, drugs control your mind. They control your mind, your character, it control your moods, it controls everything. Your bank account, it controls you…your whole ability to thinking. And I had no control over my life for those two years. It was like – I was losing me. And really and truly HIV was an easier task than being on drugs. If I didn't have my mom I probably would still be out there, really in a bad situation in the streets. I never got to the point of doing things for drugs because I had family that tried that kept me off the streets, or tried to keep me off the streets. So I was good on that level but (sigh) I still did a lot of things that I'm not proud of back then, yes.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: No. Actually when I first got my results my younger brother came with me. And back in those days it was a death sentence so it took him to get my mind right, I mean really. Back then it was just coming out and to find out that you were HIV positive meant that you would be dead in a month or two. So my brother was there with me and he was very supportive...In 1989, 1990, yeah something around there...(sigh) It was the beginning to an end, that’s what I thought. It was like okay, I have two kids, my mom is sickly, what am I going to do? In my mind I was like oh my God I'm dying. And then I had no God at that time, I wasn’t into church, so to me I had nothing to turn to but my kids. I wanted to live for them. Everything around me wanted to be alive for them. (tears)

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: They do. I think everybody who knows me, knows (laughter). I'm very open with my status, though it was not always that way. When I first got diagnosed I kept it from my family for a long time. The first ones who knew in my family was my Dad. The day that I got diagnosed I told my Dad, I just didn't want to be by myself with it. It wasn’t, I didn't have embarrassment, it wasn’t that type of feeling, it was more fear if anything. I'm so open about my health and everything that I felt like it was something the family should know so they can be there to support you. I didn't tell my children for, I don't know, at least three years. So you know, that part was scary. My mom, my sisters, just that experience was, it was surprising because the responses were different than what I expected. So now everyone knows because I'm extremely outspoken. And I don't know, it’s okay, almost like it’s not there.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract:
Oh gosh, a wonderful, wonderful diagnosis. It was really devastating, because I thought I had lymphoma cancer. I'm a researcher and I'm very, very in tune with my body so I know when something’s not right. I caught a cold, turned into strep, and then the lymph nodes in my neck swelled up. They swelled so bad that I couldn't really turn my neck and I could see lumps sitting outside my neck and I'm just like – oh my gosh, what is that? So researching all the symptoms I had led to lymphoma. Okay, I'm going to call my doctor, I think it’s this but I'm not a doctor so I don't know. And also it wasn’t like okay, this is hanging on for like two days. We’re talking weeks this thing is going on. So I'm scared, call the doctor, I said – I want a biopsy. 
	Well, when I went in, went to the health department, and they had already had test results from my last HIV test. Normally I never go back for an HIV test, any STD tests were always negative. And I knew how to protect myself. Well, I had been tested since I’d been with my now ex-husband and I didn't go back for test results, because they're always negative. Well, the health department failed to contact me. I slipped through the cracks, they actually told me that because they were trying to say well, we tried to call you, we tried to send you a letter…well no, you didn't. I still live at the same place, phone number’s been the same for years, no you didn't. Just long story short they told me I slipped through the cracks but when I got the news, the nurse couldn't even verbally tell me. Because they all knew me, I'm a really nice person and when I go into places I become a joy (laughter). 
	When I went there I'm sitting in a room, half the size of the room I’m in now, and she pushes a folder towards me and opens it and in red it said HIV Positive. And that’s how I learned. She just couldn’t…It wasn’t that she wasn’t being professional, she was hurt, she was hurt for me. Because her whole demeanor just I just didn't understand. When I got it I screamed, I cried, man I just wanted to leave. I tried to get my keys and my purse, I went to get it and it was gone because she had it hiding behind her and she was barricading the door and she just didn't want me to leave. I understand that. I was telling this story to someone before and they're like – oh my gosh why would she do that? For my protection. I was upset, I was distraught, and I wanted to get in my car and drive. Well, what if I did that? I could have had an accident or anything could have happened. But hearing that news, gosh…

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Once I embraced it because you hear – ok you're HIV positive. For some people, you have these feelings of oh my gosh, you're just still in shock. Some people can be in denial; I was never in denial, I was still just in shock. One day I was able to accept it. I was just like – deep breath, okay, it’s a part of my life. There's nothing I can do. I can't go get a shot and make it go away, I can't take medicine and make it go away. It’s always going to be there, on paper they’ll always have that December 13, 2001 I was diagnosed with HIV. I just embraced it and said you know what? What else can I do? Cause I can't allow this to weigh heavy on me because I have too many other responsibilities in life than to worry about this one thing.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: On New Year’s Eve 2006 we were getting testing done at our church in Maryland. My pastor Tony Lee, A Community of Hope Church. We did HIV testing. And I came back positive along with one of my sons who tested with me. We had to go to Johns Hopkins to get retested and prior to that weekend, I just prayed a lot and just asked to reverse everything on me so my son wouldn't be positive, because he was getting ready to go away to college. I just didn't want him to have to live his life like that...He came back negative. And I came back positive, I remember clearly because the doctor was like – well Miss, your son came back negative but you came back positive still. I was just happy and jumping up and down, yay! He’s like – but I'm telling you, you're still positive. I said that’s okay, my son is negative, I can handle it. I’ve been through abuse, been through addiction, been through sexual abuse. I can handle this.

list.subject: Claristine
list.extract: And, so he said Monday I need you to go to that appointment, don’t forget, can you rearrange your schedule? I need to know if you're going to go.  I said – I’ll be able to go, I can get somebody else to work at the daycare.  Soon as I come in the lady had this thing…before I get in the door she trying to put this in my mouth, what is this?  He was just sitting there like – oh God…that’s what he was doing, like – oh God.  She said [C] [her husband], I know you had your wife to come up here and you didn't tell her what she was coming for.  He said it was my job to get up here; it was y’all job to tell her. There she is, now tell her. The lady said, Mrs. [J] , can we please swab your mouth?  I said no, why?  So she told me, she said – we want to test you for HIV.  I looked and he had his head down like this. So I said, go ahead.  I let them swab my mouth.   But I knew by the expression on her face that I was positive.
