list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well there was a time…When I first realized what I had, I didn't want to get better. I did not want to get better, but I knew my son was trying to have a child and I asked God – if said you just let me live long enough to see my grandbaby, then whatever comes, comes. And that helped me get through a lot of it. And my sisters kept telling me – you can do this, you can do this. I was like everybody else; I was dumb. I thought it was a death sentence. When I got to working with Dr. Kozel and everything, she would talk to me and she didn't think I was going to make it, but she kept my hopes up. So I had to pull myself out of that to be able to make myself go on. And my sisters would come over and help me and make sure I had my medicine because like I said, I couldn't remember nothing; I couldn't remember when to take medicine, what day, what it looked like.

list.subject: FB
list.extract:
Tammy:....Did you ever run the streets? 
FB: No. 
Tammy: Dang! She shouldn’t be here….Do you know how you contracted HIV? 
FB Yes, I do. 
Jennie Do you want to tell us the story? 
FB My husband stayed in the streets, like I say I was working 10, 12, 16 hours a day in the factories. And he would run the roads. He was doing street drugs and this that and the other. Like I say, I never thought the first time, because he never told me he was out there for, just out getting drugs, but evidently he brought the big boy home. And I told him, I said – if you ever go back to prison, I'm leaving. So when he went back to prison I filed for divorce and left. And then I got to getting sick and it had to come from him.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: My self-esteem before was good. I had a good job, a nicehome, but then after that it all went downhill....What most worries me about this here is I’ve seen so many people being hurt over this, just over the three letters. They don’t care that you got feelings. And just for my family to know, I really don't know how they would react to it. They might react the way you think they would, but I’ve head them talk you know? What I’ve heard, I remember somebody and this boy had it and by that time I had it and they said – that boy’s got HIV. And said we're going to stay away from him, don’t get anything from rubbing up on him, this that and the other…I got thinking to myself, that’s the way they're going to treat me. And I seen this boy, and I said – don’t you think that this time he needs a friend? He don’t need everybody running away from him you know? I sit down and when I realized what I did have, I sit down and kind of looked it up to see what was going on.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract:
Here’s the other thing. So because I grew up seeing how men treated women, I treated men the same way they treated us. So I always had more than one. 
 So that brings me to how I got HIV. I think I was going through another depressive episode, wasn’t on medication, I was like in nursing school, probably using sex as my drug of choice at the time, had like four partners. So then when I found out I had HIV I didn't even know which one it came from, although I pretty much had a sneaking suspicion; I narrowed it down to like two of the four. I was like, It’s definitely one of these two clowns over here

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: In 2010, I went to Johnson County to the health department because my significant other was cheating and I needed to find out if I had contracted anything. When I went they had been looking for me and I can't really remember, they could tell me exactly how long they’d been looking for me because Wake County had notified Johnson County that they had been looking for me. But I was out using and running the streets and doing what I wanted to do, and I didn't stay at one place long. So they couldn't get up with me. But, I went to be STD tested and they had a picture of me, my name, Social Security number, and asked was that me? And I said yes, and they said well sit down, we have something to tell you. And I wouldn't sit down. They said – you're HIV positive. I denied it, I raised Cain, I put some people out. I said I'm not going nowhere until y’all test me right now. They took me around the corner, drew my blood, told me they’d get back in touch with me. I know that y’all got the machines or whatever y’all need to let me know right now that y’all didn't make no mistake. About 45 minutes later she came back and said – yes ma'am.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: I was out walking on the block or in the hood or whatever, and this guy pulled up, I'm thinking it’s just another regular trick, you know? And he asked me my name and I said yes, that’s me. He said – would you mind if I talked to you for a minute? And he showed me his badge from the health department. And I knew it couldn't have been nothing good, you know? It’s the man from the health department, you know? It’s something! So we talked and he told me they were looking for me because somebody gave them my name that I had slept with and they had tested positive for HIV. And at that moment, at that time right then, my world just completely collapsed. Just completely collapsed. It just, um I can't even think of the word for it. I didn't understand, I didn't understand right then at that moment – why me? But as time has went on – why not me? You know? Why not me, I put myself in that predicament. I did things I shouldn’t have done and this is the result of my self-will.

list.subject: Velvet
list.extract: It was 2010, this was before my father passed. That’s when I found out that I had HIV. I was staying at my sister’s and I was sick, I was getting sicker, I was losing weight, I was not eating, I had no appetite, my great-niece at the time came in the room where I was and she was about five years old, she said – auntie? I said, yeah baby? She said are you sick? I said yes, I gotta go to the bathroom. I got up and she said – you want me to help you? She grabbed me, she got me by my hand and was walking with me and said – auntie, why are you sick? I said honey, I said baby I don't know. So she said – do you want something to eat? I said no. She said – I'm going to go downstairs and I’m going to put a can of chicken noodle soup in the microwave for you. I said – make sure you don’t burn yourself, it was warm enough to her taste. She brought it upstairs and I said – sit it over there, I’ll eat a little bit at a time. Then I went into the bathroom and I took all of my clothes off, I looked in the mirror and just looked at myself, I just looked at myself and this thought came to me, I don't know why that thought came to me but the words that came outta my mouth was…you're HIV positive.

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I was told at, [diagnosed] I was at this place called Durham Center Access. I had gone there because I was homeless, I didn't have anyplace to stay, and they happened to be doing HIV testing and I had no idea I was HIV positive. It didn't take them long to let me know that I was positive. I was a little stunned but I mean, it didn't make me crazy or anything. I just knew I needed to find out what I needed to do at that point. That’s when I asked them what I needed to do and they told me I needed to start going to the health department, the EI Clinic, that I could get some medication and get some help there. So that’s what I did. Since I found out I was HIV positive, I have no problems at all, I am doing very well. It doesn’t bother me. You know what I'm saying? And I had hepatitis C, I'm rid of that now, I got in a Duke study and got the free medicine and all that. I'm real grateful.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: They gave me an HIV test without my consent, and I know it’s because I bit that nurse. When they came back to the room later on they said – Miss Wanda, did you know you was HIV positive? What! And immediately I thought you all did something, they did something to me, they nailed me because I bit that nurse, they done shot me up with some HIV (laughter), somebody else’s blood. Girl, I thought that for the longest time! Yes. And then, but I remember I had a friend back home up in Maryland that used to go mess with this girl who died from AIDS, and we had sexual encounters, but he’s walking around like nothing never happened. And he’s still trying to hook up with me today! Like he don't know. I'm more than sure that’s where I got it from, but I never let on to him that I have this and I think you got it and you need to go get it checked out…I never said a word to this day? I'm good with it, but then I'm not.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: Some damn fool, this HIV thing that’s what you're talking about, damn fool, he’s still trying to talk to me today, he done lost his mind. He got to know he got this thing, but I didn't tell him, he didn't tell me! Shit

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: I got a sharp tongue, had it all my life, I'm born with it. I was the darkest one. So I didn't want my aunties to call me – little black girl with the little short hair. Because everybody had a couple of inches or more.That bothered me. James Brown came out with this record in the ‘60s or‘70s…Say It Loud, I’m Black and I’m Proud.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: I became a somebody two or three years ago. That’s why I could put the makeup on, I could dress up the outside; but did it match the inside? No. I just got there. I just got it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: I’m a challenger, I still am. I’m a challenger.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: Like before I was diagnosed, I say the same thing now, that I never really was happy with myself — I wasn’t happy with myself and I didn’t know why. I was existing but not living. I was existing, I was not living. I remember after I suffered two months I was in my house, so I was diagnosed and went in the hospital and like a breeze came to me and told me that I’m going to borrow you for a minute. When I was in the hospital for that month, it was like I was in the hospital to introduce me to me. To connect with me, to find myself, to find myself, to rest and find myself. And my accomplish now is the relationship that I have with myself (crying). That I don’t have to be in a relationship with a man, I’m in a relationship with myself.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I’m in a relationship that I’ve never been in...and this is a strong relationship. It’s not my time to go outside myself. It’s not my time because I’m in a place I’ve never been; a relationship with myself. My mother used to tell me — good things will come to those who wait, and I never could wait. But it seems like this is my time. And if I ever get into a relationship, it’s going to be a relationship and I didn’t have to go searching, looking for it; it’s going to come to me.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: Oh boy, it seems like my life is better now that I am HIV positive because when I was HIV negative, like I said, I was existing. It’s like the virus brought me to me; the virus brought me to myself.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: The thing is, I was kind of like the tomboy of the group because of the fact that I watched all sports. I could sit with the fellas and talk sports all day long and everybody’s like—oh my goodness. And you know what you’re talking about! Because my mother brought me home from the hospital and my father was watching a game, he sat me in his lap and I sat there and watched the whole game with him. I didn’t fall asleep. I did not fall asleep. I’m three days old, I did not fall asleep, I’m just leaning on my dad, looking at the TV. And I’ve been watching sports ever since. I am a football fanatic, I love football. I even played football, that’s how much I loved football, the only girl on the football team but that was fine with me. So I wasn’t a typical girl. I had my moments when I wanted to be girly-girly and everything like that, but because I couldn’t stand just sitting around, just talking about people, that’s not who I am, that’s never who I’ve been. And that’s what most of the girls in the neighborhood did. I don’t do that. So I’m not even going to be bothered with y’all right now. So I was always hanging out with the guys, so people automati-cally assumed because I’m hanging out with the guys...I’m screw-ing the guys. Whatever! You say whatever you want! I know it’s the truth.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I was a clerk/typist for a medical malpractice law firm. That was like the first real job I ever had and I was part-time, I started out as part time and kind of pushed myself into full-time because what they needed me to do, it was a lot that needed to be done. So I was supposed to be at work at 1 o’clock; I would show up at 12. I would show up at 11. Then at 9, then at 8. So, you know. And I would do the work, and I was good at it. And then when the work cut down to a manageable point, I was able to, I went to my boss — can y’all teach me to do other things? So that’s when I started to do the mail, do the filing, and things like that. I was an exceptional typist. I’m 19 years old, my very first job, and I can type 85 words a minute. Because when I was eight, seven or eight, my father bought my sister an electric typewriter and I wanted to learn how to type. My mother had a manual typewriter, one of those old manual typewriters. She had a typing book, so I took her book and her typewriter because I wasn’t allowed to use my sister’s electric and I understood that. I was very hard on things, I was very heavy-handed, so I understood. I wasn’t offended. And I taught myself how to type.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: I have faith that there will be a cure, I have faith that I’m going to be living here a long time. I have faith in God. My spirituality is very high on my list because if I don’t have that spirit...my fiancée tells me I’m a very free spirit. Yes I want my spirit to always be free, but with a little caution added to it, you understand what I’m saying? I don’t want to be just free, free Willy, and I can be like that. I’ll be like come on Roz, come on Sue...that’s just how my spirit is. But I want to keep that in place but like I said with a little caution. Because not everybody’s going to be nice, good to you. Um, it means that for me, I’m going to find somebody like yourself that’s a free spirit, you know what I’m saying? And it’s not all bad being a free spirit, you just gotta be careful who you’re being that free spirit with. My free spirit got me homeless you know what I’m saying, I have absolutely nothing. I have life; I thank God every day for that. But I’m going to get everything back tenfold; God going to see to that.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: It was very hard, I was a little shy so I really didn’t talk too much, I didn’t like to talk because I had that country accent and the kids used to laugh at certain words I couldn’t pronounce right. So I really was a little quiet like. But on the outside when I was out in the street with my other friends I was just like a little loud ‘cause I was smoking, drinking around then. Wasn’t too good.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I’m comfortable with myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die as long as I take care of myself. It just means taking better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life...I’m a much better person now, stronger, confident, just you know ready to help whoever I can... I’m okay with it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: Thank God today I have been to groups and all kinds of educational programs, stuff like that. I learned so much about it. Yeah that is one thing, once I did find out about it, after a while, long about I’d say probably two years after I found out I think, I got myself together and I started pursuing to see what this HIV was about and how can I deal with it and live longer and that’s what I’ve been doing up until now. I just don’t feel like telling everybody about it right now, I’m comfortable myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die long as I take care of myself. It just means tak-ing better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life. Really if I look at it, you know, because I still would have been out there doing what I was doing probably, I don’t know. I’m a much better person now, stronger, confidence, just you know, ready to help whoever I can...I’m okay with it. It’s just letting people in.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: Basically I am 50 years old, I am from a family of seven children, I have one brother who is deceased now and I still have six sisters. I’m the baby of the bunch as they usually say, the black sheep and all that good stuff (laughter). Basically you know growing up for us was, it was real nice because my mom and dad were both from Mississippi and so they were kinda old fashioned and they didn’t believe in SOB kids, which I’m quite sure you know what that means, I wanna be a little discreet here. They didn’t believe in children out of wedlock at all, okay? And they didn’t believe in us dating or even thinking about having a boyfriend to bring to the house and introduce to them until we were 16 years old. But of course me being the baby and a spoiled brat of the six girls, I was sneakin’ around anyway....

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: I just always wanted to be around black people. Because in Montreal where I was raised it was en Français and the Haitians, we didn’t consider them our people. When I was little, I would say – when I grow up I’m gonna move to the States and be around a lot of my people. And when I came here (1969) people treated me so bad.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: It’s like the salmon, you know you’ve got to come back to it. And how odd that I say the salmon because my ma used to work at Cook County when we were young and we used to literally live down Harrison Street, by Harrison and Racine, made my communion, went to a school that’s no longer there, all of that there. And it’s weird that I end up working here and then being involved in [THE WIHS] study.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: But I thought well, oh gee, I’m a woman now, I’m in a white dress and I’ve got this big wedding, my first wedding was huge, and I thought—oh, this is the transition over. Well little did I know I was stepping into hell. And, you take it from there.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: As a woman I have to ask the question when did I become a woman? Because I was so violated as a woman. I was so violated and I looked up one day and I'm like, I would say – I lost my childhood before I was 10. I became a parent at 13 because my mother died and she told me to take care our baby, just everybody take care our baby. And I was 13, I think he was about four. No, he had to be about three. I said okay – and I looked up, I was a mom at 13 in a sense, helping take care her baby. And as of today that baby, I still have that child and he’s in his 40’s with kids, and not only…I mean, he still stays with me. So I'm still, and I made a promise to a dying woman. I have to look out for her son, you know, this baby. And I'm like – when do I let that go. And my dad said well, you know she’s dead. You let that go. I said – she might be dead but I made a promise. This boy’s about 42 years old and he still stay with me. So I'm like – when do I let go and when do I become a woman in a sense, even though I had two kids and I had my brothers and sisters and they would tell me – why did you have kids? You had us! And I'm like – but I wanted somebody of my own. Even though it was my brother, I loved him, but I wanted my own kids. I didn't want but two, two was enough because my mother died and there was six under me and four over me. And so I became a mom at a young age and to ask when did I become an adult or when did I become my own woman and I have to say…I would say at um 48 when I let go of my husband. Because there’s always a child, a husband, so I never been on my own. So I'm standing by myself without a husband but I still have those kids. So I'm finding who I am as a woman now, searching for the last five years I guess, finding this woman that’s somewhere inside of me – I'm not even sure who she is or what she would like or what she would like to do, you know? At this late stage I'm still looking for that woman within me.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: Knowing that I could survive in the midst of the storm, knowing that everything I’ve went through was experience. Not only that, but it’s to make me better. We go through challenges in life and if we can deal with it, we come out ahead. Looking at how I was able to see my brothers, then being pimps, and watching the womens get beat and watching the pimps come up to the school and pull the girls from the school and I'm like – oh that’s not gonna be me, that’s not gonna happen to me! And seeing the drugs and everything and still being able to say that that’s not me, even though I had a lot of pressure. But I felt that my strength was within and I believed in God, and my family didn't go to church or anything, I went to church every Sunday but no one else went. I'm like – I can do this, God got my back, my faith. And it was my faith, even at an early age, looking at all the traumas and trials I’ve been through and being able to say – man, I was there but it didn't happen to me, I didn't get into this.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: Seeing when I first walked in the door it was just unbelievable because you saw people from all walks of life, the ones who was living on the streets, the ones who prostituting, the ones who was shooting up, and you're looking at – hmm, what am I doing here, I do not fit in. And the ones who work the streets. And as I got to doing and talking to the ladies I found out that I really wasn’t a whole lot different from them, even though my lifestyle was different. We’re all women and we all were affected.

list.subject: Racheal
list.extract: I never really become a woman in Chicago until I got clean off the drug. That was August 10, 2010. When I surrendered and I was powerless over drugs. I’ve been clean off drugs ever since then. That’s when I became a woman. And I started living my life as a woman. Now I’m married, I have a home, I pay bills. I go grocery shopping. I do things that normal people do.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: I always tell people my role model is my parents, but I had another role model, Mohammad Ali. That was my role model, ‘side my parents . He was my role model because he didn’t let no one, nothing stop him for doing what he had to do as a person….So I’m kinda like that. I’m not him, but I’m kinda like that. I don’t let nobody stop me from doing or saying. If I feel like saying something – here’s my feeling, nobody else feeling, it comes from me.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: When I first came here I had…my first job, I think I was 19. 19 years old….I was working on an assembly line up North. But I had a little problem there. I wouldn’t say it was my problem, but I think it was the other guy’s problem because he called me the N word....And I slapped his face and then I got fired. He wasn’t funny, he didn’t have the right to call me that in the first place. But I was called that word when I was in the South, but this was close to close. That boy’s like a six foot man, white man called me that. And I didn’t like it and I slapped his face and I got fired. But that was 40 years ago.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I am the head of the family. Everybody looks up to me for decisions, I was there for both of my parents’ death, you know like I was the leader, took care of both of my parents, I do have older siblings but it seemed like all the weight always fell on me. Everybody looks up to me, I don't know why but they do.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: Jack of all trades. The last 15 years I’ve worked in the school system in Prince Georges County in Maryland. I worked with special ed students and regular ed students. I did daycare, I’ve done cleaning; I’ve done just about anything that paid and paid the bills.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well, I got my love of sewing before I went there, because my mama always sewed, she sewed all of her clothes and I just take after her, I love a sewing machine. That’s where I learned to love to sew. When I got into the mills I found out I could use them machines to make about anything.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Because I'm ready to kick ass, somebody jumps in my face. I'm ready to fight. But I keep myself quiet and to myself. I don’t have as many friends as I used to have, I don’t associate with nobody, and the only ones I ever see is my family which I should get out and associate more but I don’t.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: Or not even that but because well I guess maybe I’ve learned how to hide it so long and put the game face on that everybody, that nobody sees the vulnerability (crying) and I get tired. Having to put your game face on all the time…it’s tiring. It’s exhausting really. But you know how people ask – how’re you doing? And we all know it’s a rhetorical question in the first place. And you get, especially older people they say – oh, I can't complain. If I did, ain't nobody listening anyway or nobody cares anyway. And that’s pretty much how it is. So that’s why I put my game face on because I don’t have energy to expend on…that I said hi and smiled and they didn't say hi back (laughter). I don’t have energy for that. I just have just enough energy to get through whatever. I’d say, people would describe me as confident, so I’ll agree with that because I'm confident in the sense that despite my deficits, if could dig my way out from under a couple of them like the fog…from I don't know if it’s menopausal fog or if it’s from the depression or the medication hell, I don't know. But if I could dig my way out of this damn fog, I could probably do some stuff! So, I would say I'm confident, I would agree with that.I would say that I don't know, I would say I love myself only because I know technically I really don’t have self-esteem issues, but then again there are days where I just don’t care whether I live or die, and it’s not because I hate myself or because I feel that I don’t deserve to live (crying) but just because I'm tired. I'm just tired.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: I still manage, and again I don't know how, I can't count anymore the number of people who have come to me and said – you know, I wouldn't have ever done X, Y, or Z if it hadn’t been for you (crying). And that’s encouraging because then it makes me like I still have a purpose for being here. But I just like wish that…I wish I had a more concrete idea of what that purpose was and what I'm actually doing to fulfill that purpose. I guess right now that makes me foggy (laughter). That would be how I describe myself right now – foggy. That’s it

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I was the only white child in an all-African-American school in Lillington called Shawtown. For the first four years of my school year, of me going to school with all-blacks. I didn't see no color! Played, you know what I’m sayin’, spent the night, girlfriends over, I'm over their house; I didn't see any color. So when I got with one in a relationship, I still didn't see color. I don’t see color today. I felt like a black gentleman or a man treated me better than a white man did

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: Well now I'm a really a homebody, I don’t do much, I don't know many people here, I came from up north, I came down here in 2009. Off and on with my daughter, I go home, I come back, I go home and come back. And they move around so much within these few years. So, I haven't really settled in no place for a long time. Not that I want many friends because to me it’s just trouble. I don’t go anywhere, I don’t club…I babysit whenever they need me and I just stay close to the house. But I know we going to get to this, but my main concern now is I want my space. I want my space. I want to be free and freedom to me means having my own place, my own space again. I need that. I feel like I'm suffocating you know?

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: I got a sharp tongue, had it all my life, I'm born with it. I was the darkest one. So I didn't want my aunties to call me – little black girl with the little short hair. Because everybody had a couple of inches or more.That bothered me. James Brown came out with this record in the ‘60s or‘70s…Say It Loud, I’m Black and I’m Proud.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: And coming from a dysfunctional family, nobody knew how to hold each other up. They knew how to cook for you, buy you clothes, I guess pay the rent, you know? There wasn’t no hugging and kissing and all that stuff, that was abnormal in our house; that wasn’t a normal thing to do. The normal thing to do was to feed you.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: And somebody knew somebody who knew somebody who knew somebody who knew my husband, because I got married in ’90, and that’s when I found out I was HIV positive. But he married me anyway. I did the programs, I was clean and everything; in ’91 I went right back, I lost my daughter to the system. Got my daughter back in ’92 a year later, got her back but in the process of getting her back and going out to Amityville, Long Island to visit her in the foster care and the programs and stuff, I picked right back up, using.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: Well, you know how they say you reach rock bottom? So my daughter told me, she’s like — mom, I love you to death but I’m not going to be here to see you kill yourself. So either you get yourself together or you’re never going to see me or your grandkids again. So, that rang a bell, ding, ding, ding, it rang a bell. I was like you know what? I think I’m ready to do this. She goes – but you can’t do it for me mommy and you can’t do it for your grandkids; you have to do it for you, you have to get better for you before you can do for us.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: I couldn’t speak to my mom because my mom was the type of per-son that if you would tell her something she wouldn’t believe you, but I told my brother about the bullying. My brother, the only thing he told me — oh well if you don’t man-up, I’m going to have to go to school. And you don’t want me to go to school; so I had to do what I had to do. She came, she tried to take my lunch money, so I beat her down.

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: My mom was really strict, I couldn’t put on makeup to go to school, I had to wear my little pleated skirts with shorts underneath because I didn’t know how to sit down because I was always used to wearing pants, but I had to wear my skirt to go to school and you know my blouse and my black and white shoes.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: My mother had 15 children, I wasn’t the oldest and I wasn’t the youngest, I was some place in the middle but I don’t know exactly where I was at in the middle.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: At first I didn’t tell nobody, but when I was at the hospital I had a cousin coming to see me in the hospital and she kept telling me—oh, you know our cousin (because I had a cousin in the ‘80s who had died when the virus first came out, she had died); she came to see me in the hospital, she didn’t know what was wrong with me or nothing. She said—you know our cousin was right down the hall right here, down in that room. Anyway, she went and told everybody that I was sick with the virus.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I told her [MY MOM] that I wanted to go to Thomas Jefferson, because both of my sisters went to Jefferson and both my sisters got a good education at Thomas Jefferson High School. And, so she finally transferred me to Thomas Jefferson but by the time she transferred me to Thomas Jefferson, I was done with school. My mentality was—I’m done with school, I’m not doing this anymore, I’m just going just to be going. Sometimes I didn’t even go. My school called to say — and was like ‘Cheramie’s not in school’ (that’s what they called me back then, Cheramie). She said— well, Cheramie’s not coming back to school, she’s going to get her GED. I said — I am? I’m standing there going, ‘Really? When were you going to tell me this?’ Because her thought process was—you’re going to get your GED, you’re going to get a job, and you’re going to help contribute.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: Because of my rebellious attitude and things like that, my mother and I have always been in conflict. And the older I got, the worse it  got. When I was younger my mother said she couldn’t understand why her and I didn’t stay close because she didn’t go back to work, she stayed home with me the longest. She didn’t go back to work until I was actually in school. When I was about four years old I went to pre-K and that’s when she went back to work; with every-body else she went back to work before then. I don’t know, I guess I just was the type of person I liked to do what I wanted to do and didn’t really care about the consequences of the things that I did because some things I did, I knew I was going to get punished for it. ‘Okay, and...? I mean, You’re not going to kill me for it, so I’ll be alright.’

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I was born at Union Hospital in Brooklyn, I’ve lived in Brooklyn pretty much my whole life. I made some different stops in between. I was raised in a house with my two sisters, my mom and my dad until I was about eight years old. That’s when my parents divorced. A year later my mother had my brother by someone else. I was raised a Jehovah’s Witness, so things were kind of strict in my house but I was the rebel (laughter). Yeah, I was always the rebel.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I’ve had issues with my weight my whole life, and that didn’t help my relationship with my mother either, because she focused on my weight more than anybody. She never made me feel good about me as I was. She destroyed, she destroyed my self-esteem, I can honest-ly say that. Because when you’re eight years old and all your mother does is talk about how fat you are and how you can’t eat this and eat that da-da-da-da-dah that’s rough for an eight-year-old you know?

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: My mom passed away when I was going on 20. My daughter was six months old, when my mom passed away. She died at 49 years old, and then we had my dad. And then my dad died, I was so sad I forget all the time. This was my daughter who passed away also. She was 29.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I just want my family. They’re all I have. I’m blessed to have Carmen as a friend but ... you need your family, especially with your siblings when your mom passed away at a young age.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: They have these house parties, you know the Puerto Rican house parties every week with the record player that you put on the…and starting Friday my mom and my stepfather would start drinking beer and whiskey and whatever and then they would go next door to Anna’s house, and they started to party and party and party. And this is where I touch alcoholism. As an 11-year-old my mom and my stepfather were dancing and I'm tasting the beer. And then they would come back – beer’s empty? Don’t touch my beer. And this is how some children actually you can connect to alcohol because their parents are not watching them.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: My mother only had two children, my brother and I, and my mother worked very hard. She fell in love with a younger man, and this younger man had eyes for me. There were times where he would try to rub his body on me and I would tell my mom, when I was doing dishes; she didn’t believe me. I grew up with a lot of seeing him beat my mother, hit my mother to a pulp where the eyes would get so swollen and she couldn’t see the next day, she went blind for 24 hours. And so I saw a lot of…it was happy when mom was around but in the evening time, especially on weekends, there was the fighting and the drinking and me hiding under the bed. It was something that once in a while I endure, I pick it up and I think about it and I let it go.

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: I didn’t keep up with the other places he went. I really didn’t keep up with that. He came home off and on when they’d get leave and stuff like that. I remember driving down with one of high school friends to drop him off at a Marine base. And, um… he got out. I was living in the apartment with his mother and brother. I had my own space, my own room and everything you know. And my daughter and I were there. But my mother-in-law was alcoholic and she always wanted me to go buy alcohol for her. If she started getting a little crazy I wouldn’t go get it. We had a falling out at one point. She asked me to go get some alcohol for her and I refused. She slapped me and I slapped her back, she fell on the coffee table, I got my baby and left and went home and I never went back.

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: My mother has always been an active person, she’s always had a sense of community and responsibility when that’s something she kind of instilled in us as children. And then we later on took up the torch so to speak, because your community is only going to be as good as you help to make it, period point blank. That’s that. That’s what I learned.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: My brother was in the Army. My mother had 19 kids; she had 17 miscarriages; I’m the 13th child and the first one to be born. And my brother was the 15th child and the second to be born. I guess that’s why my mother did drink because of all the miscarriages, los-ing a lot of children. I had spinal meningitis; my brother has pneu-monia; a priest gave us both our last rites. By the grace of God we’re still here.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I didn’t really have too much of a childhood until I came up here when I was 10. When I was down South I was like a grownup person because I had to clean, it was very abusive, from place to place. My mother was here; she left me down South so I was like back and forth with my father’s people and then my mother’s people. But my father’s people was the best ones but my mother’s family we didn’t get to see that much, especially after my father had passed. He passed when I was very young. He the one that showed me love, we were very close.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: I grew up in Harlem, Lincoln Projects with my mother and my three sisters until they went down South. I was molested from age three until 14. By my mother’s husband. I got pregnant at 13 and my mother made me have an abortion. Then after that, I... by the age of 15 I was selling my body until about, hmm, 29. Started using drugs, heavy drugs at 17, crack cocaine. I’ve been clean since 2009 now, October 2009, seven years and some change.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: Oh, well I got along with my sisters. Me and my mother not too well because of the fact she took her husband’s side over mine and to this day they still live with each other, they’re still a couple, item or whatever, so that’s my mother. I found out she went through the same thing so she has a lot of issues too. I just found that out recently by talking to her.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: My mother raised five daughters, no boys, and my mother’s like when they grow up, get them out of my homeowners use, I’m going to travel this, I’m going to do this, I’m not watching no babies, I’m  not that... yeah, right. Even before my youngest sisters got out of the house she had started a daycare. She used to watch abused kids, she used to help out parents that didn’t have control of their kids. She did that on her own and then she started doing it, got a certificate. My cousins, all of them, the best Aunt is Aunt [S], my mother’s... she’s great. And she looks good. She’s 80 years old, September she’ll be 80, she’s going to Africa, that’s her.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: Yes I have. Even with my mom...my mother she’s just – this is my house and I pay the bills and everything is her way. Even though she accepted the fact that I was positive, when I stopped working, mat-ter of fact that’s one of the excuses I used to leave Long Island and come back to the city. I notice when I used the bathroom, even  though I would clean up behind myself she would go spray the toilet.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: I was born August 20, 1955 in Brooklyn, I was born and raised in Brooklyn. I was born the same day as my sister, she’s three years older than me. I have two other siblings, all girls. I'm the next to the baby. I grew up in the projects in Brooklyn, Cooper projects in Greepoint, in a strict household. My mom was a Jehovah’s Witness but my dad wasn’t (laughter). So we had-- It was…I didn't really know my dad. He was in jail when I was like nine months old and I think he came back when I was about five. I don't remember him when I was young, I don't know why I just don’t.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: Okay, when my daughter found out, it was one day because I was using, I started using really heavy when, after I became HIV. One day on the elevator and we were arguing you know? I said you know what? I hope I die, I’m HIV positive! I hope I die! And my daughter just sunk and fell on the floor, crying. Just seeing the way she reacted (crying) but after that she was in college so she learned a lot about HIV. So now it’s not an issue anymore, you know? She showed me DVDs about HIV and what it started from, the progress. And my younger son, he’s still, he’s in denial about it; he won’t talk about it. I won’t bother him with that now. Once I asked him and he said – mom please, I don’t want to talk about that. My oldest son, he’s okay with it. He did a lot of research on HIV, so they’re okay with it.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: I'm close to all my grandchildren. Not that I want to see them all at one time! But I am close to them because they're all at different levels and they like to take grandma’s stuff and move it around the house. Then they like to stand on the sofa or the loveseat and take down the pictures and take them somewhere else in my house! I don’t like that.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: when you go to my sister’s house, my brothers would go there and she knew that they had it and she would throw their glasses away, their fork away, their plate away. ... You think I want to go to her house and my kids see her throw something in the trash?

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: And my grandson that I raised is going to turn 18 on the 21st? Do you know every night he gives me my Atripla and don't know what it’s for? Just knows I take a pill before bed and he gives it to me. Here grandma, this is your pill.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: Basically I am 50 years old, I am from a family of seven children, I have one brother who is deceased now and I still have six sisters. I’m the baby of the bunch as they usually say, the black sheep and all that good stuff (laughter). Basically you know growing up for us was, it was real nice because my mom and dad were both from Mississippi and so they were kinda old fashioned and they didn’t believe in SOB kids, which I’m quite sure you know what that means, I wanna be a little discreet here. They didn’t believe in children out of wedlock at all, okay? And they didn’t believe in us dating or even thinking about having a boyfriend to bring to the house and introduce to them until we were 16 years old. But of course me being the baby and a spoiled brat of the six girls, I was sneakin’ around anyway....

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: [MY MOTHER] was like—well Sister (that’s my nickname, Sister) no use in keeping it a secret; it’s something you gotta live with now. You should just tell the rest of them, they’ll be understanding. And me knowing the type of family and sisters that I had, I knew that they would handle a problem, if anything they would be catering to me. I told them and that’s exactly what it was. They were catering to me, still ‘til today they—Sister, what’s your cell count? Because now they are more aware about it, especially with one of my sisters being a doctor. I’ve never been hospitalized before, I’ve never been sick, very seldom have a cold, my T-cell count always have been in the 800s, undetectable, even the herpes breakouts that I usually have on you know my bottom part, I don’t even have them that much more.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: And I'm like – if I go to school they going to take me back to my mom’s house and I’d then just leave and come back here. And I did that for about two weeks, and I got tired of being escorted out of the school in handcuffs, it was, you know…so I left their house because in order to stay in their house I needed to go to school. So by this time I'm in the streets and getting high and really didn't know why, you know? Didn't know why things happened to me, didn't know why I was doing stuff. And it’s just been recently that I'm starting to put it all together.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: No! No, I wouldn't say it was my fault. No, not my fault but it was my life. It was my body. It was the adults in my life not taking care of me. The adults in my life not teaching me how to take care of myself. Um, so I in turn did not have those skills to teach to my children. So much of it is, and was, it takes a village to raise a child. But then some insidious little person inserted child molesters into the mix, and the village all of a sudden wasn’t safe anymore. I was a product of the unsafe village. I am a product of the unsafe village. A lot of the things I do today are because of what I went through.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract:
[And what are some of the joyful things?]
Joyful things, um, I think when my daughter got, I think she was about eight. I had drugs then and she would be like – ma, can I go outside? And I’d be like – you don’t really want to go outside. Because she’d be standing there twisting my hair while she was begging to go outside, so the longer I prolonged it, the more twisting she did. She wanted to go somewhere one day and I'm like – my legs hurt. And she went – take a pill, let’s go! She accepted my illness that day. And she’s never looked back since then and she’s 28 now. But the fact that there was no judgment, you know? Today we try to be a non-judgmental family. When you're at home, no judgment. You get enough of that out in the world, you shouldn’t have to be judged when you're at home. So we kind of practice that now. 
 And that was as big a day to me as the day she told her friends – my mom has HIV. And y’all need to not be having sex! Those were two glorious days to me.

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: I’m from Canada. My dad came to visit me for two weeks. And he told me, he said – there’s something about this guy is not right. I had a big rock on my finger, it was all good, you know! And he was a professor at Northwestern, and I went – yes! My ship has finally come in. But he lied to his family, he lied to me. And then people were calling me saying they were lawyers, we could sue his estate. I never did because it was too much of a stigma. The Evanston newspapers wanted to interview me, I didn’t want no one to know. But now it’s not a death sentence, and I don’t care who knows.

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: My stepdad was a miner, my mother was a housewife, back then they didn’t work. When I was six years old I had to go live with my sister because I took epileptic seizures. And when people would raise their voice, I would get behind the stove…I was always nervous and shy. And people would come to the house, and my mother was very blunt, and they would go (gasping), and they would do that as a smartness but I didn’t know they’d go oh, that’s the little chocolate one you adopted?

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: And so I fought, I went to the Core Center, they had a program set up for parenting skills. And so they said…I still got the certificate, you go there and get your certificate, then you take that to DCFS and then they know you working towards your goal to get your son back. And so when I used to go over to her house, my son’s foster mother house, I used to sit down, she would get the bleach and wipe whatever I touched. And so it went on like that, and then I think it was more she was being nasty towards me because she know she had to fight, because I had gotten start healing then, feeling better…I want my child back! And so we started going back and forth to court and what happened was I started getting visitation, everything. They had to let me participate in everything. And this went on for years. My son is 26 now, and he’s still back and forth with her.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Well, when you're that age you learn to pretend like everything is okay. Like you had a perfect family. But what really went wrong, I did horribly in school. You know, because I was like, you know, constantly on my mind, afraid to go home. I ran away a lot, and then at the age of 13 I was in a school for bad girls, I was in the Audy Home. ...That’s a place in Chicago for children who are supposed to be, you know it’s just like the Department of Corrections but this is only for children. Bad, bad children. I wasn’t bad at all, I was just you know acting out. I didn't consider running away being bad, I just wanted, I just didn't want to be at home. And so they took me away, they put me in the Audy Home.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: I’m Latina. I was born in Indiana, we stayed mostly with my grandparents, we all stayed there, my grandfather and his brothers were the type that they built their own places and my mom met my dad there in Indiana and he was of Puerto Rican descent, so Mexican and Puerto Rican. I remember... well, it was nice having all family around—aunts, uncles, other cousins, coming to see grandma and grandpa. And then whenever grandpa wanted help out in the fields because he would do all that stuff, I remember as a young kid, he’d take whatever hands and feet were available to stand and pull, you know? We’d do all kinds of stuff out in the fields helping grandpa. And I thought it was exciting because they used to bring home live meals, take it to the garage and do what had to be done. I thought that was normal.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: ...my mom used to always work, I remember she had three jobs at one time. We were kind of like okay, there’s food in the fridge, there’s the little washer and the little dryer, she’d do the best she could and of course my father was nowhere to be found when you needed him, kind of grew up without him there. And I didn’t know I was poor. My brother had to tell us later–you know, we were poor.

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: Some of the joys and best things was…the first one was being married. I enjoyed being married. The second thing was having my children and the third thing was being able to be clean in 2007 and watching my mother and father, before he passed away that year, celebrate 60 years clean and all of my brothers and sisters and all of us still alive to see that.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: As a woman I have to ask the question when did I become a woman? Because I was so violated as a woman. I was so violated and I looked up one day and I'm like, I would say – I lost my childhood before I was 10. I became a parent at 13 because my mother died and she told me to take care our baby, just everybody take care our baby. And I was 13, I think he was about four. No, he had to be about three. I said okay – and I looked up, I was a mom at 13 in a sense, helping take care her baby. And as of today that baby, I still have that child and he’s in his 40’s with kids, and not only…I mean, he still stays with me. So I'm still, and I made a promise to a dying woman. I have to look out for her son, you know, this baby. And I'm like – when do I let that go. And my dad said well, you know she’s dead. You let that go. I said – she might be dead but I made a promise. This boy’s about 42 years old and he still stay with me. So I'm like – when do I let go and when do I become a woman in a sense, even though I had two kids and I had my brothers and sisters and they would tell me – why did you have kids? You had us! And I'm like – but I wanted somebody of my own. Even though it was my brother, I loved him, but I wanted my own kids. I didn't want but two, two was enough because my mother died and there was six under me and four over me. And so I became a mom at a young age and to ask when did I become an adult or when did I become my own woman and I have to say…I would say at um 48 when I let go of my husband. Because there’s always a child, a husband, so I never been on my own. So I'm standing by myself without a husband but I still have those kids. So I'm finding who I am as a woman now, searching for the last five years I guess, finding this woman that’s somewhere inside of me – I'm not even sure who she is or what she would like or what she would like to do, you know? At this late stage I'm still looking for that woman within me.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: My family also, we all grew up in Chicago. I have eight brothers and one sister. I have two biological kids - a boy and a girl; four adoptive kids, two boys and two girls; three grandchildren, two girls and a boy; and on the way one great-grandbaby. Basically we all get along. We just family, we have our ups and downs but we still come together as a unit.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: My mother died when I was 10, or 13, I'm sorry. But before 10 I was molested, so losing that innocence, not really seeing who I am or not even knowing who I am, knowing that this is not the norm. I would tell my mom oh, stay away from him. How can I stay away from him when you gone all the time? Let me leave with you, then I’d be away from him. But losing the innocence and really like nobody to save me in a sense, even though my mother was there but she really wasn’t there, she didn't protect me. And I hear him say oh, mama did this, mama was this…mama didn't protect me. You remember mama making biscuits…oh yes, I remember all that stuff. But I don’t remember her protecting me. If they went to jail for doing something bad, her older brothers, she was down there getting them out, I can remember that. But as protecting me…she didn't do that. I didn't hate her, I just like – you remember that? I don't remember that! I can't remember any good days as far as her protecting me and saying it’s gonna be okay and I'm going to stop this. She’d just say – stay away from him! So I'm like, when I have my kids this ain't gonna happen. But how do I know if they don’t tell you. But I told her and she didn't protect me so…that’s where it’s at.

list.subject: Racheal
list.extract: ...there were six children from five different fathers. But we were mostly raised by my mom. I'm the oldest out of six – three girls, three boys. I was born in Mississippi, I don’t remember much about that. From there we moved to Memphis, TN and I briefly remember living in Memphis, that’s where my older brother and sister, second sister was born. We lived there until I was seven then we moved to Chicago when I was seven.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: Because they would come and stay with me a couple of weeks and we buddied around, me and the twins. Me and the twins were always close. They called us the three retards, growing up in my family.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: I’ve met a lot of women who I have a lot in common with. It don’t matter where we’re from. It don’t matter if you were born on the South side, the North side, Cicero, whatever. We all have a lot in common. From the beginning to probably how a lot of us were raised or we ended up recently. And how we deal with what’s going on with us. It saddens me when I think of women that their families aren’t supportive. Because I’ve been blessed since I’ve been sick, my family has been great to me.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: And my brother. I miss him dearly. He was my hero. Back in 1997, I was doing the drugs, I was smoking the crack, I was stealing the money, I was rotten, I’m not bragging, I was rotten, I’m not lying either, that’s part of recovery. I was rotten and he rode me and he rode me and he said get out of my F’N house you Mother F’R monster, I want my sister back. When I straightened out, a year and a half later, he said – welcome back. He’s always been…he was there. I gave that poor kid a run for his money and he rode me and he straightened me…you want to do drugs, then you don’t want to eat. You want to steal money? Get out of here. You don’t need to eat. Goodbye.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: It was to the point where they were going to put me on the street. It was either straighten up and fly right, and I hit my rock bottom, finally. I got busted buying drugs, and I’m sitting in the cell waiting to go to court and I’m thinking – this is the second time. And I’m thinking – what if I get a little time or something, because you ain't gonna get off maybe like you did the first time, and I thought, what if something happens to my mother because she’s already up in age and had a number of strokes and stuff. So I said to myself – well, you know what? You need to do something differently, so that doesn’t end up happening. And the only answer was I needed to get the strength to stop doing that stuff. So what I did was I just slowly backed off of it. I lied through my teeth and said I wasn’t doing it, but it was the weirdest thing, I looked at it like dieting. If I could get $200, you could bet I had 20 rocks in my pocket and would smoke them in a day. And I just backed up. I slowed down. Just like you cut your food portions, I cut and I cut and I backed up and I backed up. And I prayed to God for strength, or to the higher power, because I didn’t necessarily believe in a God but in the possibility of a higher power, and I prayed for the inner strength, and somehow I had it. I went to a couple of meetings. I couldn’t go to a lot of meetings, I could barely walk. I was as big as a house, 338 pounds, I could hardly walk from the bus stop…

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: I just felt so comfortable with him. I always felt I belonged to be with him. No matter what happened, and believe me, a lot of things went bad, I always felt that man loved me. And I love him, he’s the love of my life. I can’t be with him, I haven’t seen him in two years, I can’t have nothing to do with him anymore. I had to draw lines up. Because he won’t stop with the drinking and things happened, I live with my family, I have to be there for my family and I can’t have the two intermingling. And of course everybody hates him because they know he gave me HIV eventually, which is wild, because I maybe had sex with my husband maybe twice in one year. Not because I didn’t love him, because I love and find him attractive, but I had my own issues, physical, or whatever, menopause, so I just couldn’t bear the pain. But twice in one year…and I got HIV. I got very sick and my friend said – I’m going to take you down to Cook County Hospital, my friend Donny, and he said you better have that tested because he knew my husband had HIV already like eight years, and that’s pretty much when I separated from my husband. I told him to stay with his mother. I was homeless, sleeping in a garage. I ended up homeless and broke. I wanted my husband to try to get into rehab or something, and his family…forget that. They’re all losers.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract:
I come from a family of eight, well there was 10 of us in all but eight of us lived….I'm the sixth. I had to think because you know my mother married when she very young, very young and she had a baby very young. It was all good time but I also growed up in that Jim Crow law if you know what Jim Crow…I'm from the South and that’s where the Jim Crow laws started but there were eight of us, I gots part of that Jim Crow law because you had different things for black and whites, whatever. I'm part of that. 
 My father wanted the best, the best for us, go to school every day, but they had a third and fourth grade education, my parent did. But I always told my parent, we came out okay, they couldn't teach us how to read or anything like that, help us with our homework, but we always said we made it.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: I always tell people my role model is my parents, but I had another role model, Mohammad Ali. That was my role model, ‘side my parents . He was my role model because he didn’t let no one, nothing stop him for doing what he had to do as a person….So I’m kinda like that. I’m not him, but I’m kinda like that. I don’t let nobody stop me from doing or saying. If I feel like saying something – here’s my feeling, nobody else feeling, it comes from me.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I was born in Brooklyn, NY and I moved to North Carolina maybe 23 years ago.  I'm 46 years old and I work for the Post Office.  My mom died and the person that I was infected from HIV, he died, and I just needed a different scene, I just needed to get away with my kids, and North Carolina was it, felt like a safer place to go.  I had nobody else to stay in New York for as far as my mom and my fiancée.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh, my prayers, I made this prayer when I got clean. I said –God, if I ever use any illegal drugs I want you to take me out right now (laughter) because that was the worst two-year stint of my life. It was only two years but it was the worse. I think living with HIV was better than being on drugs...Um, drugs control your mind. They control your mind, your character, it control your moods, it controls everything. Your bank account, it controls you…your whole ability to thinking. And I had no control over my life for those two years. It was like – I was losing me. And really and truly HIV was an easier task than being on drugs. If I didn't have my mom I probably would still be out there, really in a bad situation in the streets. I never got to the point of doing things for drugs because I had family that tried that kept me off the streets, or tried to keep me off the streets. So I was good on that level but (sigh) I still did a lot of things that I'm not proud of back then, yes.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I am the head of the family. Everybody looks up to me for decisions, I was there for both of my parents’ death, you know like I was the leader, took care of both of my parents, I do have older siblings but it seemed like all the weight always fell on me. Everybody looks up to me, I don't know why but they do.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I love my children! They are my inspiration, they are why I'm here today because I fought for life to raise them. And it’s funny because I remember saying one day – God, if you just let me see my kids graduate from high school and see them grown where they can take care of theyself, I’ll be happy. Woo, that time came and I was like okay God, let me (laughter) rephrase this please. Let me live longer. But then I was just praying for life just to raise them, just to see them grow. Now I'm praying for life to see my grandkids. You know, my grandkids are growing up, they're the apple of my life, back then all I could think of is – God, if you just get me through, just let me see them grown I’ll be so grateful. Now I’m like uh-oh, that time happened, what am I going to do now?

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: I'm originally from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. I’ve lived there all my life. I now live in North Carolina; I moved to North Carolina in 1997. I am the mother of two children and three grandchildren. I'm the oldest girl. There are a total of five, six, seven of us, now six, one has passed on. But I'm the oldest girl, I'm the big sister, I'm the one that everybody goes to when they have problems (laughter).

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Going through, coming up in school, I went to a school that was mixed, so I didn't see color. I knew people were different but it wasn’t like – oh you're white, I can't be with you. Oh you're Asian I can't be with you. I just wanted to be cool with everybody until as a kid, you see that there are differences because you get older people who are showing you that prejudice and trying to teach you that prejudice. I didn't have a difference between races until I was like in the second grade, having a best friend who was white and got invited to her house and when I went, her dad was like – what are you doing here (when he opened the door). I'm like – I'm here for the taco party! “We don’t allow niggers”...I'm a kid and I'm just like –what the what! I knew that word from watching Roots andthings like that, but never experienced it. She’s behind him and she’s sad and her little sister, they called me ‘Alicia’ and she’s like –let Aliciain, let Aliciain. My friend’s name was [M] and her sister’s name was[R] . He would not let me in and I ran home crying and my Mom went around there, I don't know what my crazy Mom did or said (laughter). She laughs because I call her that because my Mom really took up for us. All parents normally do, butif I got into a situation, my Mom always sent me away and she handled it, and I don't know what my crazy Mother did but all Iknow is after I saw [M] again I wasn’t allowed to speak to her. Her parents, if they saw me coming they would pull her away. She would just be looking like –oh, I can't talk to you. We’d be in school and we couldn't talk. It was just bad

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: They do. I think everybody who knows me, knows (laughter). I'm very open with my status, though it was not always that way. When I first got diagnosed I kept it from my family for a long time. The first ones who knew in my family was my Dad. The day that I got diagnosed I told my Dad, I just didn't want to be by myself with it. It wasn’t, I didn't have embarrassment, it wasn’t that type of feeling, it was more fear if anything. I'm so open about my health and everything that I felt like it was something the family should know so they can be there to support you. I didn't tell my children for, I don't know, at least three years. So you know, that part was scary. My mom, my sisters, just that experience was, it was surprising because the responses were different than what I expected. So now everyone knows because I'm extremely outspoken. And I don't know, it’s okay, almost like it’s not there.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Well, unfortunately fighting this girl brought up a lot of anger for me at home, and I didn't mean to but I beat the poor girl so bad and I had my sisters to protect. They were Kindergarteners and during that time at school I was told – you fight her then we're going to beat you up. If you don’t fight her we're going to beat you up. If you win, we're going to beat you up; if you lose we're going to beat you up. And you know back then it was like everybody hear about a fight, everybody’s there. So it was like crowds of people, some of the girls who were the bullies, they had pipes in their bags, homemade knives, so I'm scared like – oh my gosh I'm looking at my little sisters and seeing my Mom’s face. If I don’t get them home safely, forget all these people, Mom is going to kill me.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: I shared it with my mother when I was 25, I wrote her a letter and told her about her brother and she in return told me that it wasn’t true, that he brother said that it wasn’t true, and I’ve never had a relationship with my mother, I really still don’t have a relationship with my mother due to the fact that I was molested at five and she wasn’t there to protect me...Yes. Everyone one knows my mother and I are distant...A couple of them have passed on but one of them who just always took advantage of me was my Uncle G and I saw him one year in a store and I beat him up. I beat him bad. And the people in the store let me beat him. So I got revenge on him.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: Really I was more like the mother/nurturing one. Because as the oldest girl I used to have to be the second mother to them. No, I didn't really like it. I used to have to be the babysitter while my mom worked. My father was in and out of prison so my mom depended on me a lot, and my aunt depended on me a lot, I used to have to go over and watch her children and that’s when a lot of my abuse was, due to her husband as well.

list.subject: Claristine
list.extract: I knew I had to leave, had to get out. So I went to the streets. And that tore our relationship up because she didn't do anything about it. She didn't kick him out; she believed him, she didn't believe me. So I just went to the streets and that’s when I started. I always had a good job, I always did the right thing until then.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well my family don't know, just not but two of them that do know. And they relate to me, they take care of me, my twin sister she knows and takes..watches out for me all the time. She still hasn’t told her husband, and he takes care of me just like I'm a child. My daughter, she’s all the time if there's something wrong she’ll take care of me. But they're the only ones that know right now.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: My self-esteem before was good. I had a good job, a nicehome, but then after that it all went downhill....What most worries me about this here is I’ve seen so many people being hurt over this, just over the three letters. They don’t care that you got feelings. And just for my family to know, I really don't know how they would react to it. They might react the way you think they would, but I’ve head them talk you know? What I’ve heard, I remember somebody and this boy had it and by that time I had it and they said – that boy’s got HIV. And said we're going to stay away from him, don’t get anything from rubbing up on him, this that and the other…I got thinking to myself, that’s the way they're going to treat me. And I seen this boy, and I said – don’t you think that this time he needs a friend? He don’t need everybody running away from him you know? I sit down and when I realized what I did have, I sit down and kind of looked it up to see what was going on.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Because I'm ready to kick ass, somebody jumps in my face. I'm ready to fight. But I keep myself quiet and to myself. I don’t have as many friends as I used to have, I don’t associate with nobody, and the only ones I ever see is my family which I should get out and associate more but I don’t.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: the only part of my family that knows that I have HIV are two of my three children. My mother and father are both deceased and I have four siblings, or had four. One died in the past few years, but it’s been since I’ve been HIV positive. I’ve chosen not to tell any of my siblings because I grew up in a very religious family and they're all quite religious and I do believe that they would be more judgmental than they would be supportive.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I think I had a pretty good childhood. There was no man in the house. My grandmother raised us; she was like the mother. She did the cooking and the cleaning and the watching us. My mama was the man; she went out and did all the work. And so it was me, my two sisters, my mom, and my grandmother. Oh Lord, mama did everything. Mama could tear down a car good as a man could; she waitressed; she worked like at …what’s that word I’m looking for, like Caterpillar, what are they

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My daughter got a hold of my diary…my therapy since I was old enough to write has been to write my thoughts down on a piece of paper in a notebook, my mama taught me that, she did the day she died. So I write my thoughts down. I was living with my daughter when my husband died, I had nowhere to go; I lost my home, I lost the vehicles, I lost everything in my home down to my clothes. Me and my dog is all I have. So I’ve been living with her for almost two years; April the 1st of this year I moved in my own place. She, being nosy or whatever, she read my diary. And in my diary it said I’d been diagnosed since 2000 with hepatitis C, nothing about HIV. She treats me like I am a disease. She’ll hug me, she’ll kiss me right here. There’s the grandkids come and stay with me, and I cook. If I have something left over and they're still hungry on my plate and I offer to put it on their plate, she has a fit! To where – now you know that’s unacceptable! They can't eat after you and they can’t drink after you! I said – why not? “You know why!” “No I don’t, please tell me why!” I want her to come out and tell me that she knows. But I'm thinking that she knows it’s hepatitis C, when everybody, all my friends and my doctors and case managers tell me that they believe that she knows I have HIV.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I know my middle son would, because he’s made comments like you’ve heard. So-and-so, who’s that guy that plays on Two And A Half Men?  Charlie Sheen?  He’s HIV positive.  My son had a cookout one night – dude, did you know that Charlie Sheen’s HIV?  My God, what are we going to do?  We need to take people like that, put them all on a boat and send them away.  I'm going oh hell no, I’m not fixing to go through this right here, it’s just not worth it to me, for me not being able to see my grandbabies.  It’s just me and my care providers and what few women I’ve met today and at the clinic that know that I am.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: Actually, my mom died when I was 20 or 21 and I had had my two girls, which were a year and six months apart, so they was babies when my mom passed. I have two other brothers and a sister and my mom had insurance and stuff; I was well off. She left me everything in the house, the house and stuff like that, my brothers and stuff we didn't argue about stuff like that. I had like $97,000 and so I did some positive stuff with that. If my mom was living today, I’d probably be at home with my mom. And I probably wouldn't be, wouldn’t have gotten into that state of destruction, you understand? I think when she died that was it. That was like releasing me, just to go crazy as hell and so I did. I did, I did. I went crazy, just crazy. Just crazy

list.subject: Velvet
list.extract:
And when I went back there that time, the door was cracked, and I looked in and they had this spoon and this baking soda and this white stuff and they was fire and water and all this stuff, you know? 
 I opened the door and I said – what are y’all doing with that stuff?  My aunt wasn’t there, nobody was here but them.  They said – go on back in the living room, we’ll be in there.  I went to sit in there about an hour, I went back there and said – y’all come on out of there or I'm coming in!  
 Oh Lord.  What did I go in there for?  Doomsday.  I went in there and said – what y’all doing, smoking this stuff, they were using a can, hosing the ashes on top.  I said – let me try, what y’all doing!           From then on, it was like, nothing else.  I was in this black world.  I stayed in that, smoking that crack, for 27 years.  I didn't know what in the world to do, I didn't know how to come off of it.

list.subject: Velvet
list.extract: It was 2010, this was before my father passed. That’s when I found out that I had HIV. I was staying at my sister’s and I was sick, I was getting sicker, I was losing weight, I was not eating, I had no appetite, my great-niece at the time came in the room where I was and she was about five years old, she said – auntie? I said, yeah baby? She said are you sick? I said yes, I gotta go to the bathroom. I got up and she said – you want me to help you? She grabbed me, she got me by my hand and was walking with me and said – auntie, why are you sick? I said honey, I said baby I don't know. So she said – do you want something to eat? I said no. She said – I'm going to go downstairs and I’m going to put a can of chicken noodle soup in the microwave for you. I said – make sure you don’t burn yourself, it was warm enough to her taste. She brought it upstairs and I said – sit it over there, I’ll eat a little bit at a time. Then I went into the bathroom and I took all of my clothes off, I looked in the mirror and just looked at myself, I just looked at myself and this thought came to me, I don't know why that thought came to me but the words that came outta my mouth was…you're HIV positive.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: I ran the street like a rabbit! I sure did. I run the streets, I went to every show, every club, I used to do that, that was my thing, I didn't miss no shows. And my grandmother and these was a lot of her grandkids, she’d make sure we didn't miss any either. She would take us out to the Capitol Center concerts, take us out there, when it was over come back and pick us up. Everybody who didn't have a ticket, she’d pay and get them a ticket. Girl, I missed nothing, oh no, I missed no concerts; yes, I ran the streets. I sure did.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: ...before her [her daughter], I had an abortion, actually I had two abortions. And my mother forced me into the first abortion and, we had a nanny, and she found that I was pregnant and her mother had went away to one of those islands, St. Thomas or Bahamas or Puerto Rico somewhere and came back and came in the room and got me and was punching my stomach…you pregnant! You pregnant! She was going to beat that baby out of me, girl! Ain't no babies coming in here, I ain't finished having babies yet myself! She wasn’t lying…she set up an abortion for me and I had an abortion. And then a couple years later I had another abortion. After that abortion I fell in love with my daughter’s father who passed when she was five months old; and then I wanted to have a baby, and I couldn't. I felt God was punishing me. Every month I’d tell him, I'm pregnant, I missed my cycle…next thing I know, here comes my cycle. Why, lo and behold and this is just how it happened. We laying in the bed one day, side by side, and he turns over to me, he say – guess what? You pregnant. I thought I could beat the brakes off of him!
