I done took him through this all this time, telling everyone I'm pregnant…and I'm not pregnant. So why would he want to do this to me? Play these mind games. I'm already suffering, I'm pregnant…I'm not pregnant. But lo and behold, I was pregnant.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: I have long distance friends. I have friends up in Maryland, crazy (laughter), outgoing, you know, they're cool. And my family my family are my friends, me and my family we close, we’re going to stay that way because I would never disclose my status to them because I don't want anything to change. I’m not taking that chance. Anybody have anything to say about it, so be it.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: And coming from a dysfunctional family, nobody knew how to hold each other up. They knew how to cook for you, buy you clothes, I guess pay the rent, you know? There wasn’t no hugging and kissing and all that stuff, that was abnormal in our house; that wasn’t a normal thing to do. The normal thing to do was to feed you.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I have years from childhood stuff that I hold in, hold in, hold in. And I didn’t know, I didn’t know, until I started releasing, releasing when I went to see...first when I was diagnosed, a little later on, the feeling didn’t hit then, but when the feeling hit that took me into be depressed...I used to always cry all the time, I didn’t know why I was crying. And I remember when I was first diagnosed I told them that I needed a support system, so they had sent me to 57 Willoughby Street and I sat there almost a whole year and I never talk or nothing.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I’ve had issues with my weight my whole life, and that didn’t help my relationship with my mother either, because she focused on my weight more than anybody. She never made me feel good about me as I was. She destroyed, she destroyed my self-esteem, I can honest-ly say that. Because when you’re eight years old and all your mother does is talk about how fat you are and how you can’t eat this and eat that da-da-da-da-dah that’s rough for an eight-year-old you know?

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: You know back in the day, Spanish people took a lot from men. A lot of abuse and they got used to it. I grew up seeing my neighbors every weekend with shades on. And I already knew why. That’s why I became very strong. I would not let no man rule me. None of that, because I saw it as I was growing up. He was a good dad but he wasn’t a good husband at all.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: My mother only had two children, my brother and I, and my mother worked very hard. She fell in love with a younger man, and this younger man had eyes for me. There were times where he would try to rub his body on me and I would tell my mom, when I was doing dishes; she didn’t believe me. I grew up with a lot of seeing him beat my mother, hit my mother to a pulp where the eyes would get so swollen and she couldn’t see the next day, she went blind for 24 hours. And so I saw a lot of…it was happy when mom was around but in the evening time, especially on weekends, there was the fighting and the drinking and me hiding under the bed. It was something that once in a while I endure, I pick it up and I think about it and I let it go.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I didn’t really have too much of a childhood until I came up here when I was 10. When I was down South I was like a grownup person because I had to clean, it was very abusive, from place to place. My mother was here; she left me down South so I was like back and forth with my father’s people and then my mother’s people. But my father’s people was the best ones but my mother’s family we didn’t get to see that much, especially after my father had passed. He passed when I was very young. He the one that showed me love, we were very close.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: I grew up in Harlem, Lincoln Projects with my mother and my three sisters until they went down South. I was molested from age three until 14. By my mother’s husband. I got pregnant at 13 and my mother made me have an abortion. Then after that, I... by the age of 15 I was selling my body until about, hmm, 29. Started using drugs, heavy drugs at 17, crack cocaine. I’ve been clean since 2009 now, October 2009, seven years and some change.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: Oh, well I got along with my sisters. Me and my mother not too well because of the fact she took her husband’s side over mine and to this day they still live with each other, they’re still a couple, item or whatever, so that’s my mother. I found out she went through the same thing so she has a lot of issues too. I just found that out recently by talking to her.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: I was raped by a trick, who had HIV. I was raped in 2000, but I didn’t find out until 2003 when I was incarcerated, in jail, on Rikers Island.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: I thought that was gonna be the thing that gave me my freedom. Even my mother said – you don’t have to get married, you could just have the baby or whatever. But I just wanted to get out of her strict household and I thought that was gonna be the thing to do. And it wasn’t. It was the worst thing that I ever did. ‘Cause I wound up getting married and having the same problems, not having any freedom, my husband didn't want me to go out, he was abusive, he wound up being abusive, and he’s the reason why I don’t have any sight today. I started going to school because I wanted to get my GED and I found out about a GED program that give you college credits; but he didn't want me to go. But I started going anyway, and one day he saw me outside without the kids, because I had a neighbor that used to watch my kids, and he saw me but I didn't see him. But my girlfriend said – there go your husband…and I said well, he seen me so I guess he’s working or whatever. I just went on. Got a ride to the subway and went on to school. And when he came home that night he just came in the door and just started beating me, and wind up giving me a black eye. I used to wear glasses, contact lenses; when I was growing up I always wore glasses but I had contact lenses then. And he just continued to pound on me and he detached a retina in one eye and then caused glaucoma in the other eye. So eventually I lost sight in both.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: My first child was when I ran away at 15 and got married in Kentucky because I left home. And I thought—Oh, I’m going to live a good life! That was bull because I got beat up and all that by my husband and we ended up divorcing.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: And I'm like – if I go to school they going to take me back to my mom’s house and I’d then just leave and come back here. And I did that for about two weeks, and I got tired of being escorted out of the school in handcuffs, it was, you know…so I left their house because in order to stay in their house I needed to go to school. So by this time I'm in the streets and getting high and really didn't know why, you know? Didn't know why things happened to me, didn't know why I was doing stuff. And it’s just been recently that I'm starting to put it all together.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: No! No, I wouldn't say it was my fault. No, not my fault but it was my life. It was my body. It was the adults in my life not taking care of me. The adults in my life not teaching me how to take care of myself. Um, so I in turn did not have those skills to teach to my children. So much of it is, and was, it takes a village to raise a child. But then some insidious little person inserted child molesters into the mix, and the village all of a sudden wasn’t safe anymore. I was a product of the unsafe village. I am a product of the unsafe village. A lot of the things I do today are because of what I went through.

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Well, when you're that age you learn to pretend like everything is okay. Like you had a perfect family. But what really went wrong, I did horribly in school. You know, because I was like, you know, constantly on my mind, afraid to go home. I ran away a lot, and then at the age of 13 I was in a school for bad girls, I was in the Audy Home. ...That’s a place in Chicago for children who are supposed to be, you know it’s just like the Department of Corrections but this is only for children. Bad, bad children. I wasn’t bad at all, I was just you know acting out. I didn't consider running away being bad, I just wanted, I just didn't want to be at home. And so they took me away, they put me in the Audy Home.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Yes, I started seeking counseling [about the molestation]. And then like I said, I started going to groups. I found out that other people had worse issues than I did, you know! It didn't make me feel good but it helped to know that I wasn’t out there alone. And then some of these things that suppressed me or made me very depressed, it can happen to anybody, it can happen to the best of people.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: But I thought well, oh gee, I’m a woman now, I’m in a white dress and I’ve got this big wedding, my first wedding was huge, and I thought—oh, this is the transition over. Well little did I know I was stepping into hell. And, you take it from there.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: As a woman I have to ask the question when did I become a woman? Because I was so violated as a woman. I was so violated and I looked up one day and I'm like, I would say – I lost my childhood before I was 10. I became a parent at 13 because my mother died and she told me to take care our baby, just everybody take care our baby. And I was 13, I think he was about four. No, he had to be about three. I said okay – and I looked up, I was a mom at 13 in a sense, helping take care her baby. And as of today that baby, I still have that child and he’s in his 40’s with kids, and not only…I mean, he still stays with me. So I'm still, and I made a promise to a dying woman. I have to look out for her son, you know, this baby. And I'm like – when do I let that go. And my dad said well, you know she’s dead. You let that go. I said – she might be dead but I made a promise. This boy’s about 42 years old and he still stay with me. So I'm like – when do I let go and when do I become a woman in a sense, even though I had two kids and I had my brothers and sisters and they would tell me – why did you have kids? You had us! And I'm like – but I wanted somebody of my own. Even though it was my brother, I loved him, but I wanted my own kids. I didn't want but two, two was enough because my mother died and there was six under me and four over me. And so I became a mom at a young age and to ask when did I become an adult or when did I become my own woman and I have to say…I would say at um 48 when I let go of my husband. Because there’s always a child, a husband, so I never been on my own. So I'm standing by myself without a husband but I still have those kids. So I'm finding who I am as a woman now, searching for the last five years I guess, finding this woman that’s somewhere inside of me – I'm not even sure who she is or what she would like or what she would like to do, you know? At this late stage I'm still looking for that woman within me.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: My mother died when I was 10, or 13, I'm sorry. But before 10 I was molested, so losing that innocence, not really seeing who I am or not even knowing who I am, knowing that this is not the norm. I would tell my mom oh, stay away from him. How can I stay away from him when you gone all the time? Let me leave with you, then I’d be away from him. But losing the innocence and really like nobody to save me in a sense, even though my mother was there but she really wasn’t there, she didn't protect me. And I hear him say oh, mama did this, mama was this…mama didn't protect me. You remember mama making biscuits…oh yes, I remember all that stuff. But I don’t remember her protecting me. If they went to jail for doing something bad, her older brothers, she was down there getting them out, I can remember that. But as protecting me…she didn't do that. I didn't hate her, I just like – you remember that? I don't remember that! I can't remember any good days as far as her protecting me and saying it’s gonna be okay and I'm going to stop this. She’d just say – stay away from him! So I'm like, when I have my kids this ain't gonna happen. But how do I know if they don’t tell you. But I told her and she didn't protect me so…that’s where it’s at.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Well, unfortunately fighting this girl brought up a lot of anger for me at home, and I didn't mean to but I beat the poor girl so bad and I had my sisters to protect. They were Kindergarteners and during that time at school I was told – you fight her then we're going to beat you up. If you don’t fight her we're going to beat you up. If you win, we're going to beat you up; if you lose we're going to beat you up. And you know back then it was like everybody hear about a fight, everybody’s there. So it was like crowds of people, some of the girls who were the bullies, they had pipes in their bags, homemade knives, so I'm scared like – oh my gosh I'm looking at my little sisters and seeing my Mom’s face. If I don’t get them home safely, forget all these people, Mom is going to kill me.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: In DC? Well at five years old I was abused, I was sexually abused from the age of five to about 11 or 12. That part wasn’t nice but there was some good times growing up in DC, back in the day, nothing like it is now. Playing different games – hopscotch, kickball at different schools, just doing kid stuff. It was really fun.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: I shared it with my mother when I was 25, I wrote her a letter and told her about her brother and she in return told me that it wasn’t true, that he brother said that it wasn’t true, and I’ve never had a relationship with my mother, I really still don’t have a relationship with my mother due to the fact that I was molested at five and she wasn’t there to protect me...Yes. Everyone one knows my mother and I are distant...A couple of them have passed on but one of them who just always took advantage of me was my Uncle G and I saw him one year in a store and I beat him up. I beat him bad. And the people in the store let me beat him. So I got revenge on him.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: Really I was more like the mother/nurturing one. Because as the oldest girl I used to have to be the second mother to them. No, I didn't really like it. I used to have to be the babysitter while my mom worked. My father was in and out of prison so my mom depended on me a lot, and my aunt depended on me a lot, I used to have to go over and watch her children and that’s when a lot of my abuse was, due to her husband as well.

list.subject: Claristine
list.extract: after the molestation, well during the molestation, me and my mom was always close, but after I told her that he was molesting me, she just didn't want to believe it. She kept him in the house. So I knew sooner or later he was going to try to have sex with me; I knew I had to get outta there, because I did not want to be pregnant by my father...

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: So, when I was 11 I went to visit my sister in Maysville, which is near Jacksonville, NC and her husband was from there and her husband’s cousin molested me. So he tried to penetrate me but I was like – stop, get off me! Whatever. And he was like shhh, put his hand over my mouth to shush me. Then he did get off me because I was making up too big of a fuss. And then I was like – I'm going to tell. He said – if you do, they're just going to think you did it. They're going to blame you, and I believed that. I remember when I first saw the Lion King, and I was 26 years old when I first saw the Lion King, I remember when Scar told Simba that it was his fault that his dad died trying to save him (crying) and Simba believed him and he ran away and he left. And I remember thinking to myself, that took me back to that moment and that was the first time that I really realized that there had been bad things that had been done to me…when I was 11 years old.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: Actually, my mom died when I was 20 or 21 and I had had my two girls, which were a year and six months apart, so they was babies when my mom passed. I have two other brothers and a sister and my mom had insurance and stuff; I was well off. She left me everything in the house, the house and stuff like that, my brothers and stuff we didn't argue about stuff like that. I had like $97,000 and so I did some positive stuff with that. If my mom was living today, I’d probably be at home with my mom. And I probably wouldn't be, wouldn’t have gotten into that state of destruction, you understand? I think when she died that was it. That was like releasing me, just to go crazy as hell and so I did. I did, I did. I went crazy, just crazy. Just crazy

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: My life has been really, really just ripped apart but I know God don’t make no mistakes on what he doing but…he put so much on you that sometime you just can't take it (crying). And so you figure if you just get high, you get drunk or whatever it’ll go away – but it don’t. (crying) You just put it down deep inside your body and then when you have to talk about it and help somebody else, it’s painful.

list.subject: Velvet
list.extract:
I was gang raped, I lived through that.  This last was a gang of eight, they had on all black or blue, whatever, and the last one he saved my life.  He was just acting like he was doing something to me and he said – just act like I'm doing something to you but I want to let you fall and I'm going to run.  Because I was supposed to been initiated to the gang, but I don't want to do it if this what it takes.  He dropped me and he ran, and he told me they were going to shoot at him.  He ran and I'm telling you, he ran so fast I mean, just like I was looking at Carl Lewis!  He ran so fast, he was outta sight before it seemed like I could blink my eye.  
 I met this young man two years later on a Sunday, him and his fiancée were walking together and the only way I recognized him because I couldn't see him was his voice. And he asked me where was the bus stop, he wanted his fiancée to sit down because she was due any day with their baby.  And I said – well the bus stop is right there…And I walked [away] and we both looked back at each other and tears came down his eyes and he said, he walked to me, I walked to him and he said – I'm sorry.

what the state does to you.text: What the state does to you

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: And somebody knew somebody who knew somebody who knew somebody who knew my husband, because I got married in ’90, and that’s when I found out I was HIV positive. But he married me anyway. I did the programs, I was clean and everything; in ’91 I went right back, I lost my daughter to the system. Got my daughter back in ’92 a year later, got her back but in the process of getting her back and going out to Amityville, Long Island to visit her in the foster care and the programs and stuff, I picked right back up, using.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: Well I started smoking marijuana with my kids’ father and we used to do cocaine with him. It got the point that ACS had gotten involved and told me that if I wouldn’t shape up, they would take my kids. So that’s when I woke up. That’s when I said — that’s it for me

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: matter of fact, well I’d been incarcerated like go to Rikers Island, I’d go for like three days, 7 at the most. And I was 37 years old and the judge gave me a one to three. She said — I’m not going to give you city I don’t understand you wait so long to get a record, I’m going to teach you a tough lesson. So she sent me upstate. I was in Beacon Correctional Facility. This was in ’96. I had long dreads in my hair. Long dreadlocks. Anyway, the judge said she going to teach me a tough lesson and she did, okay? Just so happened I said — let me take a HIV test. I took the test and it came back positive. I was like devastated. But matter of fact prior to that, well my sister she also suffers from gland problems, my glands kept swolling up, swolling up, and my ear was hurting, made everything hurt. So I went and had a biopsy done and that’s when I found out I was positive

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: …you know being on public assistance you didn't get a lot of money for rent, and so I always had to—I used to have to sell my food stamps to get enough money to pay my rent. It was always a problem with having enough money. I lived in East Flatbush, a lot of apartments there were high, you know, the rent was high. Anywhere I went I never had enough money to pay the rent, so I wind up moving in with my mom and then I put in applications for city housing. That’s when I moved to Brownsville with my daughters when I got accepted for housing.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: Dr. Mardge Cohen, who of course you know is the initiator of all of this Core Center being in existence and all of that. And we used to sit in that Radiation Center before they actually built the Core Center, we’d sit in that Radiation Center, it would hot as a firecracker in there because there wasn’t no air conditioner so we’d have a fan on and we sitting skin to skin sweating and we just be talking but it was just one big family you know?

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I ended up in the penitentiary with my youngest daughter with a friend, my second diagnosis in five years, still not knowing what it is that I have. Got out of the penitentiary and there was a DCFS worker waiting for me at the gate. And he told me that if I thought I wanted my kids back I probably wouldn't get them back because I had HIV. But he brought me to the wrong place, he took me to the Fantus Clinic at Stroger Hospital. And that was his mistake, taking me to the Fantus Clinic because not only did they educate me about HIV, they educated me about my rights concerning HIV and you know, that nobody could take my child simply because…there were people trying to.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: Yes, and I’ve been standing ever since. Never had a desire…I say I’ve been delivered from the disease of addiction. I'm not recovered or recovering, I’ve been delivered. It’s been taken away, you know what I mean? I’ve learned how to live this super life a new way. You know what I mean? I got busy about my business, got busy about making my kids a priority and in the interim when I got Madison out of the system, the judge was like – don’t you have two other children in the system? When a parent gets themselves together, it’s not for one, so they re-investigated return home for the other two. So I had to go through a lot of stuff.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: I mean the pain, the emotional pain was far worse than the physical pain. and I just asked God to just – stop. Just stop (crying) the pain. And that’s when I asked him to help me to come in, and God whatever it is that I have to do I will do it, whatever they tell me to do, whatever…I'm going to do it. And when I feel like using I'm going to pray to you, you say that you are God…I need you to show me that you are God. ... And I delivered Madison and I'm telling you when I asked God for help, things just started happening. I had already had two children in the system, Jada and Jaylen, and they were already terminated from parental rights. And it was the lady from DCFS came and she was like – well, I'm going to let you take your baby but you have to get into treatment.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: And so I fought, I went to the Core Center, they had a program set up for parenting skills. And so they said…I still got the certificate, you go there and get your certificate, then you take that to DCFS and then they know you working towards your goal to get your son back. And so when I used to go over to her house, my son’s foster mother house, I used to sit down, she would get the bleach and wipe whatever I touched. And so it went on like that, and then I think it was more she was being nasty towards me because she know she had to fight, because I had gotten start healing then, feeling better…I want my child back! And so we started going back and forth to court and what happened was I started getting visitation, everything. They had to let me participate in everything. And this went on for years. My son is 26 now, and he’s still back and forth with her.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Well, when you're that age you learn to pretend like everything is okay. Like you had a perfect family. But what really went wrong, I did horribly in school. You know, because I was like, you know, constantly on my mind, afraid to go home. I ran away a lot, and then at the age of 13 I was in a school for bad girls, I was in the Audy Home. ...That’s a place in Chicago for children who are supposed to be, you know it’s just like the Department of Corrections but this is only for children. Bad, bad children. I wasn’t bad at all, I was just you know acting out. I didn't consider running away being bad, I just wanted, I just didn't want to be at home. And so they took me away, they put me in the Audy Home.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: So one day at the beginning of the year of his fourth grade they were talking about hygiene and germs, what you can see, what you can’t, clean your hands, wash your hands, cover your mouth when you sneeze; so the question was—do you understand what viruses and germs are? And he was a smart one to say— yes I do, I have the virus that can cause AIDS. So with saying that, the teacher caught on but the kids weren’t really paying attention. And we didn’t have a phone and I had a note left in my mailbox to come down to the principal’s office. To the understanding from our nurse at clinic since he’s in a public school, it had to be reported to CPS downtown that there’s an HIV child enrolled in your school. They had to do that, they had to report it. And they had to keep things, how did they tell me…in a safe, secure place.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh yes, I have problems getting my medication now because…the amount, okay if you make a certain amount of money then you don’t qualify for this program, but the medicine is so expensive that my insurance won't pay for it, so excuse my language but you're damned if you do, and you're damned if you don’t, that type of situation. Work and you make money and then your insurance don’t pay for the medicine. Don’t work and you can get all of these things but I'm living in poverty. Like now I can't get any, the social workers are trying to get me assistance, we’re trying to get my medicine. Well, I can't get it because they can't help me, because the amount. I make more money than what they require...Um, in a way because people can't go to the doctors, they can't afford to go to the health, to get medical treatment. A lot of people that don’t have money, let's put it like this. If I had $100 to put food on the table for my kids, but I needed that $100 to go to the doctor, what do you think that person will do? They’ll take that $100 and feed their children. Because that $100 probably could feed their kids for the month, if you're living in poverty. I'm not going to take the $100 and go to the doctor when I know that I have to survive. So yes, it’s a lot of people that are lacking care because of money.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract:
Oh gosh, a wonderful, wonderful diagnosis. It was really devastating, because I thought I had lymphoma cancer. I'm a researcher and I'm very, very in tune with my body so I know when something’s not right. I caught a cold, turned into strep, and then the lymph nodes in my neck swelled up. They swelled so bad that I couldn't really turn my neck and I could see lumps sitting outside my neck and I'm just like – oh my gosh, what is that? So researching all the symptoms I had led to lymphoma. Okay, I'm going to call my doctor, I think it’s this but I'm not a doctor so I don't know. And also it wasn’t like okay, this is hanging on for like two days. We’re talking weeks this thing is going on. So I'm scared, call the doctor, I said – I want a biopsy. 
	Well, when I went in, went to the health department, and they had already had test results from my last HIV test. Normally I never go back for an HIV test, any STD tests were always negative. And I knew how to protect myself. Well, I had been tested since I’d been with my now ex-husband and I didn't go back for test results, because they're always negative. Well, the health department failed to contact me. I slipped through the cracks, they actually told me that because they were trying to say well, we tried to call you, we tried to send you a letter…well no, you didn't. I still live at the same place, phone number’s been the same for years, no you didn't. Just long story short they told me I slipped through the cracks but when I got the news, the nurse couldn't even verbally tell me. Because they all knew me, I'm a really nice person and when I go into places I become a joy (laughter). 
	When I went there I'm sitting in a room, half the size of the room I’m in now, and she pushes a folder towards me and opens it and in red it said HIV Positive. And that’s how I learned. She just couldn’t…It wasn’t that she wasn’t being professional, she was hurt, she was hurt for me. Because her whole demeanor just I just didn't understand. When I got it I screamed, I cried, man I just wanted to leave. I tried to get my keys and my purse, I went to get it and it was gone because she had it hiding behind her and she was barricading the door and she just didn't want me to leave. I understand that. I was telling this story to someone before and they're like – oh my gosh why would she do that? For my protection. I was upset, I was distraught, and I wanted to get in my car and drive. Well, what if I did that? I could have had an accident or anything could have happened. But hearing that news, gosh…

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: And somebody knew somebody who knew somebody who knew somebody who knew my husband, because I got married in ’90, and that’s when I found out I was HIV positive. But he married me anyway. I did the programs, I was clean and everything; in ’91 I went right back, I lost my daughter to the system. Got my daughter back in ’92 a year later, got her back but in the process of getting her back and going out to Amityville, Long Island to visit her in the foster care and the programs and stuff, I picked right back up, using.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: Well I mean, I was, you know, I was angry, I was angry but then again I did this to myself because I was out there. I was running the streets, I didn’t care about my kids, my mom used to take care of my kids. All I was worrying about was when I was going to get my next hit. So I was angry but I did it to myself; I couldn’t be angry with anybody else because I did this to myself.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: The first person I told was my youngest daughter. Even though she grown, the first person I told my youngest daughter because that was the day that I had took the test. I never forget, I was in Brookdale Hospital and I took her in the bathroom and I told her, I said — you know that they found out that I have the virus? — just like that. And I had started crying. She said —  Mommy, we’re going to get through this, we’re going to get through this.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: When I told my kids that I had the virus it was really hard for me but I’d rather for me to be the one to tell them, because there’s a lot of mean people out there and I’d prefer maybe for my kids to hear it from me than to hear it from anybody else. Because then they going to start thinking, wow, why did I have to hear it from somebody else?

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: As soon as I turned 18. I graduated high school and then I left. To the streets really, there was nowhere, I was in the park and I met my kid’s father and had two kids by him.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: My mom passed away when I was going on 20. My daughter was six months old, when my mom passed away. She died at 49 years old, and then we had my dad. And then my dad died, I was so sad I forget all the time. This was my daughter who passed away also. She was 29.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: The difference I’m trying to make is to realize that I am HIV. There’s a lot of things that you can do to lift up your spirit. I always take my medication like clockwork. Maybe not the same time because some-times I don’t eat during...but I take it every single day. And I want to be able to live with it. I really think I’ve been so in denial, that’s why I let my body go so bad. I just didn’t...but now I have that spunk, like somebody lit a fire under my butt because I really, really want to live. I’m not embarrassed anymore. I’ll go talk and speak, but I got to  learn also how to tell my 15-year-old and I don’t even think I want to. Because [D] feels I’m all he has. His mother’s his other mother; I’m his mom. I’m his light, his God, I’m everything to [D]. Little does he know that that’s what he means to me. And sometimes I feel like I should let him know, give him the awareness because every time I look at him...maybe in groups or something where there’s other children that he can meet, because one-on-one from me I wouldn’t want to just tell him, no. I want him to see that other kids are coping with their parents with it. But I still really, I don’t know about [D], I feel like I’ll hurt him.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: I didn’t keep up with the other places he went. I really didn’t keep up with that. He came home off and on when they’d get leave and stuff like that. I remember driving down with one of high school friends to drop him off at a Marine base. And, um… he got out. I was living in the apartment with his mother and brother. I had my own space, my own room and everything you know. And my daughter and I were there. But my mother-in-law was alcoholic and she always wanted me to go buy alcohol for her. If she started getting a little crazy I wouldn’t go get it. We had a falling out at one point. She asked me to go get some alcohol for her and I refused. She slapped me and I slapped her back, she fell on the coffee table, I got my baby and left and went home and I never went back.

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: I got back there, got my baby, got in the cab, went back to the shelter and I never got high again after that. I really started to pay attention to reorienting myself to live in an active world. Because people are going to drink, they’re going to drug; the thing is, you have to choose not to. I had to reprogram myself to learn how to do that. Eventually it worked and I gave birth to [J] January 22, 1992.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: Because if you don’t take your medicine you won't be okay, period point blank. And it took a long time for them to even recognize women in anything when it comes to this disease, and then to focus on what works for us. Because what works for us is not working for men. You understand? Because I had two children before they even told me – ask me about being HIV positive or taking an HIV test. But they test them other two children I had and they never told me one way or the other with them, but I know that they're not, because time goes on. But I’ll be here for you baby.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: At 16, I experimented with marijuana. At 18, I started shooting up drugs. Nope, 17 I started sniffing, 18 I started shooting up drugs up until I was 21. That’s when I got pregnant and I stopped. Right now I don’t do anything, but I do smoke weed.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I went to school until I was in 9th grade, I got pregnant. And that was the end of that.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: that was ’71. I had a few boyfriends before that but you know sneak ones, not really like I could say – this is my boyfriend. This guy, because I was getting older and so I stated going with him and then I wind up getting pregnant. When I started that gym class they wouldn't allow me to participate and so I wind up not being able to complete, and so I never did get my high school diploma at that time. I just left. I wound up getting married at 18 and had my daughter, my oldest daughter she’s 42 now.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: I thought that was gonna be the thing that gave me my freedom. Even my mother said – you don’t have to get married, you could just have the baby or whatever. But I just wanted to get out of her strict household and I thought that was gonna be the thing to do. And it wasn’t. It was the worst thing that I ever did. ‘Cause I wound up getting married and having the same problems, not having any freedom, my husband didn't want me to go out, he was abusive, he wound up being abusive, and he’s the reason why I don’t have any sight today. I started going to school because I wanted to get my GED and I found out about a GED program that give you college credits; but he didn't want me to go. But I started going anyway, and one day he saw me outside without the kids, because I had a neighbor that used to watch my kids, and he saw me but I didn't see him. But my girlfriend said – there go your husband…and I said well, he seen me so I guess he’s working or whatever. I just went on. Got a ride to the subway and went on to school. And when he came home that night he just came in the door and just started beating me, and wind up giving me a black eye. I used to wear glasses, contact lenses; when I was growing up I always wore glasses but I had contact lenses then. And he just continued to pound on me and he detached a retina in one eye and then caused glaucoma in the other eye. So eventually I lost sight in both.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: I don’t’ curse. Oh boy I used to be crazy with cursing and fighting, oh my goodness, I used to fight, blind and fighting and threatening people, just being that typical drunk. And not…because I left the house with pressed clothes and looking a certain way, because I was always raised that way but I was just always using something, so it would always wind up being like that Roxy. That person that was always in trouble, like that kid that was always in trouble. I don’t even know what happened but I just thank God that it did. Maybe that last prayer that I prayed, that I just needed help. But I always felt like I was just maintaining, I had a right to drink, I had a right to…as long as I was taking care of my kids I considered myself doing the right thing because I kept my kids and never had to go into a shelter. So I always felt like I was just one step above all the other people that used.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I ended up in the penitentiary with my youngest daughter with a friend, my second diagnosis in five years, still not knowing what it is that I have. Got out of the penitentiary and there was a DCFS worker waiting for me at the gate. And he told me that if I thought I wanted my kids back I probably wouldn't get them back because I had HIV. But he brought me to the wrong place, he took me to the Fantus Clinic at Stroger Hospital. And that was his mistake, taking me to the Fantus Clinic because not only did they educate me about HIV, they educated me about my rights concerning HIV and you know, that nobody could take my child simply because…there were people trying to.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: This was ’85.  And the doctor came in and started asking me about my life and my habits.  And he came back and he goes – your baby has HIV so I'm pretty sure you have it, too. He walked away and I let him.  It was just like everything else in my life, nobody explained it to me, nobody told me anything.  So after a week or so in the hospital they let my daughter come home, she was better.  Her immune system had kicked in, kicked mine out, she is not positive.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract:
[And what are some of the joyful things?]
Joyful things, um, I think when my daughter got, I think she was about eight. I had drugs then and she would be like – ma, can I go outside? And I’d be like – you don’t really want to go outside. Because she’d be standing there twisting my hair while she was begging to go outside, so the longer I prolonged it, the more twisting she did. She wanted to go somewhere one day and I'm like – my legs hurt. And she went – take a pill, let’s go! She accepted my illness that day. And she’s never looked back since then and she’s 28 now. But the fact that there was no judgment, you know? Today we try to be a non-judgmental family. When you're at home, no judgment. You get enough of that out in the world, you shouldn’t have to be judged when you're at home. So we kind of practice that now. 
 And that was as big a day to me as the day she told her friends – my mom has HIV. And y’all need to not be having sex! Those were two glorious days to me.

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: Yes, and I’ve been standing ever since. Never had a desire…I say I’ve been delivered from the disease of addiction. I'm not recovered or recovering, I’ve been delivered. It’s been taken away, you know what I mean? I’ve learned how to live this super life a new way. You know what I mean? I got busy about my business, got busy about making my kids a priority and in the interim when I got Madison out of the system, the judge was like – don’t you have two other children in the system? When a parent gets themselves together, it’s not for one, so they re-investigated return home for the other two. So I had to go through a lot of stuff.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: So I was up all night calling places, and it just so happened that Julie Washington, she works at the Core Center, she was my substitute for my counselor, but she wasn’t even working at the Core, she was working at County and somewhere she saw my name. She was just coming to see if it was me. I call her my guardian angel. She walked down that hall and I said – Julie, I need your help, I gotta go into treatment, they said I can keep my baby! (crying) You know and she was like…she called some place and they found a place that day for me to take Madison. They came and picked us up and took us to Haymarket.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: So God was allowing me to get my mind right. (crying) (inaudible) I was about to take, and I was ready then. Treatment opened up, because I was scared, I didn't want no more and I wanted to give my son a chance! And I stayed in Maryville for two years, I went to Haymarket, I stayed there for 18 months and I was scared to leave because I just didn't want to have no more. I moved into a program where they monitor us, you know? They subsidized my rent, then I had just got active into, after that I begin engaged in my medical care, wanted now to take care of my HIV. I began to educate myself about what it is that I had.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: I mean the pain, the emotional pain was far worse than the physical pain. and I just asked God to just – stop. Just stop (crying) the pain. And that’s when I asked him to help me to come in, and God whatever it is that I have to do I will do it, whatever they tell me to do, whatever…I'm going to do it. And when I feel like using I'm going to pray to you, you say that you are God…I need you to show me that you are God. ... And I delivered Madison and I'm telling you when I asked God for help, things just started happening. I had already had two children in the system, Jada and Jaylen, and they were already terminated from parental rights. And it was the lady from DCFS came and she was like – well, I'm going to let you take your baby but you have to get into treatment.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Mae
list.extract: You know, we’ve come such a long way and never in a million years did I think that I would be here 20 years later. I thought to myself – dear God, just give me…my daughter was 16 and my son was 21 when I was diagnosed and I thought…dear God, just give me two years. That’s all I want is two years. And here he’s given me 20.

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: And so I fought, I went to the Core Center, they had a program set up for parenting skills. And so they said…I still got the certificate, you go there and get your certificate, then you take that to DCFS and then they know you working towards your goal to get your son back. And so when I used to go over to her house, my son’s foster mother house, I used to sit down, she would get the bleach and wipe whatever I touched. And so it went on like that, and then I think it was more she was being nasty towards me because she know she had to fight, because I had gotten start healing then, feeling better…I want my child back! And so we started going back and forth to court and what happened was I started getting visitation, everything. They had to let me participate in everything. And this went on for years. My son is 26 now, and he’s still back and forth with her.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: When I had him I was never given prenatal care and then on top of that I was shooting drugs, I was drinking, I'm surprised he came out a perfect baby like he did. But the thing was, when he came out he had drugs in his system….So when I got to the hospital he was gone. But before they even did all that, they released me and kept him because they had to let him detox. Before they even did all that they came in my room, the doctor, fully gowned I mean from head to toe looking like astronauts and told me I had AIDS. They didn't say nothing about HIV positive, and did I want to talk to a chaplain? And you know if you have to talk to a chaplain, that means, you know, you don’t have long to live. It could be today or tomorrow. That’s because they didn't really know that much about HIV or AIDS you know?

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: I’ve had abortions too, so you know I'm on both sides of the card there you know because some will say okay, I'm a killer and then at the same time I have given birth. But then I’ve given birth with not the intention of getting pregnant, it happened and trust me, I was looking for options to get out of them, both of them. I wouldn't trade them in now, but that’s a turning point. I don't think I could take anything back in my life that has brought me here today. So in other words some have made it, some haven't.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: So one day at the beginning of the year of his fourth grade they were talking about hygiene and germs, what you can see, what you can’t, clean your hands, wash your hands, cover your mouth when you sneeze; so the question was—do you understand what viruses and germs are? And he was a smart one to say— yes I do, I have the virus that can cause AIDS. So with saying that, the teacher caught on but the kids weren’t really paying attention. And we didn’t have a phone and I had a note left in my mailbox to come down to the principal’s office. To the understanding from our nurse at clinic since he’s in a public school, it had to be reported to CPS downtown that there’s an HIV child enrolled in your school. They had to do that, they had to report it. And they had to keep things, how did they tell me…in a safe, secure place.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: I thought it was a death sentence when I first found out about it and it ended up making me a better person. I ended up becoming stronger and being more health conscious without drug use and being more mindful and more aware of my body and the things that I need to do for me to stay healthy. Because one of the things I feared most in the WIHS study – I remember one of the questions they asked me was what is the one thing you fear most? I remember breaking out crying in the middle of a study when they asked me a question, I was watching my kids grow up. And it always stuck in my head. And now my kids are grown, and I have two grandbabies.

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: Some of the joys and best things was…the first one was being married. I enjoyed being married. The second thing was having my children and the third thing was being able to be clean in 2007 and watching my mother and father, before he passed away that year, celebrate 60 years clean and all of my brothers and sisters and all of us still alive to see that.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: As a woman I have to ask the question when did I become a woman? Because I was so violated as a woman. I was so violated and I looked up one day and I'm like, I would say – I lost my childhood before I was 10. I became a parent at 13 because my mother died and she told me to take care our baby, just everybody take care our baby. And I was 13, I think he was about four. No, he had to be about three. I said okay – and I looked up, I was a mom at 13 in a sense, helping take care her baby. And as of today that baby, I still have that child and he’s in his 40’s with kids, and not only…I mean, he still stays with me. So I'm still, and I made a promise to a dying woman. I have to look out for her son, you know, this baby. And I'm like – when do I let that go. And my dad said well, you know she’s dead. You let that go. I said – she might be dead but I made a promise. This boy’s about 42 years old and he still stay with me. So I'm like – when do I let go and when do I become a woman in a sense, even though I had two kids and I had my brothers and sisters and they would tell me – why did you have kids? You had us! And I'm like – but I wanted somebody of my own. Even though it was my brother, I loved him, but I wanted my own kids. I didn't want but two, two was enough because my mother died and there was six under me and four over me. And so I became a mom at a young age and to ask when did I become an adult or when did I become my own woman and I have to say…I would say at um 48 when I let go of my husband. Because there’s always a child, a husband, so I never been on my own. So I'm standing by myself without a husband but I still have those kids. So I'm finding who I am as a woman now, searching for the last five years I guess, finding this woman that’s somewhere inside of me – I'm not even sure who she is or what she would like or what she would like to do, you know? At this late stage I'm still looking for that woman within me.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: My mother died when I was 10, or 13, I'm sorry. But before 10 I was molested, so losing that innocence, not really seeing who I am or not even knowing who I am, knowing that this is not the norm. I would tell my mom oh, stay away from him. How can I stay away from him when you gone all the time? Let me leave with you, then I’d be away from him. But losing the innocence and really like nobody to save me in a sense, even though my mother was there but she really wasn’t there, she didn't protect me. And I hear him say oh, mama did this, mama was this…mama didn't protect me. You remember mama making biscuits…oh yes, I remember all that stuff. But I don’t remember her protecting me. If they went to jail for doing something bad, her older brothers, she was down there getting them out, I can remember that. But as protecting me…she didn't do that. I didn't hate her, I just like – you remember that? I don't remember that! I can't remember any good days as far as her protecting me and saying it’s gonna be okay and I'm going to stop this. She’d just say – stay away from him! So I'm like, when I have my kids this ain't gonna happen. But how do I know if they don’t tell you. But I told her and she didn't protect me so…that’s where it’s at.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: No. Actually when I first got my results my younger brother came with me. And back in those days it was a death sentence so it took him to get my mind right, I mean really. Back then it was just coming out and to find out that you were HIV positive meant that you would be dead in a month or two. So my brother was there with me and he was very supportive...In 1989, 1990, yeah something around there...(sigh) It was the beginning to an end, that’s what I thought. It was like okay, I have two kids, my mom is sickly, what am I going to do? In my mind I was like oh my God I'm dying. And then I had no God at that time, I wasn’t into church, so to me I had nothing to turn to but my kids. I wanted to live for them. Everything around me wanted to be alive for them. (tears)

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Um, yes, because the percentage that they gave me of the child not being positive was so low that it was an influence yes, go get rid of this baby because it was what they were telling me it was more than 50% chance that the child would be positive. Which we know nowadays no, that’s not true, but back then I didn't know any better. I had zero to no knowledge about this and they had zero to no knowledge and all that I saw that the people that had AIDS and were HIV positive were dying. In the streets dying, that was all around me, everybody was dying. Nobody was living from it.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I love my children! They are my inspiration, they are why I'm here today because I fought for life to raise them. And it’s funny because I remember saying one day – God, if you just let me see my kids graduate from high school and see them grown where they can take care of theyself, I’ll be happy. Woo, that time came and I was like okay God, let me (laughter) rephrase this please. Let me live longer. But then I was just praying for life just to raise them, just to see them grow. Now I'm praying for life to see my grandkids. You know, my grandkids are growing up, they're the apple of my life, back then all I could think of is – God, if you just get me through, just let me see them grown I’ll be so grateful. Now I’m like uh-oh, that time happened, what am I going to do now?

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: I'm originally from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. I’ve lived there all my life. I now live in North Carolina; I moved to North Carolina in 1997. I am the mother of two children and three grandchildren. I'm the oldest girl. There are a total of five, six, seven of us, now six, one has passed on. But I'm the oldest girl, I'm the big sister, I'm the one that everybody goes to when they have problems (laughter).

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: On New Year’s Eve 2006 we were getting testing done at our church in Maryland. My pastor Tony Lee, A Community of Hope Church. We did HIV testing. And I came back positive along with one of my sons who tested with me. We had to go to Johns Hopkins to get retested and prior to that weekend, I just prayed a lot and just asked to reverse everything on me so my son wouldn't be positive, because he was getting ready to go away to college. I just didn't want him to have to live his life like that...He came back negative. And I came back positive, I remember clearly because the doctor was like – well Miss, your son came back negative but you came back positive still. I was just happy and jumping up and down, yay! He’s like – but I'm telling you, you're still positive. I said that’s okay, my son is negative, I can handle it. I’ve been through abuse, been through addiction, been through sexual abuse. I can handle this.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: It did, because I didn't really want to deal with people because I was a closet hitter. People that really knew me knew what I did but they would really never see me out because I was a closet hitter, at home hiding...Not really, because I had kids. I had to make sure my kids were taken care of, even though I had an addiction I didn't want anything to happen to my kids so I just let them do whatever they wanted in the house and give them whatever they wanted, as long as I could sit in the house and get high and go in my bathroom and hide, everything was okay.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My daughter got a hold of my diary…my therapy since I was old enough to write has been to write my thoughts down on a piece of paper in a notebook, my mama taught me that, she did the day she died. So I write my thoughts down. I was living with my daughter when my husband died, I had nowhere to go; I lost my home, I lost the vehicles, I lost everything in my home down to my clothes. Me and my dog is all I have. So I’ve been living with her for almost two years; April the 1st of this year I moved in my own place. She, being nosy or whatever, she read my diary. And in my diary it said I’d been diagnosed since 2000 with hepatitis C, nothing about HIV. She treats me like I am a disease. She’ll hug me, she’ll kiss me right here. There’s the grandkids come and stay with me, and I cook. If I have something left over and they're still hungry on my plate and I offer to put it on their plate, she has a fit! To where – now you know that’s unacceptable! They can't eat after you and they can’t drink after you! I said – why not? “You know why!” “No I don’t, please tell me why!” I want her to come out and tell me that she knows. But I'm thinking that she knows it’s hepatitis C, when everybody, all my friends and my doctors and case managers tell me that they believe that she knows I have HIV.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I know my middle son would, because he’s made comments like you’ve heard. So-and-so, who’s that guy that plays on Two And A Half Men?  Charlie Sheen?  He’s HIV positive.  My son had a cookout one night – dude, did you know that Charlie Sheen’s HIV?  My God, what are we going to do?  We need to take people like that, put them all on a boat and send them away.  I'm going oh hell no, I’m not fixing to go through this right here, it’s just not worth it to me, for me not being able to see my grandbabies.  It’s just me and my care providers and what few women I’ve met today and at the clinic that know that I am.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: Actually, my mom died when I was 20 or 21 and I had had my two girls, which were a year and six months apart, so they was babies when my mom passed. I have two other brothers and a sister and my mom had insurance and stuff; I was well off. She left me everything in the house, the house and stuff like that, my brothers and stuff we didn't argue about stuff like that. I had like $97,000 and so I did some positive stuff with that. If my mom was living today, I’d probably be at home with my mom. And I probably wouldn't be, wouldn’t have gotten into that state of destruction, you understand? I think when she died that was it. That was like releasing me, just to go crazy as hell and so I did. I did, I did. I went crazy, just crazy. Just crazy

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: And I was doing the best I could, I was working, paying my bills, but you know it just got so hard that I tried to keep them up and do the drugs too and I chose the drugs over my children! I chose drugs and stuff over my children, who does that? And why didn't I get to see my kids on a regular basis, because when they come see me it tears them up so much they didn't want to leave, so why would you keep putting them kids through that? (crying) So I just told them – don’t bring them back, don’t bring them back to see me until I get myself together.

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I quit my job…I got $150,000 and I invested, tried to do the right thing, I gave my mom and dad $10,000 apiece off the top to pay for their burial plots, I did some sensible stuff with it– but then I also did some crazy stuff because like I said, I was on the drugs. It didn't last very long. I took myself to the Bahamas, I just treated myself good you know? Because I felt like I paid a dear price; the check was because I couldn't have children. I had one of those Dalkon Shields, I couldn't have children…that still wasn’t enough, that didn't take the place of me being able to have children.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: ...before her [her daughter], I had an abortion, actually I had two abortions. And my mother forced me into the first abortion and, we had a nanny, and she found that I was pregnant and her mother had went away to one of those islands, St. Thomas or Bahamas or Puerto Rico somewhere and came back and came in the room and got me and was punching my stomach…you pregnant! You pregnant! She was going to beat that baby out of me, girl! Ain't no babies coming in here, I ain't finished having babies yet myself! She wasn’t lying…she set up an abortion for me and I had an abortion. And then a couple years later I had another abortion. After that abortion I fell in love with my daughter’s father who passed when she was five months old; and then I wanted to have a baby, and I couldn't. I felt God was punishing me. Every month I’d tell him, I'm pregnant, I missed my cycle…next thing I know, here comes my cycle. Why, lo and behold and this is just how it happened. We laying in the bed one day, side by side, and he turns over to me, he say – guess what? You pregnant. I thought I could beat the brakes off of him! I done took him through this all this time, telling everyone I'm pregnant…and I'm not pregnant. So why would he want to do this to me? Play these mind games. I'm already suffering, I'm pregnant…I'm not pregnant. But lo and behold, I was pregnant.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: And back then, they said people who had HIV had an expectancy to live five years. This is ’93. I had up until ’95…to try everything! Because I’m not going to live! So I was trying to try everything. ’96 and ’97 came around I’m like – oh God! So I got tired, I got tired. I got arrested one more time, and then after that I had a hysterectomy on May 24, 1998.

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: Well actually like I said, I stopped but I did it for me, I didn’t really do it for none of them, I did it for me. Because you have to do it for you before you can be there for anybody, for anybody else. But my oldest daughter, she was really, really...and I could really see it in her eyes, like she wanted me, she goes — okay you have the virus, okay I’ve known people with the virus, I know people with AIDS, they can live long lives and long and long and long! She’s like — I just want you, because that was her worst fear of losing me.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Mae
list.extract: You know, we’ve come such a long way and never in a million years did I think that I would be here 20 years later. I thought to myself – dear God, just give me…my daughter was 16 and my son was 21 when I was diagnosed and I thought…dear God, just give me two years. That’s all I want is two years. And here he’s given me 20.

list.subject: Mae
list.extract: He was past the HIV stage and his count was 12. The doctor basically said you know it’s just a matter of time. He could last two weeks, he could last two months, but he’s not going to last long.

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: I thought it was a death sentence when I first found out about it and it ended up making me a better person. I ended up becoming stronger and being more health conscious without drug use and being more mindful and more aware of my body and the things that I need to do for me to stay healthy. Because one of the things I feared most in the WIHS study – I remember one of the questions they asked me was what is the one thing you fear most? I remember breaking out crying in the middle of a study when they asked me a question, I was watching my kids grow up. And it always stuck in my head. And now my kids are grown, and I have two grandbabies.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I want my future to look…I want there to become a cure, a real cure. I know that the medicines are keeping us alive but I want one day to take that test and say – it’s not there anymore! That’s what I want my future to be. I don't want to have to put expiration dates on my life, like my first goal was to see my kids graduate from high school. Now this goal I'm making is to see my grandkids grown. I don't want to have to have praying for expiration dates. I want to be praying that God give man knowledge of a cure, a real cure, and not just a Band-aid that you putting over by taking the medication.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: No. Actually when I first got my results my younger brother came with me. And back in those days it was a death sentence so it took him to get my mind right, I mean really. Back then it was just coming out and to find out that you were HIV positive meant that you would be dead in a month or two. So my brother was there with me and he was very supportive...In 1989, 1990, yeah something around there...(sigh) It was the beginning to an end, that’s what I thought. It was like okay, I have two kids, my mom is sickly, what am I going to do? In my mind I was like oh my God I'm dying. And then I had no God at that time, I wasn’t into church, so to me I had nothing to turn to but my kids. I wanted to live for them. Everything around me wanted to be alive for them. (tears)

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I'm good, I have to get it together. You know I never told my story so I guess telling this story now is making me emotional because I never had an opportunity or I never wanted to share my story because of people and ignorance. People are still ignorant to this disease. It’s like they don’t understand, the world still doesn’t understand that I could live just as long as someone, or longer than someone, who has cancer because now the treatment, I'm able to live longer than someone else you know? And people still shun you, so it’s hard to want to come forward because of that. But I'm here.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I love my children! They are my inspiration, they are why I'm here today because I fought for life to raise them. And it’s funny because I remember saying one day – God, if you just let me see my kids graduate from high school and see them grown where they can take care of theyself, I’ll be happy. Woo, that time came and I was like okay God, let me (laughter) rephrase this please. Let me live longer. But then I was just praying for life just to raise them, just to see them grow. Now I'm praying for life to see my grandkids. You know, my grandkids are growing up, they're the apple of my life, back then all I could think of is – God, if you just get me through, just let me see them grown I’ll be so grateful. Now I’m like uh-oh, that time happened, what am I going to do now?

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: And back then, they said people who had HIV had an expectancy to live five years. This is ’93. I had up until ’95…to try everything! Because I’m not going to live! So I was trying to try everything. ’96 and ’97 came around I’m like – oh God! So I got tired, I got tired. I got arrested one more time, and then after that I had a hysterectomy on May 24, 1998.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: That’s when I was incarcerated and I just so happened to take the test and it came back positive. I was incarcerated. I think they was trying to find out who has it in the penal system or not, and that’s how I found out.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: I moved out of here in Brooklyn with my boyfriend in like 2000. And he got incarcerated and I had got incarcerated. So when I came home I had nowhere to go. I was in the shelter system for about five years. I just recently got my apartment two years ago ... on Crook Avenue, a CAMBA building.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: Oh, I was devastated but also I was actually still coming down from the high, because I got locked up, I was high when I got locked up. Have to go through the bullpen and all that. I was coming down, so really it wasn’t registering, I didn’t know what the hell they was talking about (laughter) until I seen pamphlets and stuff about it.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: I was raped by a trick, who had HIV. I was raped in 2000, but I didn’t find out until 2003 when I was incarcerated, in jail, on Rikers Island.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: Well, when I first was diagnosed I didn’t have no education about it so I didn’t know by using the drugs could constantly...I was messing myself up even more. My CD4 count and making myself out there more to expose myself to more things and more complications to me. And when I got arrested in 2009 they gave me a choice of a two-year program or four and a half years to nine in jail. I took the two-year program. I went to Queens to J-CAP, graduated with flying colors, been clean ever since.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: Okay, I was incarcerated and I went upstate. I stayed at Rikers Island for 30 days exactly, and I went straight upstate. I stayed upstate from January of ’97 to August ’97. Nine months. Nine months, yeah. Eight months. I would have been there less than that but I went to work release, but then I had to fight.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: matter of fact, well I’d been incarcerated like go to Rikers Island, I’d go for like three days, 7 at the most. And I was 37 years old and the judge gave me a one to three. She said — I’m not going to give you city I don’t understand you wait so long to get a record, I’m going to teach you a tough lesson. So she sent me upstate. I was in Beacon Correctional Facility. This was in ’96. I had long dreads in my hair. Long dreadlocks. Anyway, the judge said she going to teach me a tough lesson and she did, okay? Just so happened I said — let me take a HIV test. I took the test and it came back positive. I was like devastated. But matter of fact prior to that, well my sister she also suffers from gland problems, my glands kept swolling up, swolling up, and my ear was hurting, made everything hurt. So I went and had a biopsy done and that’s when I found out I was positive

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: I was born August 20, 1955 in Brooklyn, I was born and raised in Brooklyn. I was born the same day as my sister, she’s three years older than me. I have two other siblings, all girls. I'm the next to the baby. I grew up in the projects in Brooklyn, Cooper projects in Greepoint, in a strict household. My mom was a Jehovah’s Witness but my dad wasn’t (laughter). So we had-- It was…I didn't really know my dad. He was in jail when I was like nine months old and I think he came back when I was about five. I don't remember him when I was young, I don't know why I just don’t.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I ended up in the penitentiary with my youngest daughter with a friend, my second diagnosis in five years, still not knowing what it is that I have. Got out of the penitentiary and there was a DCFS worker waiting for me at the gate. And he told me that if I thought I wanted my kids back I probably wouldn't get them back because I had HIV. But he brought me to the wrong place, he took me to the Fantus Clinic at Stroger Hospital. And that was his mistake, taking me to the Fantus Clinic because not only did they educate me about HIV, they educated me about my rights concerning HIV and you know, that nobody could take my child simply because…there were people trying to.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: Really I was more like the mother/nurturing one. Because as the oldest girl I used to have to be the second mother to them. No, I didn't really like it. I used to have to be the babysitter while my mom worked. My father was in and out of prison so my mom depended on me a lot, and my aunt depended on me a lot, I used to have to go over and watch her children and that’s when a lot of my abuse was, due to her husband as well.

list.subject: FB
list.extract:
Tammy:....Did you ever run the streets? 
FB: No. 
Tammy: Dang! She shouldn’t be here….Do you know how you contracted HIV? 
FB Yes, I do. 
Jennie Do you want to tell us the story? 
FB My husband stayed in the streets, like I say I was working 10, 12, 16 hours a day in the factories. And he would run the roads. He was doing street drugs and this that and the other. Like I say, I never thought the first time, because he never told me he was out there for, just out getting drugs, but evidently he brought the big boy home. And I told him, I said – if you ever go back to prison, I'm leaving. So when he went back to prison I filed for divorce and left. And then I got to getting sick and it had to come from him.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: But I’m not sad today being HIV positive. I’m not sad today for the fact that had I not, and this might sound real strange, had I not started using drugs, had I not been in that place to meet the man that I met out there, using drugs, and doing what I do to get my drugs through that individual, I would never have my queen today.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: I became a somebody two or three years ago. That’s why I could put the makeup on, I could dress up the outside; but did it match the inside? No. I just got there. I just got it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: Well actually like I said, I stopped but I did it for me, I didn’t really do it for none of them, I did it for me. Because you have to do it for you before you can be there for anybody, for anybody else. But my oldest daughter, she was really, really...and I could really see it in her eyes, like she wanted me, she goes — okay you have the virus, okay I’ve known people with the virus, I know people with AIDS, they can live long lives and long and long and long! She’s like — I just want you, because that was her worst fear of losing me.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: Like before I was diagnosed, I say the same thing now, that I never really was happy with myself — I wasn’t happy with myself and I didn’t know why. I was existing but not living. I was existing, I was not living. I remember after I suffered two months I was in my house, so I was diagnosed and went in the hospital and like a breeze came to me and told me that I’m going to borrow you for a minute. When I was in the hospital for that month, it was like I was in the hospital to introduce me to me. To connect with me, to find myself, to find myself, to rest and find myself. And my accomplish now is the relationship that I have with myself (crying). That I don’t have to be in a relationship with a man, I’m in a relationship with myself.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I’m in a relationship that I’ve never been in...and this is a strong relationship. It’s not my time to go outside myself. It’s not my time because I’m in a place I’ve never been; a relationship with myself. My mother used to tell me — good things will come to those who wait, and I never could wait. But it seems like this is my time. And if I ever get into a relationship, it’s going to be a relationship and I didn’t have to go searching, looking for it; it’s going to come to me.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: Oh boy, it seems like my life is better now that I am HIV positive because when I was HIV negative, like I said, I was existing. It’s like the virus brought me to me; the virus brought me to myself.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I have years from childhood stuff that I hold in, hold in, hold in. And I didn’t know, I didn’t know, until I started releasing, releasing when I went to see...first when I was diagnosed, a little later on, the feeling didn’t hit then, but when the feeling hit that took me into be depressed...I used to always cry all the time, I didn’t know why I was crying. And I remember when I was first diagnosed I told them that I needed a support system, so they had sent me to 57 Willoughby Street and I sat there almost a whole year and I never talk or nothing.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: The difference I’m trying to make is to realize that I am HIV. There’s a lot of things that you can do to lift up your spirit. I always take my medication like clockwork. Maybe not the same time because some-times I don’t eat during...but I take it every single day. And I want to be able to live with it. I really think I’ve been so in denial, that’s why I let my body go so bad. I just didn’t...but now I have that spunk, like somebody lit a fire under my butt because I really, really want to live. I’m not embarrassed anymore. I’ll go talk and speak, but I got to  learn also how to tell my 15-year-old and I don’t even think I want to. Because [D] feels I’m all he has. His mother’s his other mother; I’m his mom. I’m his light, his God, I’m everything to [D]. Little does he know that that’s what he means to me. And sometimes I feel like I should let him know, give him the awareness because every time I look at him...maybe in groups or something where there’s other children that he can meet, because one-on-one from me I wouldn’t want to just tell him, no.
