I want him to see that other kids are coping with their parents with it. But I still really, I don’t know about [D], I feel like I’ll hurt him.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: I disclosed to my grandchildren in Georgia. I disclosed to my daughters; I haven't disclosed to my grandchildren here because they're still young and they're in college, one of them, and one is on the way to high school. The other is graduating next week from junior high, so I don't want their feelings mixed up right now, because they love their grandma! I didn't tell my mother. She took it to the—I let her-- She died, I didn't tell my mother. But it feels like a good load is off your body, it’s like an energy that just left you because being HIV positive it’s like you are living with dumbbells inside, and it’s weighing you. You feel the weight. When you let go and you feel the courage to disclose, you feel this weight off your feet and you feel light.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I’m comfortable with myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die as long as I take care of myself. It just means taking better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life...I’m a much better person now, stronger, confident, just you know ready to help whoever I can... I’m okay with it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: Thank God today I have been to groups and all kinds of educational programs, stuff like that. I learned so much about it. Yeah that is one thing, once I did find out about it, after a while, long about I’d say probably two years after I found out I think, I got myself together and I started pursuing to see what this HIV was about and how can I deal with it and live longer and that’s what I’ve been doing up until now. I just don’t feel like telling everybody about it right now, I’m comfortable myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die long as I take care of myself. It just means tak-ing better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life. Really if I look at it, you know, because I still would have been out there doing what I was doing probably, I don’t know. I’m a much better person now, stronger, confidence, just you know, ready to help whoever I can...I’m okay with it. It’s just letting people in.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: I’ve been doing pretty good. I’m still on the same regimen, yes. I really look at it as a blessing in a sense because if I hadn’t found out I was positive I wouldn’t be looking on the brighter side and doing better things for myself. I might not have seeked housing, I might still been out there. I look at it as a blessing.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: When I moved back from Long Island to Brooklyn, when I got my apartment in Brooklyn I had set two short goals – first to get my skates, and get a sewing machine. I was back in Brooklyn for about a month and it came like that (snap) and that made me feel good. I started back skating and I didn’t miss a beat.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: One of the things I accomplished was keeping up my home, doing, living day by day; I still haven’t accomplished everything that I wanted to accomplish but little by little, I’m accomplishing things

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: My support system is my family, my friends, a sponsor that I had, may she rest in peace, she taught me a lot of things. I didn’t tell her anything about the HIV because she was like—oh, you don’t have to disclose, you can if you want to but you’re not obligated to let anybody know. I was always at home, she always talked to me, we used to go out and have dinner. But we had our own one-to-one meeting and she said—you don’t have to be alone, you know? She said, whenever you need anything, call me, no matter what time it is, just call me. She said to get out, even if it’s by yourself, go to the park, walk in the park, go see a movie, if I don’t have anyone to go with, just go by yourself. You don’t need anyone to live your life, to enjoy yourself. Now I’m starting to practice that. Like yesterday I went to a concert, my daughter bought me a ticket for Mother’s Day for this concert, I had a great time by myself you know? [inaudible] It was great.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: Because I believe in God and I think that that’s what’s helped me through a lot of everything that’s happened in my life is going to church and praying to God and learning that God is there no matter what...for me.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: He’s the person that I had my last two children with, he’s the person who taught…well, I can’t say taught…but showed me the difference in life and that I could be loved, that I was worth loving. And there was nothing he wouldn’t do for us. You see what I’m saying? And I stood with him for 22 years, I took care of him.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: My T-cells, nothing has never went down that low. I’ve always been active, always been able to do for myself. Never had to have no—I’m not going to say I didn’t get the flu or whatever, you know that’s common. But as far as my HIV status, no. I’ve been able to take care of myself, do for myself.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: HIV definitely saved my life. I knew enough to know I didn't want to die, you know? And that meant getting clean, getting sober. I had one attack in my body like it was a hungry lion and then I threw drugs and alcohol in the mix and my body was like – girl! I'm going to quit on you if you don’t stop!

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I did my volunteer work, I did the MATEC training you know. Because nobody wanted to be with the AIDS patients in Cook County Hospital. So what’d they do? They trained the AIDS patients to go sit with the AIDS patients. Because we knew that there’s nothing, we knew we needed comfort, so we took these classes and we went and comforted our people.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract:
[And what are some of the joyful things?]
Joyful things, um, I think when my daughter got, I think she was about eight. I had drugs then and she would be like – ma, can I go outside? And I’d be like – you don’t really want to go outside. Because she’d be standing there twisting my hair while she was begging to go outside, so the longer I prolonged it, the more twisting she did. She wanted to go somewhere one day and I'm like – my legs hurt. And she went – take a pill, let’s go! She accepted my illness that day. And she’s never looked back since then and she’s 28 now. But the fact that there was no judgment, you know? Today we try to be a non-judgmental family. When you're at home, no judgment. You get enough of that out in the world, you shouldn’t have to be judged when you're at home. So we kind of practice that now. 
 And that was as big a day to me as the day she told her friends – my mom has HIV. And y’all need to not be having sex! Those were two glorious days to me.

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: Northwestern started a women’s group for women over the age of 40. With HIV…oh, this smells so good. And, um, I started going twice a month to the women’s group, and we would have an evening dinner and it was informal. We would just talk about what’s bothering us, what’s on our mind, things like when we were first diagnosed you would get up 50 times a night and make sure your door was locked. And I’ve learned through my yoga and meditation, to just let it go, like Frozen.

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: It was actually through Northwestern. Because I said – I can’t afford this medicine. And they said all you have to is pick it up. And then after every so many weeks I would go in…my ears got black, and people kept saying – have you been to the Bahamas? Because I was really chocolate, and I liked the color, but then after they adjusted it, my nails are white again.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: So God was allowing me to get my mind right. (crying) (inaudible) I was about to take, and I was ready then. Treatment opened up, because I was scared, I didn't want no more and I wanted to give my son a chance! And I stayed in Maryville for two years, I went to Haymarket, I stayed there for 18 months and I was scared to leave because I just didn't want to have no more. I moved into a program where they monitor us, you know? They subsidized my rent, then I had just got active into, after that I begin engaged in my medical care, wanted now to take care of my HIV. I began to educate myself about what it is that I had.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: And so I fought, I went to the Core Center, they had a program set up for parenting skills. And so they said…I still got the certificate, you go there and get your certificate, then you take that to DCFS and then they know you working towards your goal to get your son back. And so when I used to go over to her house, my son’s foster mother house, I used to sit down, she would get the bleach and wipe whatever I touched. And so it went on like that, and then I think it was more she was being nasty towards me because she know she had to fight, because I had gotten start healing then, feeling better…I want my child back! And so we started going back and forth to court and what happened was I started getting visitation, everything. They had to let me participate in everything. And this went on for years. My son is 26 now, and he’s still back and forth with her.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Yes, I started seeking counseling [about the molestation]. And then like I said, I started going to groups. I found out that other people had worse issues than I did, you know! It didn't make me feel good but it helped to know that I wasn’t out there alone. And then some of these things that suppressed me or made me very depressed, it can happen to anybody, it can happen to the best of people.

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: The most pressing issues I faced was my drug addiction and finding out I was positive was…there were a couple of other personal issues that I faced. My drug addiction, I remember I went to the methadone clinic to try to get myself some treatment, and that didn’t work for me. I remember one day going to my mom’s house and I was just out of it, and I remember her telling me distinctly – I don’t know what kind of help you’re getting, what ever help you’re getting is worse than the stuff that you were on before you got the help. And that always stuck in my head.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I want my future to look…I want there to become a cure, a real cure. I know that the medicines are keeping us alive but I want one day to take that test and say – it’s not there anymore! That’s what I want my future to be. I don't want to have to put expiration dates on my life, like my first goal was to see my kids graduate from high school. Now this goal I'm making is to see my grandkids grown. I don't want to have to have praying for expiration dates. I want to be praying that God give man knowledge of a cure, a real cure, and not just a Band-aid that you putting over by taking the medication.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: It was up to me to take matters in my own hands or leave it alone and live my life. I planned on taking matters in my own hands. I wanted to kill him, I made a vow with myself that I would, and even though going through counseling eventually I just started to lie – like oh I'm not going to hurt anybody, oh I'm better now. Because I definitely had to get counseling. What I did was I planned – I'm going to find this man and kill him so he won't do this to anybody else. I’ll deal with the jail time. I even got a will prepared for myself so my kids would be taken care of. It just never happened and I'm thankful that it never did. I didn't see him until I had forgiven myself and forgiven him. I did that in 2004. I went to a church encounter for women and gosh, I just laid everything down, all my anger, all my hurts from childhood all the way up…I had to forgive me for making different choices that put me in harm’s way, forgive people for hurting me. I just had to get it off of my chest.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Once I embraced it because you hear – ok you're HIV positive. For some people, you have these feelings of oh my gosh, you're just still in shock. Some people can be in denial; I was never in denial, I was still just in shock. One day I was able to accept it. I was just like – deep breath, okay, it’s a part of my life. There's nothing I can do. I can't go get a shot and make it go away, I can't take medicine and make it go away. It’s always going to be there, on paper they’ll always have that December 13, 2001 I was diagnosed with HIV. I just embraced it and said you know what? What else can I do? Cause I can't allow this to weigh heavy on me because I have too many other responsibilities in life than to worry about this one thing.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: I'm grateful for…I wouldn't change the diagnosis. People say would you go back? Go back for what? There’s too much to go back to. Honestly I’ve met more people, I’ve been able to do a whole lot as an advocate and a woman living with HIV. I’ve been able to help other women, connect with other women, network with other women, come up with ideas so we can help make an impact on our community and dispel myths and stop stigmas. It’s just been great. Even doing the research studies, I always say yes, I never say no. There are a lot of people who are afraid of research, even if it is questioning. Because just fear, lack of knowing, years ago it was always said – what goes on in the house stays in the house, don’t tell people your business. But a lot of these things help other people and that’s what I'm about, helping other people. If I have to be a part of it, I care. That’s it because I’ll keep talking (laughter).

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: I shared it with my mother when I was 25, I wrote her a letter and told her about her brother and she in return told me that it wasn’t true, that he brother said that it wasn’t true, and I’ve never had a relationship with my mother, I really still don’t have a relationship with my mother due to the fact that I was molested at five and she wasn’t there to protect me...Yes. Everyone one knows my mother and I are distant...A couple of them have passed on but one of them who just always took advantage of me was my Uncle G and I saw him one year in a store and I beat him up. I beat him bad. And the people in the store let me beat him. So I got revenge on him.

list.subject: Claristine
list.extract: I would like… to leave a legacy for women. I would like to do everything I could to help HIV women, help women on the street, that’s why I'm trying to get this house for women, and the name of it is The House of Refuge Women’s Center.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: I don’t ever want to make my day feel like I'm living with HIV. I don’t never live like that. I don’t never put it in my head that that’s what I'm living with or that’s what I'm living for, because I'm not! I'm living for myself. In the next two years I'm going to be older, I know I'm going to be older. But I really don’t see myself anywhere else but where I'm at today. You know?

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I'm a (crying) good person, because of WIHS and people like you and ID Clinic, I'm living with a disease. I have a disease; the disease don’t have me anymore. It’s a part of me but it ain't got me by no means. I’ve been undetected for five years and I was diagnosed in 2010. So I think I did pretty good.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I learned that to get pretty or get nice for me; I don’t do it for nobody else. I got clean, I tried to get clean for my husbands, for my kids. I didn't get clean until I wanted to get clean for Tamie. When I decided to get clean for me, I got clean. I'm staying clean for me. I get dressed up and do what I need to do for me. So it’s all about me

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: I was out walking on the block or in the hood or whatever, and this guy pulled up, I'm thinking it’s just another regular trick, you know? And he asked me my name and I said yes, that’s me. He said – would you mind if I talked to you for a minute? And he showed me his badge from the health department. And I knew it couldn't have been nothing good, you know? It’s the man from the health department, you know? It’s something! So we talked and he told me they were looking for me because somebody gave them my name that I had slept with and they had tested positive for HIV. And at that moment, at that time right then, my world just completely collapsed. Just completely collapsed. It just, um I can't even think of the word for it. I didn't understand, I didn't understand right then at that moment – why me? But as time has went on – why not me? You know? Why not me, I put myself in that predicament. I did things I shouldn’t have done and this is the result of my self-will.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: When they gave it to me I could be at the dope house, call my friend up – I forgot to take my medicine, can you bring it to me? That’s how serious I was that this is not going to beat me, I'm going to beat it. And now as I look back over my life, I wouldn't change a thing, nothing would I have changed. Because what I got now is way, way better than what I had then. My children love me, my family still loves me, but most of all I love me! And if I can love me, who cares what people think or people say?

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Velvet
list.extract:
I was gang raped, I lived through that.  This last was a gang of eight, they had on all black or blue, whatever, and the last one he saved my life.  He was just acting like he was doing something to me and he said – just act like I'm doing something to you but I want to let you fall and I'm going to run.  Because I was supposed to been initiated to the gang, but I don't want to do it if this what it takes.  He dropped me and he ran, and he told me they were going to shoot at him.  He ran and I'm telling you, he ran so fast I mean, just like I was looking at Carl Lewis!  He ran so fast, he was outta sight before it seemed like I could blink my eye.  
 I met this young man two years later on a Sunday, him and his fiancée were walking together and the only way I recognized him because I couldn't see him was his voice. And he asked me where was the bus stop, he wanted his fiancée to sit down because she was due any day with their baby.  And I said – well the bus stop is right there…And I walked [away] and we both looked back at each other and tears came down his eyes and he said, he walked to me, I walked to him and he said – I'm sorry.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: But today, to give back to society, to give back to somebody to help me, even to give back to welfare that took care of me all my life, to pay into Medicaid and my insurance and pay taxes and all that good stuff. I hate it, but to pay bills, that a good thing, to give

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I was diagnosed at Brookdale Hospital and I always say that they almost killed me before they healed me. I always say they almost killed me before they healed me. Every time I used to come to the clinic I used to always cry, cry, cry all the time. But now keep my appointment, I come to the clinic faithfully, even though I know what I’m here for, I do not stress about it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: ...then they told me that they was closing the place. I thought my heart just fell out. In my mind I was saying — how can they close this place? What am I’m going to do? I’m going to go back, I’m going to go backwards in my feelings right, being closed in with myself. Yes, I cried, cried my way all the way home and then when I got home it was like this voice came to me and told me—when one door close another door will open.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I have years from childhood stuff that I hold in, hold in, hold in. And I didn’t know, I didn’t know, until I started releasing, releasing when I went to see...first when I was diagnosed, a little later on, the feeling didn’t hit then, but when the feeling hit that took me into be depressed...I used to always cry all the time, I didn’t know why I was crying. And I remember when I was first diagnosed I told them that I needed a support system, so they had sent me to 57 Willoughby Street and I sat there almost a whole year and I never talk or nothing.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: For me to be diagnosed it was like a relief to know what was wrong with me, because I suffered. Before I was diagnosed I suffered. They was treating me for asthma, giving me all kind of asthma pumps and stuff. This went on for two months, giving me all types of asthma pumps and when I go to the emergency rooms they give me a treat-ment and send me back home. Meanwhile everything I did, I’m gasping for breath, gasping for breath, gasping for breath. This went on for two months.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I’ve never had any side effects but the fact that I was going to have to take them every day, that was my issue. I don’t like taking medication.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I met someone and I knew he was a drug dealer and I went out with him and I never thought nothing of it. And I wasn’t diagnosed until I left Beacon and came to Queens because I was checked in Beacon and I was fine. So when you switch to another state you got go to a new clinic...The doctor said — can I do an HIV test? I said yes, you can, because I’m fine. ’91. When she came back and told me I was HIV— because back in the days I thought you were just dying. I didn’t read up, I should have, and I started to cry and I told her —  ‘now what? You don’t want to touch me?’ Oh God, that doctor hugged me so hard.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I don’t know how to tell [D] because I’m...I don’t want him to think because you’re HIV you’re going to die. I had to correct a lady one time in a clinic because she said —  do you have AIDS? And I said no ma’am, I have the virus. Why did I get so mad? I had to recently see my doctor because I was getting scared because if I have an ear-ache, I’m already thinking...see I’m losing weight, a lot of weight and I asked her if I’m going downhill. And she said Cookie — your T-cell count is undetected, your viral load is sky high. You ain’t going to die from that. [VIRAL LOAD IS UNDETECTABLE AND YOUR T-CELLS ARE HIGH] She said so high, so it woke me up. I gotta get out of this funk. I really have to get out of it. I just take medication and now I’m drinking protein.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: Now I’ve been on one for many years, but altogether I went through maybe 18 [medications] throughout 30 years. Only because I developed what they call lipodystrophy. Back then they didn't have the studies that they have now. One of the very first medications that I took, I was taking 10+ pills per day, which was called Viracept. And it would give a person chronic diarrhea; I couldn't leave the house, I had to wait to use the bathroom first to be able to get dressed and go out, because I had a fear of using the bathroom. Thank God I’ve never had drug resistance.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: HIV is just one of little thing of many. I don’t focus on it. I take my medication like I'm taking for a headache. It has become part of me, my medication. So it’s a ritual that I have. They're next to my bedside, I take it in the morning and I take it in the evening. But it’s a ritual because I take that bottle of medication to the kitchen with me so I could take the morning, then I take it back to the bedroom so I can take in the night. So I would never find that pill bottle in the kitchen in the evening because it’s a ritual I do. Where this has focused me on being adhered to my medications. This is how I help others also.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: My thing was – when detox is over, what am I going to do and where am I going to go? After that weekend that I was supposed to get out, they held me an extra day because I told them – where am I going from here? So they held me an extra day. [A] talked to the social service department in the Women and Infant Transmission Study because that’s how I got plugged into Downstate. They were running this program for pregnant women that were positive at that time. They had a study going on; she asked me if I wanted to be part of it and well, a smart person would think – okay, this where you’re going to get most of your information firsthand and sooner than later if I join this, I’ll get to learn a lot more about what’s going on a lot quicker than I would anyplace else.

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: Because if you don’t take your medicine you won't be okay, period point blank. And it took a long time for them to even recognize women in anything when it comes to this disease, and then to focus on what works for us. Because what works for us is not working for men. You understand? Because I had two children before they even told me – ask me about being HIV positive or taking an HIV test. But they test them other two children I had and they never told me one way or the other with them, but I know that they're not, because time goes on. But I’ll be here for you baby.

list.subject: Loretta
list.extract: Because like I was just explaining to you guys, there was a time when I couldn’t tolerate it. I couldn’t tolerate it, and I just wouldn’t take ‘em. And I told my doctor – until I get better with it, there’s nothing that she could do, she could tell me and change the pills and do whatever, nothing she could do until I get better with it and that’s what it took. I’m much better now with the medication and taking the medication and managing with the medication. I thank God for it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: When I first found out I was in denial. I wouldn’t take no medication. They only had AZT back then; I declined it because people was dying. Now I’m on a regimen that is working, I’m undetectable, I want to live now. I was self-destructive when I first found out. Now I just want to live another 33 years (laughter).

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: I’ve been doing pretty good. I’m still on the same regimen, yes. I really look at it as a blessing in a sense because if I hadn’t found out I was positive I wouldn’t be looking on the brighter side and doing better things for myself. I might not have seeked housing, I might still been out there. I look at it as a blessing.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: I like them [THE WIHS STAFF] because they came to be—Joan, Dr. Sha, Sylvia, Anna— they have all came to be like a family.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: I’m like okay, I got to questioning my faith and like okay, you been to church all these years, apparently you’ve got all this or whatever and so you still around for something. I started doing a little bit of research, I’m real good with computers and I started doing a little bit of research, and I heard about the Radiation Center, which was, they had a women’s group in there, a women’s support group. So I started going to the women’s support group at Cook County Hospital, okay?

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract:
And that’s how WIHS was born.... And it got bigger and bigger and branched out and they, it was such an inspiration to me because the Core Center for one, they have groups there, different support groups. So I could come to the Core Center and I could go to a Recovery Group, I can go to a Women of Dignity Group, I can go to an HIV Support Group, I can do all of that at the Core Center. And I could see my primary doctor. And WIHS, before they got this wonderful office, they still have some of their people that come back and forth that’s at the Core Center, but then they created this wonderful office. So for one, WIHS took a lot of weight off of our primary care doctors because WIHS does so much for us, from the Pap smear to the…so when I go to see my primary care doctor, she’s like—okay Cordelia, what you need? Some paperwork filled out or refills sent down? And let me check your heart and look in your ears, okay, have a good day (laughter). And for a while I was like dang, that’s not fair, she don’t have to do nothing! Here it is research got to do all this different stuff. I’m like okay, you get the care where you can get it or
when you can get it, from whoever you can get it from.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: Dr. Mardge Cohen, who of course you know is the initiator of all of this Core Center being in existence and all of that. And we used to sit in that Radiation Center before they actually built the Core Center, we’d sit in that Radiation Center, it would hot as a firecracker in there because there wasn’t no air conditioner so we’d have a fan on and we sitting skin to skin sweating and we just be talking but it was just one big family you know?

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: But you know what's ironic to me about that little area, it was in the radiation center and the irony of like how many of us with HIV are now dying from cancer? To think that the women’s clinic started in the cancer clinic and now we need a cancer clinic in our clinic.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I ended up in the penitentiary with my youngest daughter with a friend, my second diagnosis in five years, still not knowing what it is that I have. Got out of the penitentiary and there was a DCFS worker waiting for me at the gate. And he told me that if I thought I wanted my kids back I probably wouldn't get them back because I had HIV. But he brought me to the wrong place, he took me to the Fantus Clinic at Stroger Hospital. And that was his mistake, taking me to the Fantus Clinic because not only did they educate me about HIV, they educated me about my rights concerning HIV and you know, that nobody could take my child simply because…there were people trying to.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: This was ’85.  And the doctor came in and started asking me about my life and my habits.  And he came back and he goes – your baby has HIV so I'm pretty sure you have it, too. He walked away and I let him.  It was just like everything else in my life, nobody explained it to me, nobody told me anything.  So after a week or so in the hospital they let my daughter come home, she was better.  Her immune system had kicked in, kicked mine out, she is not positive.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I did my volunteer work, I did the MATEC training you know. Because nobody wanted to be with the AIDS patients in Cook County Hospital. So what’d they do? They trained the AIDS patients to go sit with the AIDS patients. Because we knew that there’s nothing, we knew we needed comfort, so we took these classes and we went and comforted our people.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I never forget, I walked up one day and there was this guy, he just had the sheet wrapped around him and he was just rocking. He was like – I’ve been here for five days, nobody’s talked to me, they barely want to touch me. I'm like – we can talk, I'm here, I ain't going nowhere. And for me, that was my epiphany. To see him just wrapped up, just waiting to die. Because the nurses only came when they had to. So from that point on I started running my mouth and talking and…

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: A specialist girlfriend of mine called me from Evanston, everybody knew we were getting married, this guy and I. And I came in from church and she said – sit down. I went – what’s up? She said, the guy you're engaged to is dying from AIDS. I went – I'm not engaged to him anymore. And then she said – well, you were with him for over two years and you said you stopped using condoms after you became engaged because – I thought he was safe. But he wasn’t. So um she said – get to Evanston Hospital, and I got out there and they knew nothing about this virus, and at that time you had to wait like a month for results. And when this young intern came in he looked at me and he said – Delores? I said – what? He said – (whispering) you’re going to die. I automatically started hyperventilating (deep breaths).

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: Northwestern started a women’s group for women over the age of 40. With HIV…oh, this smells so good. And, um, I started going twice a month to the women’s group, and we would have an evening dinner and it was informal. We would just talk about what’s bothering us, what’s on our mind, things like when we were first diagnosed you would get up 50 times a night and make sure your door was locked. And I’ve learned through my yoga and meditation, to just let it go, like Frozen.

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: It was actually through Northwestern. Because I said – I can’t afford this medicine. And they said all you have to is pick it up. And then after every so many weeks I would go in…my ears got black, and people kept saying – have you been to the Bahamas? Because I was really chocolate, and I liked the color, but then after they adjusted it, my nails are white again.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: So I was up all night calling places, and it just so happened that Julie Washington, she works at the Core Center, she was my substitute for my counselor, but she wasn’t even working at the Core, she was working at County and somewhere she saw my name. She was just coming to see if it was me. I call her my guardian angel. She walked down that hall and I said – Julie, I need your help, I gotta go into treatment, they said I can keep my baby! (crying) You know and she was like…she called some place and they found a place that day for me to take Madison. They came and picked us up and took us to Haymarket.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: I didn't know anything [about AIDS when I was diagnosed]! All I know was that it was like a deadly…I did know this, it was a virus and it was a deadly virus. And I did know that it was a gay man’s disease. But I really didn't care at that time, you know? I didn't really care because I was just still out there, you know, in the street. All I cared about was getting my fix and then oh – I’ll get treated tomorrow. But when I got to the Fantus Clinic I started learning about it through group, you know. I started listening to what my doctor was saying and I didn't even know that if your T-cell count fall below, back then it was 200, then you had the AIDS.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: When I had him I was never given prenatal care and then on top of that I was shooting drugs, I was drinking, I'm surprised he came out a perfect baby like he did. But the thing was, when he came out he had drugs in his system….So when I got to the hospital he was gone. But before they even did all that, they released me and kept him because they had to let him detox. Before they even did all that they came in my room, the doctor, fully gowned I mean from head to toe looking like astronauts and told me I had AIDS. They didn't say nothing about HIV positive, and did I want to talk to a chaplain? And you know if you have to talk to a chaplain, that means, you know, you don’t have long to live. It could be today or tomorrow. That’s because they didn't really know that much about HIV or AIDS you know?

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: Hey we’re still here. I got more appointments now that I'm getting older of course…oh check this out, check that out!

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: There’s a new ‘women and children’s clinic’ at the county, it was like six months old. That was February of ‘89 and they started that summer before, July of ‘88. And so I eventually found my way to the Radiation Center, but not before going to a couple of different addresses because he really didn’t know how to tell me where the hell it was, somewhere in there. So after making a couple of calls, after going to where these people would tell me which was all the wrong places, I finally got through and they told me of a health educator and he was the one to get in touch with to get the testing done. And I remember I kept missing him.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: Remember when we used to have the group on the second floor in the Fantus Clinic? The women’s support group we’d have on the second floor in the back. So I waited out in front for him where the population was waiting for whatever clinic they were going to go into, in the Fantus Clinic. The lady at the front told me—well, he’s a little guy and he’s usually in a white coat.

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: The most pressing issues I faced was my drug addiction and finding out I was positive was…there were a couple of other personal issues that I faced. My drug addiction, I remember I went to the methadone clinic to try to get myself some treatment, and that didn’t work for me. I remember one day going to my mom’s house and I was just out of it, and I remember her telling me distinctly – I don’t know what kind of help you’re getting, what ever help you’re getting is worse than the stuff that you were on before you got the help. And that always stuck in my head.

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract: it has recently come to the doctor’s attention that this is something new that they know nothing about but yet people are starting to show up with these symptoms and with this particular blood work

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: Then I got introduced to WIHS through the Core Center. And WIHS is just great, they’re great to us. I get tests that I need to actually have anyway and all the Paps and that, I need that because I had problems with my cervix in the past, so I need that. I get what I need – medical attention. They’re very friendly and very nice to us, generous with us, you know generous with us, personable. It’s been a great experience being in WIHS. I love this project, I’m glad to do it. I’m glad to share my experiences, if anybody has an interest.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: They ask a lot of good questions about different things in your life – do you have access to the proper healthcare? Do you have access to medicine? People need to know somebody cares and finds that out. Relationships. We were in a project about relationships, disclosure, I got a little certificate a couple years back.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh yes, I have problems getting my medication now because…the amount, okay if you make a certain amount of money then you don’t qualify for this program, but the medicine is so expensive that my insurance won't pay for it, so excuse my language but you're damned if you do, and you're damned if you don’t, that type of situation. Work and you make money and then your insurance don’t pay for the medicine. Don’t work and you can get all of these things but I'm living in poverty. Like now I can't get any, the social workers are trying to get me assistance, we’re trying to get my medicine. Well, I can't get it because they can't help me, because the amount. I make more money than what they require...Um, in a way because people can't go to the doctors, they can't afford to go to the health, to get medical treatment. A lot of people that don’t have money, let's put it like this. If I had $100 to put food on the table for my kids, but I needed that $100 to go to the doctor, what do you think that person will do? They’ll take that $100 and feed their children. Because that $100 probably could feed their kids for the month, if you're living in poverty. I'm not going to take the $100 and go to the doctor when I know that I have to survive. So yes, it’s a lot of people that are lacking care because of money.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh yes, a lot, I have. I went to a woman’s clinic down here in North Carolina and I was having female problems and the doctor said to me…you might want to go to a clinic that deals with people like you. And I didn't understand what he meant. You know, I was like – what do you mean by that? At first I was like do you mean black people? And he was like oh, come on. You know what I mean. We’re not equipped to handle your situation. So that really…and this was like maybe 10 years ago, so it’s not that knowledge wasn’t out there and he didn't know, that’s just the way he felt. He didn't want to deal with me. He didn't want to treat me.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Um, yes, because the percentage that they gave me of the child not being positive was so low that it was an influence yes, go get rid of this baby because it was what they were telling me it was more than 50% chance that the child would be positive. Which we know nowadays no, that’s not true, but back then I didn't know any better. I had zero to no knowledge about this and they had zero to no knowledge and all that I saw that the people that had AIDS and were HIV positive were dying. In the streets dying, that was all around me, everybody was dying. Nobody was living from it.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: So I go to this dentist and he read my chart and he wouldn't come near me. As close as you're sitting to me, he was a little bit further away, and when it came time for him to look in my mouth he was kind of like hesitant to look. He didn't touch me at all. He just wouldn't come near me. And he said – I'm just going to give you the purple pill, this acid reflux. And I'm like – acid reflux, no it’s something else and I didn't know what it was, I didn't really know it was my tonsils, I thought my glands were swollen. He prescribed it and he never checked me over or anything, he just wanted to get away from me. I just felt small, I just felt isolated, felt really, really sad, and I didn't even get a follow-up appointment, I just left out of there…I kinda left out in tears.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract:
Oh gosh, a wonderful, wonderful diagnosis. It was really devastating, because I thought I had lymphoma cancer. I'm a researcher and I'm very, very in tune with my body so I know when something’s not right. I caught a cold, turned into strep, and then the lymph nodes in my neck swelled up. They swelled so bad that I couldn't really turn my neck and I could see lumps sitting outside my neck and I'm just like – oh my gosh, what is that? So researching all the symptoms I had led to lymphoma. Okay, I'm going to call my doctor, I think it’s this but I'm not a doctor so I don't know. And also it wasn’t like okay, this is hanging on for like two days. We’re talking weeks this thing is going on. So I'm scared, call the doctor, I said – I want a biopsy. 
	Well, when I went in, went to the health department, and they had already had test results from my last HIV test. Normally I never go back for an HIV test, any STD tests were always negative. And I knew how to protect myself. Well, I had been tested since I’d been with my now ex-husband and I didn't go back for test results, because they're always negative. Well, the health department failed to contact me. I slipped through the cracks, they actually told me that because they were trying to say well, we tried to call you, we tried to send you a letter…well no, you didn't. I still live at the same place, phone number’s been the same for years, no you didn't. Just long story short they told me I slipped through the cracks but when I got the news, the nurse couldn't even verbally tell me. Because they all knew me, I'm a really nice person and when I go into places I become a joy (laughter). 
	When I went there I'm sitting in a room, half the size of the room I’m in now, and she pushes a folder towards me and opens it and in red it said HIV Positive. And that’s how I learned. She just couldn’t…It wasn’t that she wasn’t being professional, she was hurt, she was hurt for me. Because her whole demeanor just I just didn't understand. When I got it I screamed, I cried, man I just wanted to leave. I tried to get my keys and my purse, I went to get it and it was gone because she had it hiding behind her and she was barricading the door and she just didn't want me to leave. I understand that. I was telling this story to someone before and they're like – oh my gosh why would she do that? For my protection. I was upset, I was distraught, and I wanted to get in my car and drive. Well, what if I did that? I could have had an accident or anything could have happened. But hearing that news, gosh…

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well there was a time…When I first realized what I had, I didn't want to get better. I did not want to get better, but I knew my son was trying to have a child and I asked God – if said you just let me live long enough to see my grandbaby, then whatever comes, comes. And that helped me get through a lot of it. And my sisters kept telling me – you can do this, you can do this. I was like everybody else; I was dumb. I thought it was a death sentence. When I got to working with Dr. Kozel and everything, she would talk to me and she didn't think I was going to make it, but she kept my hopes up. So I had to pull myself out of that to be able to make myself go on. And my sisters would come over and help me and make sure I had my medicine because like I said, I couldn't remember nothing; I couldn't remember when to take medicine, what day, what it looked like.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: I guess HIV is still (having happened to me) is still a meaningful experience in that basically it kind of just having to deal with it, again you're going to learn a lot about yourself, a lot about the people around you, who’s really for you and who’s really not. Really if you're going to take care of yourself, I thought I was resourceful and knew a lot about survival, but yes, to a whole other level have I had to learn about survival and resourcefulness from having HIV just in terms of being a working person without health insurance and making too much for Ryan White or ADAT and having to find medication, things like that.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: So, there was that, and then when I got to this study, the people here are so great, you never feel judged. It’s like a warm, fuzzy, sunshiny place to come to for me. You always feel, you know, they always make you feel like a person (crying)... And they don't want anything from you (crying)… So it’s not like they're charging you to make you feel like a person (crying). And you know they provide a lot of needed things, in my case of course it was the physicals and pap smears, but you know, moral support, helping to make sure that I don’t fall into the cracks, which I normally would have done by now in this situation. And there was a time where I was like…I couldn't get the medication because I made too much money (crying) but I didn't have insurance. And I was too depressed to care! (crying)

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: In 2010, I went to Johnson County to the health department because my significant other was cheating and I needed to find out if I had contracted anything. When I went they had been looking for me and I can't really remember, they could tell me exactly how long they’d been looking for me because Wake County had notified Johnson County that they had been looking for me. But I was out using and running the streets and doing what I wanted to do, and I didn't stay at one place long. So they couldn't get up with me. But, I went to be STD tested and they had a picture of me, my name, Social Security number, and asked was that me? And I said yes, and they said well sit down, we have something to tell you. And I wouldn't sit down. They said – you're HIV positive. I denied it, I raised Cain, I put some people out. I said I'm not going nowhere until y’all test me right now. They took me around the corner, drew my blood, told me they’d get back in touch with me. I know that y’all got the machines or whatever y’all need to let me know right now that y’all didn't make no mistake. About 45 minutes later she came back and said – yes ma'am.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I'm a (crying) good person, because of WIHS and people like you and ID Clinic, I'm living with a disease. I have a disease; the disease don’t have me anymore. It’s a part of me but it ain't got me by no means. I’ve been undetected for five years and I was diagnosed in 2010. So I think I did pretty good.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I quit my job…I got $150,000 and I invested, tried to do the right thing, I gave my mom and dad $10,000 apiece off the top to pay for their burial plots, I did some sensible stuff with it– but then I also did some crazy stuff because like I said, I was on the drugs. It didn't last very long. I took myself to the Bahamas, I just treated myself good you know? Because I felt like I paid a dear price; the check was because I couldn't have children. I had one of those Dalkon Shields, I couldn't have children…that still wasn’t enough, that didn't take the place of me being able to have children.

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I was told at, [diagnosed] I was at this place called Durham Center Access. I had gone there because I was homeless, I didn't have anyplace to stay, and they happened to be doing HIV testing and I had no idea I was HIV positive. It didn't take them long to let me know that I was positive. I was a little stunned but I mean, it didn't make me crazy or anything. I just knew I needed to find out what I needed to do at that point. That’s when I asked them what I needed to do and they told me I needed to start going to the health department, the EI Clinic, that I could get some medication and get some help there. So that’s what I did. Since I found out I was HIV positive, I have no problems at all, I am doing very well. It doesn’t bother me. You know what I'm saying? And I had hepatitis C, I'm rid of that now, I got in a Duke study and got the free medicine and all that. I'm real grateful.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: they have a lot of help in Durham for people with or without HIV, I’m just saying. I know enough people to be able to find out about studies and pretty much anything I need to know I’ll research it and I know people I can call and they tell me about studies where I can make some extra money. When they tell me, I let somebody else know. I don’t keep it to myself, you know what I'm saying? Help. Each one, teach one. That’s right.

list.subject: Barbara
list.extract: But today, to give back to society, to give back to somebody to help me, even to give back to welfare that took care of me all my life, to pay into Medicaid and my insurance and pay taxes and all that good stuff. I hate it, but to pay bills, that a good thing, to give

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I was a clerk/typist for a medical malpractice law firm. That was like the first real job I ever had and I was part-time, I started out as part time and kind of pushed myself into full-time because what they needed me to do, it was a lot that needed to be done. So I was supposed to be at work at 1 o’clock; I would show up at 12. I would show up at 11. Then at 9, then at 8. So, you know. And I would do the work, and I was good at it. And then when the work cut down to a manageable point, I was able to, I went to my boss — can y’all teach me to do other things? So that’s when I started to do the mail, do the filing, and things like that. I was an exceptional typist. I’m 19 years old, my very first job, and I can type 85 words a minute. Because when I was eight, seven or eight, my father bought my sister an electric typewriter and I wanted to learn how to type. My mother had a manual typewriter, one of those old manual typewriters. She had a typing book, so I took her book and her typewriter because I wasn’t allowed to use my sister’s electric and I understood that. I was very hard on things, I was very heavy-handed, so I understood. I wasn’t offended. And I taught myself how to type.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: I empower other women to stay on track in Star Health Center. I’ve been with them since 1992 and I worked myself up getting knowledgeable with HIV and took trainings and so on, certificates throughout the years. What I do now is I empower others, let them know that they're not alone. And I can share and I can relate because I'm walking their shoes.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I didn’t really have too much of a childhood until I came up here when I was 10. When I was down South I was like a grownup person because I had to clean, it was very abusive, from place to place. My mother was here; she left me down South so I was like back and forth with my father’s people and then my mother’s people. But my father’s people was the best ones but my mother’s family we didn’t get to see that much, especially after my father had passed. He passed when I was very young. He the one that showed me love, we were very close.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: I was a replicator. I used to make releases for record companies. I had some medical papers and one of them disclosed that I was HIV positive. And this girl, she’s a big girl, she used to like to bully everybody. It was about her. And she saw those papers and she showed everybody. In years later she came to me and said you know what? I found out I was HIV positive too. So now I know what it feels like. But you don’t know what it feels like to have somebody do what you did to me.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: I was never a street worker, I never had to get out there like that. And when I did graduate from high school I went straight into start working. I always have had good jobs... I was doing good things but bad things at the same time. Basically all my jobs that I did have, they were good jobs. That’s how I lost them, because of the drugs, because I would be tired and call in—I can’t come today. And then in 1992 I was feeling like…I lost my mom in ‘99 but in ‘92 I was feeling, it was around the time when Magic Johnson got diagnosedand everyone was kind of running to the little neighborhood clinics.

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: I talked to anyone, you know, and I learned mainly from gay, gay men about this disease. What I did was I started working as a Certified Nurse Assistant, so mostly all my patients back then had AIDS. They had Kaposi’s sarcoma, you know. It was all kind of, it was a gay man’s disease back then. But what they didn't know was that I was diagnosed with HIV, they said AIDS. I was adhering to my medications. I took control of what I was supposed to do.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: I’m Latina. I was born in Indiana, we stayed mostly with my grandparents, we all stayed there, my grandfather and his brothers were the type that they built their own places and my mom met my dad there in Indiana and he was of Puerto Rican descent, so Mexican and Puerto Rican. I remember... well, it was nice having all family around—aunts, uncles, other cousins, coming to see grandma and grandpa. And then whenever grandpa wanted help out in the fields because he would do all that stuff, I remember as a young kid, he’d take whatever hands and feet were available to stand and pull, you know? We’d do all kinds of stuff out in the fields helping grandpa. And I thought it was exciting because they used to bring home live meals, take it to the garage and do what had to be done. I thought that was normal.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: It’s like the salmon, you know you’ve got to come back to it. And how odd that I say the salmon because my ma used to work at Cook County when we were young and we used to literally live down Harrison Street, by Harrison and Racine, made my communion, went to a school that’s no longer there, all of that there. And it’s weird that I end up working here and then being involved in [THE WIHS] study.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: When I first came here I had…my first job, I think I was 19. 19 years old….I was working on an assembly line up North. But I had a little problem there. I wouldn’t say it was my problem, but I think it was the other guy’s problem because he called me the N word....And I slapped his face and then I got fired. He wasn’t funny, he didn’t have the right to call me that in the first place. But I was called that word when I was in the South, but this was close to close. That boy’s like a six foot man, white man called me that. And I didn’t like it and I slapped his face and I got fired. But that was 40 years ago.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I was born in Brooklyn, NY and I moved to North Carolina maybe 23 years ago.  I'm 46 years old and I work for the Post Office.  My mom died and the person that I was infected from HIV, he died, and I just needed a different scene, I just needed to get away with my kids, and North Carolina was it, felt like a safer place to go.  I had nobody else to stay in New York for as far as my mom and my fiancée.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: Jack of all trades. The last 15 years I’ve worked in the school system in Prince Georges County in Maryland. I worked with special ed students and regular ed students. I did daycare, I’ve done cleaning; I’ve done just about anything that paid and paid the bills.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well, I got my love of sewing before I went there, because my mama always sewed, she sewed all of her clothes and I just take after her, I love a sewing machine. That’s where I learned to love to sew. When I got into the mills I found out I could use them machines to make about anything.

list.subject: FB
list.extract:
Tammy:....Did you ever run the streets? 
FB: No. 
Tammy: Dang! She shouldn’t be here….Do you know how you contracted HIV? 
FB Yes, I do. 
Jennie Do you want to tell us the story? 
FB My husband stayed in the streets, like I say I was working 10, 12, 16 hours a day in the factories. And he would run the roads. He was doing street drugs and this that and the other. Like I say, I never thought the first time, because he never told me he was out there for, just out getting drugs, but evidently he brought the big boy home. And I told him, I said – if you ever go back to prison, I'm leaving. So when he went back to prison I filed for divorce and left. And then I got to getting sick and it had to come from him.

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: Yes, my first job was at the housing authority in Durham, I was a clerk-typist there. I stayed there for three years and then I wanted to do something different and back then, working at Duke was the ideal thing to do. So I messed around, and went and applied to Duke and got on, and you couldn't tell me nothing – I was working at Duke! So, I had it going on!

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: Well, I haven’t told like a couple of people that I had in my life because a lot of people are naïve, they don’t know; right away they real quick to judge you. But I felt that they didn’t need to know because if you’re going to judge me, then you don’t need to know.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: At first I didn’t tell nobody, but when I was at the hospital I had a cousin coming to see me in the hospital and she kept telling me—oh, you know our cousin (because I had a cousin in the ‘80s who had died when the virus first came out, she had died); she came to see me in the hospital, she didn’t know what was wrong with me or nothing. She said—you know our cousin was right down the hall right here, down in that room. Anyway, she went and told everybody that I was sick with the virus.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I had a sister die, she had the virus; I had a niece die of the virus. The first one died was my cousin, that was in the early-‘80s. Then I had a sister die. But my sister, she died from other complications. She didn’t die from the virus. But my niece, she died from the virus because I guess when she got her results she didn’t let nobody know it, she was keeping it to herself. I think stress and the virus killed her. And I have a brother right now living with the virus.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: The first person I told was my youngest daughter. Even though she grown, the first person I told my youngest daughter because that was the day that I had took the test. I never forget, I was in Brookdale Hospital and I took her in the bathroom and I told her, I said — you know that they found out that I have the virus? — just like that. And I had started crying. She said —  Mommy, we’re going to get through this, we’re going to get through this.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I didn’t really deal with any stigmas when it came to HIV. I was very fortunate about that. Because I’ve heard some stories and I’m so glad I didn’t have to deal with that.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: When I told my kids that I had the virus it was really hard for me but I’d rather for me to be the one to tell them, because there’s a lot of mean people out there and I’d prefer maybe for my kids to hear it from me than to hear it from anybody else. Because then they going to start thinking, wow, why did I have to hear it from somebody else?

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I don’t know how to tell [D] because I’m...I don’t want him to think because you’re HIV you’re going to die. I had to correct a lady one time in a clinic because she said —  do you have AIDS? And I said no ma’am, I have the virus. Why did I get so mad? I had to recently see my doctor because I was getting scared because if I have an ear-ache, I’m already thinking...see I’m losing weight, a lot of weight and I asked her if I’m going downhill. And she said Cookie — your T-cell count is undetected, your viral load is sky high. You ain’t going to die from that. [VIRAL LOAD IS UNDETECTABLE AND YOUR T-CELLS ARE HIGH] She said so high, so it woke me up. I gotta get out of this funk. I really have to get out of it. I just take medication and now I’m drinking protein.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: The difference I’m trying to make is to realize that I am HIV. There’s a lot of things that you can do to lift up your spirit. I always take my medication like clockwork. Maybe not the same time because some-times I don’t eat during...but I take it every single day. And I want to be able to live with it. I really think I’ve been so in denial, that’s why I let my body go so bad. I just didn’t...but now I have that spunk, like somebody lit a fire under my butt because I really, really want to live. I’m not embarrassed anymore. I’ll go talk and speak, but I got to  learn also how to tell my 15-year-old and I don’t even think I want to. Because [D] feels I’m all he has. His mother’s his other mother; I’m his mom. I’m his light, his God, I’m everything to [D]. Little does he know that that’s what he means to me. And sometimes I feel like I should let him know, give him the awareness because every time I look at him...maybe in groups or something where there’s other children that he can meet, because one-on-one from me I wouldn’t want to just tell him, no. I want him to see that other kids are coping with their parents with it. But I still really, I don’t know about [D], I feel like I’ll hurt him.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: Well, drug use will lead to getting HIV if you don’t focus on protection. Because a person that’s getting high on drugs, won't think about – especially if she’s sleeping with someone that’s going to offer her drugs – she’s not going to think about using protection. Because I contracted this from my husband, I wasn’t out there, but I was out there after, so who knows who I infected? Who knows who I infected? Because there were times when I would sleep with guys that gave me money and you know, I did favors and I didn't think about protection, nor did I tell them I was positive.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: I disclosed to my grandchildren in Georgia. I disclosed to my daughters; I haven't disclosed to my grandchildren here because they're still young and they're in college, one of them, and one is on the way to high school. The other is graduating next week from junior high, so I don't want their feelings mixed up right now, because they love their grandma! I didn't tell my mother. She took it to the—I let her-- She died, I didn't tell my mother. But it feels like a good load is off your body, it’s like an energy that just left you because being HIV positive it’s like you are living with dumbbells inside, and it’s weighing you. You feel the weight. When you let go and you feel the courage to disclose, you feel this weight off your feet and you feel light.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: Thank God today I have been to groups and all kinds of educational programs, stuff like that. I learned so much about it. Yeah that is one thing, once I did find out about it, after a while, long about I’d say probably two years after I found out I think, I got myself together and I started pursuing to see what this HIV was about and how can I deal with it and live longer and that’s what I’ve been doing up until now. I just don’t feel like telling everybody about it right now, I’m comfortable myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die long as I take care of myself. It just means tak-ing better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life. Really if I look at it, you know, because I still would have been out there doing what I was doing probably, I don’t know. I’m a much better person now, stronger, confidence, just you know, ready to help whoever I can...I’m okay with it. It’s just letting people in.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I haven’t told a lot of people tell you the truth... because I don’t know, I just don’t want — I feel like they’ll look at me different or something. I don’t know, I’m just not ready to deal with it, certain people knowing. I just let my family, my brothers, my mom, like I said my partners, a couple of friends; that’s about it.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: I was a replicator. I used to make releases for record companies. I had some medical papers and one of them disclosed that I was HIV positive. And this girl, she’s a big girl, she used to like to bully everybody. It was about her. And she saw those papers and she showed everybody. In years later she came to me and said you know what? I found out I was HIV positive too. So now I know what it feels like. But you don’t know what it feels like to have somebody do what you did to me.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: Yes I have. Even with my mom...my mother she’s just – this is my house and I pay the bills and everything is her way. Even though she accepted the fact that I was positive, when I stopped working, mat-ter of fact that’s one of the excuses I used to leave Long Island and come back to the city. I notice when I used the bathroom, even  though I would clean up behind myself she would go spray the toilet.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: They test you in all these places but the thing about it that they never told me – there was one time that I got tested when I was in program and they gave me my diagnosis in a closed, in a sealed envelope. And I brought it home and then I couldn't read it, and I was scared to ask anybody to read it because then they would know if it was positive or not. I kept it, I held it, so then this one guy that I started going with, I finally got the nerve to ask him to read it and then when I went to get the letter…I couldn't find it. I don’t even know if I was positive then or not. But when I went to detox and I came back, that was in January, I was still in the methadone program but I stopped using everything else. And they offered the test again and I took it, and that’s when I found out, and that was in March of ’91.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: My support system is my family, my friends, a sponsor that I had, may she rest in peace, she taught me a lot of things. I didn’t tell her anything about the HIV because she was like—oh, you don’t have to disclose, you can if you want to but you’re not obligated to let anybody know. I was always at home, she always talked to me, we used to go out and have dinner. But we had our own one-to-one meeting and she said—you don’t have to be alone, you know? She said, whenever you need anything, call me, no matter what time it is, just call me. She said to get out, even if it’s by yourself, go to the park, walk in the park, go see a movie, if I don’t have anyone to go with, just go by yourself. You don’t need anyone to live your life, to enjoy yourself. Now I’m starting to practice that. Like yesterday I went to a concert, my daughter bought me a ticket for Mother’s Day for this concert, I had a great time by myself you know? [inaudible] It was great.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: Okay, when my daughter found out, it was one day because I was using, I started using really heavy when, after I became HIV. One day on the elevator and we were arguing you know? I said you know what? I hope I die, I’m HIV positive! I hope I die! And my daughter just sunk and fell on the floor, crying. Just seeing the way she reacted (crying) but after that she was in college so she learned a lot about HIV. So now it’s not an issue anymore, you know? She showed me DVDs about HIV and what it started from, the progress. And my younger son, he’s still, he’s in denial about it; he won’t talk about it. I won’t bother him with that now. Once I asked him and he said – mom please, I don’t want to talk about that. My oldest son, he’s okay with it. He did a lot of research on HIV, so they’re okay with it.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: The first person that I disclosed to was my mom. As soon as I found out I had HIV, they said they would do the test and they did it. When it came back that it was positive again, I called my mom and said, “Mom, guess what? I'm positive. You positive? What are you talking about? I said I'm HIV positive. Oh, okay. You just gotta take care of yourself, that’ll be the lifestyle that you live, you gotta take care of yourself you know? Try not to get sick. Because I had a brother that died of AIDS and now a lot of people are living, people aren't dying like they were back then.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: Still to today, my son went to his death and didn’t know that I’m HIV-positive. My other two children don’t know that I’m HIV-positive; my mother doesn’t know, no one knows. My brothers don’t know. And I lost two brothers from HIV. And I got one sitting right now in UIC that got sores all over him and everything else. He’s getting ready probably to pass…soon. But he doesn’t know I have HIV.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: Normally it’s just the people from WIHS that really know, okay. And my husband knew.... I live like, I don’t even know how to say, like ashamed of myself. I’m very clean, my house is immaculate, if I get cut I won’t let nobody help me, nobody even come near where I bled if it went on my floor. You see what I’m saying? My bathroom’s so immaculate you wouldn’t believe it.This is the way I am because of me having this HIV. And I’m so afraid. What happens if something happens and they catch it, how do I live with myself without telling my own children?

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: when you go to my sister’s house, my brothers would go there and she knew that they had it and she would throw their glasses away, their fork away, their plate away. ... You think I want to go to her house and my kids see her throw something in the trash?

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: [MY MOTHER] was like—well Sister (that’s my nickname, Sister) no use in keeping it a secret; it’s something you gotta live with now. You should just tell the rest of them, they’ll be understanding. And me knowing the type of family and sisters that I had, I knew that they would handle a problem, if anything they would be catering to me. I told them and that’s exactly what it was. They were catering to me, still ‘til today they—Sister, what’s your cell count? Because now they are more aware about it, especially with one of my sisters being a doctor. I’ve never been hospitalized before, I’ve never been sick, very seldom have a cold, my T-cell count always have been in the 800s, undetectable, even the herpes breakouts that I usually have on you know my bottom part, I don’t even have them that much more.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: I’m from Canada. My dad came to visit me for two weeks. And he told me, he said – there’s something about this guy is not right. I had a big rock on my finger, it was all good, you know! And he was a professor at Northwestern, and I went – yes! My ship has finally come in. But he lied to his family, he lied to me. And then people were calling me saying they were lawyers, we could sue his estate. I never did because it was too much of a stigma. The Evanston newspapers wanted to interview me, I didn’t want no one to know. But now it’s not a death sentence, and I don’t care who knows.

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: And so I fought, I went to the Core Center, they had a program set up for parenting skills. And so they said…I still got the certificate, you go there and get your certificate, then you take that to DCFS and then they know you working towards your goal to get your son back. And so when I used to go over to her house, my son’s foster mother house, I used to sit down, she would get the bleach and wipe whatever I touched. And so it went on like that, and then I think it was more she was being nasty towards me because she know she had to fight, because I had gotten start healing then, feeling better…I want my child back! And so we started going back and forth to court and what happened was I started getting visitation, everything. They had to let me participate in everything. And this went on for years. My son is 26 now, and he’s still back and forth with her.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Because most of the African-American churches, I don't know how it is now, but I knew then – you were ousted, people would cringe because they didn't know, understand it. You don’t get HIV from touching someone, you don’t get HIV from going to bathroom, you know? But I have heard a lot of people complain about you know they came out in church and then people felt differently of them. And so that’s when I stopped going to church.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: So one day at the beginning of the year of his fourth grade they were talking about hygiene and germs, what you can see, what you can’t, clean your hands, wash your hands, cover your mouth when you sneeze; so the question was—do you understand what viruses and germs are? And he was a smart one to say— yes I do, I have the virus that can cause AIDS. So with saying that, the teacher caught on but the kids weren’t really paying attention. And we didn’t have a phone and I had a note left in my mailbox to come down to the principal’s office. To the understanding from our nurse at clinic since he’s in a public school, it had to be reported to CPS downtown that there’s an HIV child enrolled in your school. They had to do that, they had to report it. And they had to keep things, how did they tell me…in a safe, secure place.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: The most pressing issues I faced was my drug addiction and finding out I was positive was…there were a couple of other personal issues that I faced. My drug addiction, I remember I went to the methadone clinic to try to get myself some treatment, and that didn’t work for me.
