I remember one day going to my mom’s house and I was just out of it, and I remember her telling me distinctly – I don’t know what kind of help you’re getting, what ever help you’re getting is worse than the stuff that you were on before you got the help. And that always stuck in my head.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: I had somebody close. It’s still hard to date, period. But that person know about my status. But it’s hard. I think that’s the biggest thing handling HIV dating. You might see somebody you want to date and you talk to him but you can’t go no further than that unless you tell him. And you have to be very careful with that, too.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I'm good, I have to get it together. You know I never told my story so I guess telling this story now is making me emotional because I never had an opportunity or I never wanted to share my story because of people and ignorance. People are still ignorant to this disease. It’s like they don’t understand, the world still doesn’t understand that I could live just as long as someone, or longer than someone, who has cancer because now the treatment, I'm able to live longer than someone else you know? And people still shun you, so it’s hard to want to come forward because of that. But I'm here.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: So I go to this dentist and he read my chart and he wouldn't come near me. As close as you're sitting to me, he was a little bit further away, and when it came time for him to look in my mouth he was kind of like hesitant to look. He didn't touch me at all. He just wouldn't come near me. And he said – I'm just going to give you the purple pill, this acid reflux. And I'm like – acid reflux, no it’s something else and I didn't know what it was, I didn't really know it was my tonsils, I thought my glands were swollen. He prescribed it and he never checked me over or anything, he just wanted to get away from me. I just felt small, I just felt isolated, felt really, really sad, and I didn't even get a follow-up appointment, I just left out of there…I kinda left out in tears.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: They do. I think everybody who knows me, knows (laughter). I'm very open with my status, though it was not always that way. When I first got diagnosed I kept it from my family for a long time. The first ones who knew in my family was my Dad. The day that I got diagnosed I told my Dad, I just didn't want to be by myself with it. It wasn’t, I didn't have embarrassment, it wasn’t that type of feeling, it was more fear if anything. I'm so open about my health and everything that I felt like it was something the family should know so they can be there to support you. I didn't tell my children for, I don't know, at least three years. So you know, that part was scary. My mom, my sisters, just that experience was, it was surprising because the responses were different than what I expected. So now everyone knows because I'm extremely outspoken. And I don't know, it’s okay, almost like it’s not there.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract:
We still married before things got bad because I felt like nobody would want to be with me, why would I be with anybody else? We're going to get married; he wants me, nobody else ever will want the woman living with HIV. So after the wedding is when he told me, through an argument, because I asked a lot of questions like – how did you contract this? Were you doing drugs, were you promiscuous, were you having sex with sex workers undercover, down low…what's going on? 
	The argument ended in – yes, I knew, I already knew I was positive and so what? Now what do you want to do because you already have it, there's nothing you can do.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: Not at all. And that’s the thing. People say HIV like that is the worst thing in the world to have. But if a doctor came in and said Angela, I have just diagnosed you with cancer, I would break down. I would rather them tell me I'm HIV positive then tell me that I have cancer. People look at this disease as the dirtiest, the wickedest, the nastiest thing to have in this world and it’s crazy. There's many idiots out here don’t understand what HIV and AIDS are.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well my family don't know, just not but two of them that do know. And they relate to me, they take care of me, my twin sister she knows and takes..watches out for me all the time. She still hasn’t told her husband, and he takes care of me just like I'm a child. My daughter, she’s all the time if there's something wrong she’ll take care of me. But they're the only ones that know right now.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: I felt dirty, I just felt…and I could never understand…what my problem is is trying to understand this whole situation is – you’ve got every kind of disease out there. But this disease, they want to blackball you from everything. That’s something I never understood. You can get herpes, gonorrhea, syphilis, all that stuff can kill you. But yet they're putting it on us…and why?

list.subject: FB
list.extract: My self-esteem before was good. I had a good job, a nicehome, but then after that it all went downhill....What most worries me about this here is I’ve seen so many people being hurt over this, just over the three letters. They don’t care that you got feelings. And just for my family to know, I really don't know how they would react to it. They might react the way you think they would, but I’ve head them talk you know? What I’ve heard, I remember somebody and this boy had it and by that time I had it and they said – that boy’s got HIV. And said we're going to stay away from him, don’t get anything from rubbing up on him, this that and the other…I got thinking to myself, that’s the way they're going to treat me. And I seen this boy, and I said – don’t you think that this time he needs a friend? He don’t need everybody running away from him you know? I sit down and when I realized what I did have, I sit down and kind of looked it up to see what was going on.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: the only part of my family that knows that I have HIV are two of my three children. My mother and father are both deceased and I have four siblings, or had four. One died in the past few years, but it’s been since I’ve been HIV positive. I’ve chosen not to tell any of my siblings because I grew up in a very religious family and they're all quite religious and I do believe that they would be more judgmental than they would be supportive.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My daughter got a hold of my diary…my therapy since I was old enough to write has been to write my thoughts down on a piece of paper in a notebook, my mama taught me that, she did the day she died. So I write my thoughts down. I was living with my daughter when my husband died, I had nowhere to go; I lost my home, I lost the vehicles, I lost everything in my home down to my clothes. Me and my dog is all I have. So I’ve been living with her for almost two years; April the 1st of this year I moved in my own place. She, being nosy or whatever, she read my diary. And in my diary it said I’d been diagnosed since 2000 with hepatitis C, nothing about HIV. She treats me like I am a disease. She’ll hug me, she’ll kiss me right here. There’s the grandkids come and stay with me, and I cook. If I have something left over and they're still hungry on my plate and I offer to put it on their plate, she has a fit! To where – now you know that’s unacceptable! They can't eat after you and they can’t drink after you! I said – why not? “You know why!” “No I don’t, please tell me why!” I want her to come out and tell me that she knows. But I'm thinking that she knows it’s hepatitis C, when everybody, all my friends and my doctors and case managers tell me that they believe that she knows I have HIV.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I know my middle son would, because he’s made comments like you’ve heard. So-and-so, who’s that guy that plays on Two And A Half Men?  Charlie Sheen?  He’s HIV positive.  My son had a cookout one night – dude, did you know that Charlie Sheen’s HIV?  My God, what are we going to do?  We need to take people like that, put them all on a boat and send them away.  I'm going oh hell no, I’m not fixing to go through this right here, it’s just not worth it to me, for me not being able to see my grandbabies.  It’s just me and my care providers and what few women I’ve met today and at the clinic that know that I am.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My husband died I said – Lord, okay, I got HIV so you know there ain't going to be no more men. First of all I'm too old to learn somebody else. And I don't want to say – I have HIV, is that going to be a problem? Because I don't want nobody to know. So therefore I'm not going to be in a relationship no more. So being alone is my (crying) biggest, biggest thing. I have to take care of my self now... I really would like (crying) to be in another relationship, I don't want to die alone. But if that don’t happen, just having friends. Me and you go to the movies, we’ll meet and go to the show, just being able to get out; I don’t get out. I ain't got no car, my daddy’s fixin’ to buy me a car and I know what that’s going to cost, that’s going to be some problems. And I know it but I'm not going to tell him not to do it.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I wished I could be like some of the ladies I’ve met that can be out and say – I'm HIV positive but I'm living. I can't do it.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: They gave me an HIV test without my consent, and I know it’s because I bit that nurse. When they came back to the room later on they said – Miss Wanda, did you know you was HIV positive? What! And immediately I thought you all did something, they did something to me, they nailed me because I bit that nurse, they done shot me up with some HIV (laughter), somebody else’s blood. Girl, I thought that for the longest time! Yes. And then, but I remember I had a friend back home up in Maryland that used to go mess with this girl who died from AIDS, and we had sexual encounters, but he’s walking around like nothing never happened. And he’s still trying to hook up with me today! Like he don't know. I'm more than sure that’s where I got it from, but I never let on to him that I have this and I think you got it and you need to go get it checked out…I never said a word to this day? I'm good with it, but then I'm not.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: I have long distance friends. I have friends up in Maryland, crazy (laughter), outgoing, you know, they're cool. And my family my family are my friends, me and my family we close, we’re going to stay that way because I would never disclose my status to them because I don't want anything to change. I’m not taking that chance. Anybody have anything to say about it, so be it.

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: Well, I haven’t told like a couple of people that I had in my life because a lot of people are naïve, they don’t know; right away they real quick to judge you. But I felt that they didn’t need to know because if you’re going to judge me, then you don’t need to know.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: The first person I told was my youngest daughter. Even though she grown, the first person I told my youngest daughter because that was the day that I had took the test. I never forget, I was in Brookdale Hospital and I took her in the bathroom and I told her, I said — you know that they found out that I have the virus? — just like that. And I had started crying. She said —  Mommy, we’re going to get through this, we’re going to get through this.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I just want my family. They’re all I have. I’m blessed to have Carmen as a friend but ... you need your family, especially with your siblings when your mom passed away at a young age.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: I empower other women to stay on track in Star Health Center. I’ve been with them since 1992 and I worked myself up getting knowledgeable with HIV and took trainings and so on, certificates throughout the years. What I do now is I empower others, let them know that they're not alone. And I can share and I can relate because I'm walking their shoes.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: My mother has always been an active person, she’s always had a sense of community and responsibility when that’s something she kind of instilled in us as children. And then we later on took up the torch so to speak, because your community is only going to be as good as you help to make it, period point blank. That’s that. That’s what I learned.

list.subject: Loretta
list.extract: I love the Lord and I’m a child of God. And I know that all that I’m going through and experiencing, it’s only a matter of time. And I’m sitting here talking about I’m scared of this and scared of that and I shouldn’t be a coward, just hit me with something...when she says she’s not afraid. My grandmother tell me that all the time. What you scared of girl? You shouldn’t be scared.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: …you know being on public assistance you didn't get a lot of money for rent, and so I always had to—I used to have to sell my food stamps to get enough money to pay my rent. It was always a problem with having enough money. I lived in East Flatbush, a lot of apartments there were high, you know, the rent was high. Anywhere I went I never had enough money to pay the rent, so I wind up moving in with my mom and then I put in applications for city housing. That’s when I moved to Brownsville with my daughters when I got accepted for housing.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: My support system is my family, my friends, a sponsor that I had, may she rest in peace, she taught me a lot of things. I didn’t tell her anything about the HIV because she was like—oh, you don’t have to disclose, you can if you want to but you’re not obligated to let anybody know. I was always at home, she always talked to me, we used to go out and have dinner. But we had our own one-to-one meeting and she said—you don’t have to be alone, you know? She said, whenever you need anything, call me, no matter what time it is, just call me. She said to get out, even if it’s by yourself, go to the park, walk in the park, go see a movie, if I don’t have anyone to go with, just go by yourself. You don’t need anyone to live your life, to enjoy yourself. Now I’m starting to practice that. Like yesterday I went to a concert, my daughter bought me a ticket for Mother’s Day for this concert, I had a great time by myself you know? [inaudible] It was great.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: I’m like okay, I got to questioning my faith and like okay, you been to church all these years, apparently you’ve got all this or whatever and so you still around for something. I started doing a little bit of research, I’m real good with computers and I started doing a little bit of research, and I heard about the Radiation Center, which was, they had a women’s group in there, a women’s support group. So I started going to the women’s support group at Cook County Hospital, okay?

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: Dr. Mardge Cohen, who of course you know is the initiator of all of this Core Center being in existence and all of that. And we used to sit in that Radiation Center before they actually built the Core Center, we’d sit in that Radiation Center, it would hot as a firecracker in there because there wasn’t no air conditioner so we’d have a fan on and we sitting skin to skin sweating and we just be talking but it was just one big family you know?

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I did my volunteer work, I did the MATEC training you know. Because nobody wanted to be with the AIDS patients in Cook County Hospital. So what’d they do? They trained the AIDS patients to go sit with the AIDS patients. Because we knew that there’s nothing, we knew we needed comfort, so we took these classes and we went and comforted our people.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I never forget, I walked up one day and there was this guy, he just had the sheet wrapped around him and he was just rocking. He was like – I’ve been here for five days, nobody’s talked to me, they barely want to touch me. I'm like – we can talk, I'm here, I ain't going nowhere. And for me, that was my epiphany. To see him just wrapped up, just waiting to die. Because the nurses only came when they had to. So from that point on I started running my mouth and talking and…

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: Northwestern started a women’s group for women over the age of 40. With HIV…oh, this smells so good. And, um, I started going twice a month to the women’s group, and we would have an evening dinner and it was informal. We would just talk about what’s bothering us, what’s on our mind, things like when we were first diagnosed you would get up 50 times a night and make sure your door was locked. And I’ve learned through my yoga and meditation, to just let it go, like Frozen.

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Yes, I started seeking counseling [about the molestation]. And then like I said, I started going to groups. I found out that other people had worse issues than I did, you know! It didn't make me feel good but it helped to know that I wasn’t out there alone. And then some of these things that suppressed me or made me very depressed, it can happen to anybody, it can happen to the best of people.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: [MY SON HAS] given me two more grandchildren and they’re fine and his wife is still fine. It goes on like that. Yes, little close encounters like that kind of wake you up. Once all the drugging and the alcohol, I finally got rid of all of that, you know WIHS and the clinic and the people you meet, you learn something from people everyday.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: Seeing when I first walked in the door it was just unbelievable because you saw people from all walks of life, the ones who was living on the streets, the ones who prostituting, the ones who was shooting up, and you're looking at – hmm, what am I doing here, I do not fit in. And the ones who work the streets. And as I got to doing and talking to the ladies I found out that I really wasn’t a whole lot different from them, even though my lifestyle was different. We’re all women and we all were affected.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: I’ve met a lot of women who I have a lot in common with. It don’t matter where we’re from. It don’t matter if you were born on the South side, the North side, Cicero, whatever. We all have a lot in common. From the beginning to probably how a lot of us were raised or we ended up recently. And how we deal with what’s going on with us. It saddens me when I think of women that their families aren’t supportive. Because I’ve been blessed since I’ve been sick, my family has been great to me.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: And my brother. I miss him dearly. He was my hero. Back in 1997, I was doing the drugs, I was smoking the crack, I was stealing the money, I was rotten, I’m not bragging, I was rotten, I’m not lying either, that’s part of recovery. I was rotten and he rode me and he rode me and he said get out of my F’N house you Mother F’R monster, I want my sister back. When I straightened out, a year and a half later, he said – welcome back. He’s always been…he was there. I gave that poor kid a run for his money and he rode me and he straightened me…you want to do drugs, then you don’t want to eat. You want to steal money? Get out of here. You don’t need to eat. Goodbye.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh, my prayers, I made this prayer when I got clean. I said –God, if I ever use any illegal drugs I want you to take me out right now (laughter) because that was the worst two-year stint of my life. It was only two years but it was the worse. I think living with HIV was better than being on drugs...Um, drugs control your mind. They control your mind, your character, it control your moods, it controls everything. Your bank account, it controls you…your whole ability to thinking. And I had no control over my life for those two years. It was like – I was losing me. And really and truly HIV was an easier task than being on drugs. If I didn't have my mom I probably would still be out there, really in a bad situation in the streets. I never got to the point of doing things for drugs because I had family that tried that kept me off the streets, or tried to keep me off the streets. So I was good on that level but (sigh) I still did a lot of things that I'm not proud of back then, yes.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: No. Actually when I first got my results my younger brother came with me. And back in those days it was a death sentence so it took him to get my mind right, I mean really. Back then it was just coming out and to find out that you were HIV positive meant that you would be dead in a month or two. So my brother was there with me and he was very supportive...In 1989, 1990, yeah something around there...(sigh) It was the beginning to an end, that’s what I thought. It was like okay, I have two kids, my mom is sickly, what am I going to do? In my mind I was like oh my God I'm dying. And then I had no God at that time, I wasn’t into church, so to me I had nothing to turn to but my kids. I wanted to live for them. Everything around me wanted to be alive for them. (tears)

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: That’s another reason why I advocate, because there are people who are not like that. There are women who won't speak up for themselves; not because they don't want to, because they can't. They don't know what to say, how to say it. So they need somebody there for them. I don’t mind being that person. I had to do it for myself, although I had support to encourage me and empower me to do it for myself. Now it’s a no-brainer for me, I just automatically do it. So when I made that decision to take the medication I even remember sitting on the edge of my sofa, holding this pill and looking at it and I'm like – hmm, when I swallow you it’s going to be for the rest of my life.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: I'm grateful for…I wouldn't change the diagnosis. People say would you go back? Go back for what? There’s too much to go back to. Honestly I’ve met more people, I’ve been able to do a whole lot as an advocate and a woman living with HIV. I’ve been able to help other women, connect with other women, network with other women, come up with ideas so we can help make an impact on our community and dispel myths and stop stigmas. It’s just been great. Even doing the research studies, I always say yes, I never say no. There are a lot of people who are afraid of research, even if it is questioning. Because just fear, lack of knowing, years ago it was always said – what goes on in the house stays in the house, don’t tell people your business. But a lot of these things help other people and that’s what I'm about, helping other people. If I have to be a part of it, I care. That’s it because I’ll keep talking (laughter).

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: I would love to hit the Power Ball so I could help people that are living with this disease; help the homeless; help the children; help the people that are abused. I just want to help. Prayer helps, but you need financial. I'm ready to hit that Power Ball so I can really get out here and help.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: The only reason I started taking the medication was I got a case of shingles and the Complera that was prescribed to me got rid of the shingles. So it was good and bad. Good it got rid of the shingles but bad because then I kind of sunk in that I have HIV. As long as I didn't have to take the medication I was like – okay. I don’t have it. It’s just in my body. But when I had to start taking medication, it was a different feeling...I sure do! I was on my way to Miss Kitty’s funeral and I had that pill in my hand and was talking with my older play sister Violet and was like – man, I got to take this pilgrimage. I was crying. I don't want to take this pill, I don't want to have to do this the rest of my life. Why I got to go through it? And that was kind of a Debbie Downer moment. But I got over it real quick.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well my family don't know, just not but two of them that do know. And they relate to me, they take care of me, my twin sister she knows and takes..watches out for me all the time. She still hasn’t told her husband, and he takes care of me just like I'm a child. My daughter, she’s all the time if there's something wrong she’ll take care of me. But they're the only ones that know right now.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well there was a time…When I first realized what I had, I didn't want to get better. I did not want to get better, but I knew my son was trying to have a child and I asked God – if said you just let me live long enough to see my grandbaby, then whatever comes, comes. And that helped me get through a lot of it. And my sisters kept telling me – you can do this, you can do this. I was like everybody else; I was dumb. I thought it was a death sentence. When I got to working with Dr. Kozel and everything, she would talk to me and she didn't think I was going to make it, but she kept my hopes up. So I had to pull myself out of that to be able to make myself go on. And my sisters would come over and help me and make sure I had my medicine because like I said, I couldn't remember nothing; I couldn't remember when to take medicine, what day, what it looked like.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: My self-esteem before was good. I had a good job, a nicehome, but then after that it all went downhill....What most worries me about this here is I’ve seen so many people being hurt over this, just over the three letters. They don’t care that you got feelings. And just for my family to know, I really don't know how they would react to it. They might react the way you think they would, but I’ve head them talk you know? What I’ve heard, I remember somebody and this boy had it and by that time I had it and they said – that boy’s got HIV. And said we're going to stay away from him, don’t get anything from rubbing up on him, this that and the other…I got thinking to myself, that’s the way they're going to treat me. And I seen this boy, and I said – don’t you think that this time he needs a friend? He don’t need everybody running away from him you know? I sit down and when I realized what I did have, I sit down and kind of looked it up to see what was going on.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Because I'm ready to kick ass, somebody jumps in my face. I'm ready to fight. But I keep myself quiet and to myself. I don’t have as many friends as I used to have, I don’t associate with nobody, and the only ones I ever see is my family which I should get out and associate more but I don’t.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: I guess HIV is still (having happened to me) is still a meaningful experience in that basically it kind of just having to deal with it, again you're going to learn a lot about yourself, a lot about the people around you, who’s really for you and who’s really not. Really if you're going to take care of yourself, I thought I was resourceful and knew a lot about survival, but yes, to a whole other level have I had to learn about survival and resourcefulness from having HIV just in terms of being a working person without health insurance and making too much for Ryan White or ADAT and having to find medication, things like that.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: So, there was that, and then when I got to this study, the people here are so great, you never feel judged. It’s like a warm, fuzzy, sunshiny place to come to for me. You always feel, you know, they always make you feel like a person (crying)... And they don't want anything from you (crying)… So it’s not like they're charging you to make you feel like a person (crying). And you know they provide a lot of needed things, in my case of course it was the physicals and pap smears, but you know, moral support, helping to make sure that I don’t fall into the cracks, which I normally would have done by now in this situation. And there was a time where I was like…I couldn't get the medication because I made too much money (crying) but I didn't have insurance. And I was too depressed to care! (crying)

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: Or not even that but because well I guess maybe I’ve learned how to hide it so long and put the game face on that everybody, that nobody sees the vulnerability (crying) and I get tired. Having to put your game face on all the time…it’s tiring. It’s exhausting really. But you know how people ask – how’re you doing? And we all know it’s a rhetorical question in the first place. And you get, especially older people they say – oh, I can't complain. If I did, ain't nobody listening anyway or nobody cares anyway. And that’s pretty much how it is. So that’s why I put my game face on because I don’t have energy to expend on…that I said hi and smiled and they didn't say hi back (laughter). I don’t have energy for that. I just have just enough energy to get through whatever. I’d say, people would describe me as confident, so I’ll agree with that because I'm confident in the sense that despite my deficits, if could dig my way out from under a couple of them like the fog…from I don't know if it’s menopausal fog or if it’s from the depression or the medication hell, I don't know. But if I could dig my way out of this damn fog, I could probably do some stuff! So, I would say I'm confident, I would agree with that.I would say that I don't know, I would say I love myself only because I know technically I really don’t have self-esteem issues, but then again there are days where I just don’t care whether I live or die, and it’s not because I hate myself or because I feel that I don’t deserve to live (crying) but just because I'm tired. I'm just tired.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: I still manage, and again I don't know how, I can't count anymore the number of people who have come to me and said – you know, I wouldn't have ever done X, Y, or Z if it hadn’t been for you (crying). And that’s encouraging because then it makes me like I still have a purpose for being here. But I just like wish that…I wish I had a more concrete idea of what that purpose was and what I'm actually doing to fulfill that purpose. I guess right now that makes me foggy (laughter). That would be how I describe myself right now – foggy. That’s it

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My husband died I said – Lord, okay, I got HIV so you know there ain't going to be no more men. First of all I'm too old to learn somebody else. And I don't want to say – I have HIV, is that going to be a problem? Because I don't want nobody to know. So therefore I'm not going to be in a relationship no more. So being alone is my (crying) biggest, biggest thing. I have to take care of my self now... I really would like (crying) to be in another relationship, I don't want to die alone. But if that don’t happen, just having friends. Me and you go to the movies, we’ll meet and go to the show, just being able to get out; I don’t get out. I ain't got no car, my daddy’s fixin’ to buy me a car and I know what that’s going to cost, that’s going to be some problems. And I know it but I'm not going to tell him not to do it.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: My life has been really, really just ripped apart but I know God don’t make no mistakes on what he doing but…he put so much on you that sometime you just can't take it (crying). And so you figure if you just get high, you get drunk or whatever it’ll go away – but it don’t. (crying) You just put it down deep inside your body and then when you have to talk about it and help somebody else, it’s painful.

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: The WIHS Study is one of them [support systems]. Also there's another group that I'm with at CARE, Inc. called the PAW Group, which stands for Positive Active Women (Wanda: where is that?) in Durham. (Wanda: Ya’ll got everything in Durham) It’s a support group of women who have, well, you don’t have to have HIV to be in, but a lot of the women in that group are HIV positive. The ‘Positive’ doesn’t mean that you're positive for HIV, it’s just that you're doing positive things in your life

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I like to, if I find out about a female that might be positive and doesn’t know about…I try to share with her the fact that there's some support groups and places you can go to get some help if you're having a hard time dealing with the fact that you found out you were HIV positive. Because it’s not a death sentence; there's help

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: they have a lot of help in Durham for people with or without HIV, I’m just saying. I know enough people to be able to find out about studies and pretty much anything I need to know I’ll research it and I know people I can call and they tell me about studies where I can make some extra money. When they tell me, I let somebody else know. I don’t keep it to myself, you know what I'm saying? Help. Each one, teach one. That’s right.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: Well now I'm a really a homebody, I don’t do much, I don't know many people here, I came from up north, I came down here in 2009. Off and on with my daughter, I go home, I come back, I go home and come back. And they move around so much within these few years. So, I haven't really settled in no place for a long time. Not that I want many friends because to me it’s just trouble. I don’t go anywhere, I don’t club…I babysit whenever they need me and I just stay close to the house. But I know we going to get to this, but my main concern now is I want my space. I want my space. I want to be free and freedom to me means having my own place, my own space again. I need that. I feel like I'm suffocating you know?

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: I have long distance friends. I have friends up in Maryland, crazy (laughter), outgoing, you know, they're cool. And my family my family are my friends, me and my family we close, we’re going to stay that way because I would never disclose my status to them because I don't want anything to change. I’m not taking that chance. Anybody have anything to say about it, so be it.

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: I couldn’t speak to my mom because my mom was the type of per-son that if you would tell her something she wouldn’t believe you, but I told my brother about the bullying. My brother, the only thing he told me — oh well if you don’t man-up, I’m going to have to go to school. And you don’t want me to go to school; so I had to do what I had to do. She came, she tried to take my lunch money, so I beat her down.

list.subject: Carmen
list.extract: My mom was really strict, I couldn’t put on makeup to go to school, I had to wear my little pleated skirts with shorts underneath because I didn’t know how to sit down because I was always used to wearing pants, but I had to wear my skirt to go to school and you know my blouse and my black and white shoes.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I didn’t like to go to school because when I need help I did not used to ask for help and stuff. I used to stay inside myself. How do you say that? Even though the teachers used to say when you need help, I didn’t know how to express myself, I’ll put it that way. Instead of asking for help I used to keep it to myself. I used to fight a lot in school.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: Because of my rebellious attitude and things like that, my mother and I have always been in conflict. And the older I got, the worse it  got. When I was younger my mother said she couldn’t understand why her and I didn’t stay close because she didn’t go back to work, she stayed home with me the longest. She didn’t go back to work until I was actually in school. When I was about four years old I went to pre-K and that’s when she went back to work; with every-body else she went back to work before then. I don’t know, I guess I just was the type of person I liked to do what I wanted to do and didn’t really care about the consequences of the things that I did because some things I did, I knew I was going to get punished for it. ‘Okay, and...? I mean, You’re not going to kill me for it, so I’ll be alright.’

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I was born at Union Hospital in Brooklyn, I’ve lived in Brooklyn pretty much my whole life. I made some different stops in between. I was raised in a house with my two sisters, my mom and my dad until I was about eight years old. That’s when my parents divorced. A year later my mother had my brother by someone else. I was raised a Jehovah’s Witness, so things were kind of strict in my house but I was the rebel (laughter). Yeah, I was always the rebel.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I’ve had issues with my weight my whole life, and that didn’t help my relationship with my mother either, because she focused on my weight more than anybody. She never made me feel good about me as I was. She destroyed, she destroyed my self-esteem, I can honest-ly say that. Because when you’re eight years old and all your mother does is talk about how fat you are and how you can’t eat this and eat that da-da-da-da-dah that’s rough for an eight-year-old you know?

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: The thing is, I was kind of like the tomboy of the group because of the fact that I watched all sports. I could sit with the fellas and talk sports all day long and everybody’s like—oh my goodness. And you know what you’re talking about! Because my mother brought me home from the hospital and my father was watching a game, he sat me in his lap and I sat there and watched the whole game with him. I didn’t fall asleep. I did not fall asleep. I’m three days old, I did not fall asleep, I’m just leaning on my dad, looking at the TV. And I’ve been watching sports ever since. I am a football fanatic, I love football. I even played football, that’s how much I loved football, the only girl on the football team but that was fine with me. So I wasn’t a typical girl. I had my moments when I wanted to be girly-girly and everything like that, but because I couldn’t stand just sitting around, just talking about people, that’s not who I am, that’s never who I’ve been. And that’s what most of the girls in the neighborhood did. I don’t do that. So I’m not even going to be bothered with y’all right now. So I was always hanging out with the guys, so people automati-cally assumed because I’m hanging out with the guys...I’m screw-ing the guys. Whatever! You say whatever you want! I know it’s the truth.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I was a clerk/typist for a medical malpractice law firm. That was like the first real job I ever had and I was part-time, I started out as part time and kind of pushed myself into full-time because what they needed me to do, it was a lot that needed to be done. So I was supposed to be at work at 1 o’clock; I would show up at 12. I would show up at 11. Then at 9, then at 8. So, you know. And I would do the work, and I was good at it. And then when the work cut down to a manageable point, I was able to, I went to my boss — can y’all teach me to do other things? So that’s when I started to do the mail, do the filing, and things like that. I was an exceptional typist. I’m 19 years old, my very first job, and I can type 85 words a minute. Because when I was eight, seven or eight, my father bought my sister an electric typewriter and I wanted to learn how to type. My mother had a manual typewriter, one of those old manual typewriters. She had a typing book, so I took her book and her typewriter because I wasn’t allowed to use my sister’s electric and I understood that. I was very hard on things, I was very heavy-handed, so I understood. I wasn’t offended. And I taught myself how to type.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I was born in ’61, I was born in the Bronx, East Tremont with my mom and five siblings, four girls and a boy. My dad was there on the weekends. A nice neighborhood, everybody got along with every-body, all the parents took care of everybody else’s children. I had a good childhood.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: You know back in the day, Spanish people took a lot from men. A lot of abuse and they got used to it. I grew up seeing my neighbors every weekend with shades on. And I already knew why. That’s why I became very strong. I would not let no man rule me. None of that, because I saw it as I was growing up. He was a good dad but he wasn’t a good husband at all.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: They have these house parties, you know the Puerto Rican house parties every week with the record player that you put on the…and starting Friday my mom and my stepfather would start drinking beer and whiskey and whatever and then they would go next door to Anna’s house, and they started to party and party and party. And this is where I touch alcoholism. As an 11-year-old my mom and my stepfather were dancing and I'm tasting the beer. And then they would come back – beer’s empty? Don’t touch my beer. And this is how some children actually you can connect to alcohol because their parents are not watching them.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: My mother only had two children, my brother and I, and my mother worked very hard. She fell in love with a younger man, and this younger man had eyes for me. There were times where he would try to rub his body on me and I would tell my mom, when I was doing dishes; she didn’t believe me. I grew up with a lot of seeing him beat my mother, hit my mother to a pulp where the eyes would get so swollen and she couldn’t see the next day, she went blind for 24 hours. And so I saw a lot of…it was happy when mom was around but in the evening time, especially on weekends, there was the fighting and the drinking and me hiding under the bed. It was something that once in a while I endure, I pick it up and I think about it and I let it go.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: My brother was in the Army. My mother had 19 kids; she had 17 miscarriages; I’m the 13th child and the first one to be born. And my brother was the 15th child and the second to be born. I guess that’s why my mother did drink because of all the miscarriages, los-ing a lot of children. I had spinal meningitis; my brother has pneu-monia; a priest gave us both our last rites. By the grace of God we’re still here.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: I was born August 20, 1955 in Brooklyn, I was born and raised in Brooklyn. I was born the same day as my sister, she’s three years older than me. I have two other siblings, all girls. I'm the next to the baby. I grew up in the projects in Brooklyn, Cooper projects in Greepoint, in a strict household. My mom was a Jehovah’s Witness but my dad wasn’t (laughter). So we had-- It was…I didn't really know my dad. He was in jail when I was like nine months old and I think he came back when I was about five. I don't remember him when I was young, I don't know why I just don’t.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: The projects, it was a lot of families like ours, so I had a lot of friends. The neighborhood was nice, we had green grass and parks, the big park, then we had little parks with barrels and monkey bars and stuff to play on. It was safe and we always was able to go outside by ourselves, my older sister would take us to the library, to the store, to the park, to wherever. My mom always worked.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: My first child was when I ran away at 15 and got married in Kentucky because I left home. And I thought—Oh, I’m going to live a good life! That was bull because I got beat up and all that by my husband and we ended up divorcing.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: My mother died when I was 10, or 13, I'm sorry. But before 10 I was molested, so losing that innocence, not really seeing who I am or not even knowing who I am, knowing that this is not the norm. I would tell my mom oh, stay away from him. How can I stay away from him when you gone all the time? Let me leave with you, then I’d be away from him. But losing the innocence and really like nobody to save me in a sense, even though my mother was there but she really wasn’t there, she didn't protect me. And I hear him say oh, mama did this, mama was this…mama didn't protect me. You remember mama making biscuits…oh yes, I remember all that stuff. But I don’t remember her protecting me. If they went to jail for doing something bad, her older brothers, she was down there getting them out, I can remember that. But as protecting me…she didn't do that. I didn't hate her, I just like – you remember that? I don't remember that! I can't remember any good days as far as her protecting me and saying it’s gonna be okay and I'm going to stop this. She’d just say – stay away from him! So I'm like, when I have my kids this ain't gonna happen. But how do I know if they don’t tell you. But I told her and she didn't protect me so…that’s where it’s at.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Going through, coming up in school, I went to a school that was mixed, so I didn't see color. I knew people were different but it wasn’t like – oh you're white, I can't be with you. Oh you're Asian I can't be with you. I just wanted to be cool with everybody until as a kid, you see that there are differences because you get older people who are showing you that prejudice and trying to teach you that prejudice. I didn't have a difference between races until I was like in the second grade, having a best friend who was white and got invited to her house and when I went, her dad was like – what are you doing here (when he opened the door). I'm like – I'm here for the taco party! “We don’t allow niggers”...I'm a kid and I'm just like –what the what! I knew that word from watching Roots andthings like that, but never experienced it. She’s behind him and she’s sad and her little sister, they called me ‘Alicia’ and she’s like –let Aliciain, let Aliciain. My friend’s name was [M] and her sister’s name was[R] . He would not let me in and I ran home crying and my Mom went around there, I don't know what my crazy Mom did or said (laughter). She laughs because I call her that because my Mom really took up for us. All parents normally do, butif I got into a situation, my Mom always sent me away and she handled it, and I don't know what my crazy Mother did but all Iknow is after I saw [M] again I wasn’t allowed to speak to her. Her parents, if they saw me coming they would pull her away. She would just be looking like –oh, I can't talk to you. We’d be in school and we couldn't talk. It was just bad

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Well, unfortunately fighting this girl brought up a lot of anger for me at home, and I didn't mean to but I beat the poor girl so bad and I had my sisters to protect. They were Kindergarteners and during that time at school I was told – you fight her then we're going to beat you up. If you don’t fight her we're going to beat you up. If you win, we're going to beat you up; if you lose we're going to beat you up. And you know back then it was like everybody hear about a fight, everybody’s there. So it was like crowds of people, some of the girls who were the bullies, they had pipes in their bags, homemade knives, so I'm scared like – oh my gosh I'm looking at my little sisters and seeing my Mom’s face. If I don’t get them home safely, forget all these people, Mom is going to kill me.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: In DC? Well at five years old I was abused, I was sexually abused from the age of five to about 11 or 12. That part wasn’t nice but there was some good times growing up in DC, back in the day, nothing like it is now. Playing different games – hopscotch, kickball at different schools, just doing kid stuff. It was really fun.

list.subject: Claristine
list.extract: after the molestation, well during the molestation, me and my mom was always close, but after I told her that he was molesting me, she just didn't want to believe it. She kept him in the house. So I knew sooner or later he was going to try to have sex with me; I knew I had to get outta there, because I did not want to be pregnant by my father...

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: Let's see, we lived in New York until I was eight years old. In New York, I just remember that there were all different kinds of people – you know, Hispanics, Jews, everybody all there together – I don't remember there being racism and people calling you out on your name, because of your color or because of the language that you spoke or anything like that.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: So, when I was 11 I went to visit my sister in Maysville, which is near Jacksonville, NC and her husband was from there and her husband’s cousin molested me. So he tried to penetrate me but I was like – stop, get off me! Whatever. And he was like shhh, put his hand over my mouth to shush me. Then he did get off me because I was making up too big of a fuss. And then I was like – I'm going to tell. He said – if you do, they're just going to think you did it. They're going to blame you, and I believed that. I remember when I first saw the Lion King, and I was 26 years old when I first saw the Lion King, I remember when Scar told Simba that it was his fault that his dad died trying to save him (crying) and Simba believed him and he ran away and he left. And I remember thinking to myself, that took me back to that moment and that was the first time that I really realized that there had been bad things that had been done to me…when I was 11 years old.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I think I had a pretty good childhood. There was no man in the house. My grandmother raised us; she was like the mother. She did the cooking and the cleaning and the watching us. My mama was the man; she went out and did all the work. And so it was me, my two sisters, my mom, and my grandmother. Oh Lord, mama did everything. Mama could tear down a car good as a man could; she waitressed; she worked like at …what’s that word I’m looking for, like Caterpillar, what are they

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: I had a great childhood, I can't complain about my childhood. My mama kept me active in Girl Scouts, I was a Daisy. I went to the cadet and I could have had my own little Girl Scout unit. I just did a lot of stuff. They taught me how to sail, how to camp, ski, climb rocks or mountains or whatever; I had a real good childhood, really great.

list.subject: Velvet
list.extract: Few Gardens was rough, it was rough. But we had great times there, we could live, we could stay in our grandmother’s house, we could spend the night, sleep outside in the front yard on a pallet with a little small black and white television in the window and the front door and back doors opened, the windows up, and nobody would go in, come in the house, nobody would bother us, those were the good days. If you could ever sleep on a pallet in the front yard with a television in the window and it’s just like you're in a drive-in movie, you know? We’d sleep out there, oh wow, that was some of the best sleep that we had. The grandchildren just on a pallet, just right there bunched up, just like sardines in a can but we slept good, legs and arms all over each other. It was no problem.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: Like before I was diagnosed, I say the same thing now, that I never really was happy with myself — I wasn’t happy with myself and I didn’t know why. I was existing but not living. I was existing, I was not living. I remember after I suffered two months I was in my house, so I was diagnosed and went in the hospital and like a breeze came to me and told me that I’m going to borrow you for a minute. When I was in the hospital for that month, it was like I was in the hospital to introduce me to me. To connect with me, to find myself, to find myself, to rest and find myself. And my accomplish now is the relationship that I have with myself (crying). That I don’t have to be in a relationship with a man, I’m in a relationship with myself.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: Oh boy, it seems like my life is better now that I am HIV positive because when I was HIV negative, like I said, I was existing. It’s like the virus brought me to me; the virus brought me to myself.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I’m comfortable with myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die as long as I take care of myself. It just means taking better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life...I’m a much better person now, stronger, confident, just you know ready to help whoever I can... I’m okay with it.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: Thank God today I have been to groups and all kinds of educational programs, stuff like that. I learned so much about it. Yeah that is one thing, once I did find out about it, after a while, long about I’d say probably two years after I found out I think, I got myself together and I started pursuing to see what this HIV was about and how can I deal with it and live longer and that’s what I’ve been doing up until now. I just don’t feel like telling everybody about it right now, I’m comfortable myself knowing and I know it’s not a death sentence, I’m not going to die long as I take care of myself. It just means tak-ing better care of myself now, I’m more healthier now than I ever were. If I was still out there using I would probably be dead now, so the HIV really saved my life. Really if I look at it, you know, because I still would have been out there doing what I was doing probably, I don’t know. I’m a much better person now, stronger, confidence, just you know, ready to help whoever I can...I’m okay with it. It’s just letting people in.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: I’ve been doing pretty good. I’m still on the same regimen, yes. I really look at it as a blessing in a sense because if I hadn’t found out I was positive I wouldn’t be looking on the brighter side and doing better things for myself. I might not have seeked housing, I might still been out there. I look at it as a blessing.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: HIV definitely saved my life. I knew enough to know I didn't want to die, you know? And that meant getting clean, getting sober. I had one attack in my body like it was a hungry lion and then I threw drugs and alcohol in the mix and my body was like – girl! I'm going to quit on you if you don’t stop!

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: I thought it was a death sentence when I first found out about it and it ended up making me a better person. I ended up becoming stronger and being more health conscious without drug use and being more mindful and more aware of my body and the things that I need to do for me to stay healthy. Because one of the things I feared most in the WIHS study – I remember one of the questions they asked me was what is the one thing you fear most? I remember breaking out crying in the middle of a study when they asked me a question, I was watching my kids grow up. And it always stuck in my head. And now my kids are grown, and I have two grandbabies.

list.subject: Racheal
list.extract: I wasn’t surprised that I tested positive because of the lifestyle I had lived, but I was still hurt. It wasn’t like it was a shock because of the lifestyle I had lived. But it still was a painful moment to me. And she let me sit down there and she said you can go ahead and cry. And the first thing I thought was – it’s a death sentence, I’m dying…not knowing what I know about HIV now, I thought I was going to die, and that’s been seven years ago. Now I’m here, I’m living here, I’m undetectable, my T-cells are great. I’m as healthy as a horse.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: I'm not angry with this disease; matter of fact, this disease saved my life.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: When they gave it to me I could be at the dope house, call my friend up – I forgot to take my medicine, can you bring it to me? That’s how serious I was that this is not going to beat me, I'm going to beat it. And now as I look back over my life, I wouldn't change a thing, nothing would I have changed. Because what I got now is way, way better than what I had then. My children love me, my family still loves me, but most of all I love me! And if I can love me, who cares what people think or people say?

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: ...then they told me that they was closing the place. I thought my heart just fell out. In my mind I was saying — how can they close this place? What am I’m going to do? I’m going to go back, I’m going to go backwards in my feelings right, being closed in with myself. Yes, I cried, cried my way all the way home and then when I got home it was like this voice came to me and told me—when one door close another door will open.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: My mom passed away when I was going on 20. My daughter was six months old, when my mom passed away. She died at 49 years old, and then we had my dad. And then my dad died, I was so sad I forget all the time. This was my daughter who passed away also. She was 29.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: Okay, when I contracted HIV I was, okay I was using drugs. I got involved with this guy because, what happened was, my husband had passed away and I was really mean, I was really bad to this man, and he was really good to me. He passed away and I didn't do nothing, I felt so bad. And then I said – the next man I have I want to be really good you know? But it didn't work out like that because this guy, he knew he had the virus, he didn't tell me, the mom knew she didn't tell me you know, and she kept saying just don’t have no babies, you’re getting tooold for that, because she knew that he had the virus. How can you not tell me? I didn't have it. So this man, whenever I went out he would have girls in my house, he used to be a lot with this girl that had AIDS in my neighborhood but I never suspected that he was, you know, doing anything with her. So that’s how I contracted it.

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract:
Katherine: It was 1989. But I’ve only been clean for 13 years.
Jennie:Only!?
Katherine: Only. I mean…
Jennie: (laughter)
Katherine: That’s a great thing, but you know…
Jennie: You used for a long time.
Katherine: For a very long time. And even HIV was not a motivating factor for me to stop. I had to experience something that was very devastating for me to be encouraged to stop.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: And then a year ago in October, there was a terrible car accident, my sister-in-law was driving and she passed out at the wheel, it had something to do with the heart medicine she was on. They didn’t know what was going to happen, and my two retarded brothers were with her, because they were coming home from visiting me. And one of them got killed in the car accident. And these two were used to being together all the time. This is what I was saying about – Randall was used to always being with somebody.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: I was diagnosed in June 1992, June the 4th. At the same time I was diagnosed, two or three days later, my nephew got killed….All the emotion and everything running around, but when this was diagnosed with me, I was mad as hell. I was mad as hell because I felt that God had traded…but when things happen to people, they think of all crazy kinda stuff. That’s a human. You think – why did this happen to you? You might be a good person, you might be a bad person. But I was mad as hell.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I was born in Brooklyn, NY and I moved to North Carolina maybe 23 years ago.  I'm 46 years old and I work for the Post Office.  My mom died and the person that I was infected from HIV, he died, and I just needed a different scene, I just needed to get away with my kids, and North Carolina was it, felt like a safer place to go.  I had nobody else to stay in New York for as far as my mom and my fiancée.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My daughter got a hold of my diary…my therapy since I was old enough to write has been to write my thoughts down on a piece of paper in a notebook, my mama taught me that, she did the day she died. So I write my thoughts down. I was living with my daughter when my husband died, I had nowhere to go; I lost my home, I lost the vehicles, I lost everything in my home down to my clothes. Me and my dog is all I have. So I’ve been living with her for almost two years; April the 1st of this year I moved in my own place. She, being nosy or whatever, she read my diary. And in my diary it said I’d been diagnosed since 2000 with hepatitis C, nothing about HIV. She treats me like I am a disease. She’ll hug me, she’ll kiss me right here. There’s the grandkids come and stay with me, and I cook. If I have something left over and they're still hungry on my plate and I offer to put it on their plate, she has a fit! To where – now you know that’s unacceptable! They can't eat after you and they can’t drink after you! I said – why not? “You know why!” “No I don’t, please tell me why!” I want her to come out and tell me that she knows. But I'm thinking that she knows it’s hepatitis C, when everybody, all my friends and my doctors and case managers tell me that they believe that she knows I have HIV.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My husband died I said – Lord, okay, I got HIV so you know there ain't going to be no more men. First of all I'm too old to learn somebody else. And I don't want to say – I have HIV, is that going to be a problem? Because I don't want nobody to know. So therefore I'm not going to be in a relationship no more. So being alone is my (crying) biggest, biggest thing. I have to take care of my self now... I really would like (crying) to be in another relationship, I don't want to die alone. But if that don’t happen, just having friends. Me and you go to the movies, we’ll meet and go to the show, just being able to get out; I don’t get out. I ain't got no car, my daddy’s fixin’ to buy me a car and I know what that’s going to cost, that’s going to be some problems. And I know it but I'm not going to tell him not to do it.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: Actually, my mom died when I was 20 or 21 and I had had my two girls, which were a year and six months apart, so they was babies when my mom passed. I have two other brothers and a sister and my mom had insurance and stuff; I was well off. She left me everything in the house, the house and stuff like that, my brothers and stuff we didn't argue about stuff like that. I had like $97,000 and so I did some positive stuff with that. If my mom was living today, I’d probably be at home with my mom. And I probably wouldn't be, wouldn’t have gotten into that state of destruction, you understand? I think when she died that was it. That was like releasing me, just to go crazy as hell and so I did. I did, I did. I went crazy, just crazy. Just crazy

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I didn’t like to go to school because when I need help I did not used to ask for help and stuff. I used to stay inside myself. How do you say that? Even though the teachers used to say when you need help, I didn’t know how to express myself, I’ll put it that way. Instead of asking for help I used to keep it to myself. I used to fight a lot in school.

list.subject: Cheri
list.extract: I told her [MY MOM] that I wanted to go to Thomas Jefferson, because both of my sisters went to Jefferson and both my sisters got a good education at Thomas Jefferson High School. And, so she finally transferred me to Thomas Jefferson but by the time she transferred me to Thomas Jefferson, I was done with school. My mentality was—I’m done with school, I’m not doing this anymore, I’m just going just to be going. Sometimes I didn’t even go. My school called to say — and was like ‘Cheramie’s not in school’ (that’s what they called me back then, Cheramie). She said— well, Cheramie’s not coming back to school, she’s going to get her GED. I said — I am? I’m standing there going, ‘Really? When were you going to tell me this?’ Because her thought process was—you’re going to get your GED, you’re going to get a job, and you’re going to help contribute.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I went in Brooklyn 256, PS44, 305, Clara Barton was the last high school I went to. Clara Barton, ‘cause I wanted to be a nurse... I couldn’t even stand blood.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I went to school until I was in 9th grade, I got pregnant. And that was the end of that.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: that was ’71. I had a few boyfriends before that but you know sneak ones, not really like I could say – this is my boyfriend. This guy, because I was getting older and so I stated going with him and then I wind up getting pregnant. When I started that gym class they wouldn't allow me to participate and so I wind up not being able to complete, and so I never did get my high school diploma at that time. I just left. I wound up getting married at 18 and had my daughter, my oldest daughter she’s 42 now.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: I thought that was gonna be the thing that gave me my freedom. Even my mother said – you don’t have to get married, you could just have the baby or whatever. But I just wanted to get out of her strict household and I thought that was gonna be the thing to do. And it wasn’t. It was the worst thing that I ever did. ‘Cause I wound up getting married and having the same problems, not having any freedom, my husband didn't want me to go out, he was abusive, he wound up being abusive, and he’s the reason why I don’t have any sight today. I started going to school because I wanted to get my GED and I found out about a GED program that give you college credits; but he didn't want me to go. But I started going anyway, and one day he saw me outside without the kids, because I had a neighbor that used to watch my kids, and he saw me but I didn't see him. But my girlfriend said – there go your husband…and I said well, he seen me so I guess he’s working or whatever. I just went on. Got a ride to the subway and went on to school. And when he came home that night he just came in the door and just started beating me, and wind up giving me a black eye. I used to wear glasses, contact lenses; when I was growing up I always wore glasses but I had contact lenses then. And he just continued to pound on me and he detached a retina in one eye and then caused glaucoma in the other eye. So eventually I lost sight in both.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: I was never a street worker, I never had to get out there like that. And when I did graduate from high school I went straight into start working. I always have had good jobs... I was doing good things but bad things at the same time. Basically all my jobs that I did have, they were good jobs. That’s how I lost them, because of the drugs, because I would be tired and call in—I can’t come today. And then in 1992 I was feeling like…I lost my mom in ‘99 but in ‘92 I was feeling, it was around the time when Magic Johnson got diagnosedand everyone was kind of running to the little neighborhood clinics.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: And I'm like – if I go to school they going to take me back to my mom’s house and I’d then just leave and come back here. And I did that for about two weeks, and I got tired of being escorted out of the school in handcuffs, it was, you know…so I left their house because in order to stay in their house I needed to go to school. So by this time I'm in the streets and getting high and really didn't know why, you know? Didn't know why things happened to me, didn't know why I was doing stuff. And it’s just been recently that I'm starting to put it all together.

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Well, when you're that age you learn to pretend like everything is okay. Like you had a perfect family. But what really went wrong, I did horribly in school. You know, because I was like, you know, constantly on my mind, afraid to go home. I ran away a lot, and then at the age of 13 I was in a school for bad girls, I was in the Audy Home. ...That’s a place in Chicago for children who are supposed to be, you know it’s just like the Department of Corrections but this is only for children. Bad, bad children. I wasn’t bad at all, I was just you know acting out. I didn't consider running away being bad, I just wanted, I just didn't want to be at home. And so they took me away, they put me in the Audy Home.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Life after diagnosis has changed, for the better. It may have taken me many years after 1989 to get my life back in order. I eventually got back on track. The want and need to go back to school is what my desire was and that’s what I did. I did not let my HIV status stop me nor did I let people stop me.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract:
I come from a family of eight, well there was 10 of us in all but eight of us lived….I'm the sixth. I had to think because you know my mother married when she very young, very young and she had a baby very young. It was all good time but I also growed up in that Jim Crow law if you know what Jim Crow…I'm from the South and that’s where the Jim Crow laws started but there were eight of us, I gots part of that Jim Crow law because you had different things for black and whites, whatever. I'm part of that. 
 My father wanted the best, the best for us, go to school every day, but they had a third and fourth grade education, my parent did. But I always told my parent, we came out okay, they couldn't teach us how to read or anything like that, help us with our homework, but we always said we made it.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Going through, coming up in school, I went to a school that was mixed, so I didn't see color. I knew people were different but it wasn’t like – oh you're white, I can't be with you. Oh you're Asian I can't be with you. I just wanted to be cool with everybody until as a kid, you see that there are differences because you get older people who are showing you that prejudice and trying to teach you that prejudice. I didn't have a difference between races until I was like in the second grade, having a best friend who was white and got invited to her house and when I went, her dad was like – what are you doing here (when he opened the door). I'm like – I'm here for the taco party! “We don’t allow niggers”...I'm a kid and I'm just like –what the what! I knew that word from watching Roots andthings like that, but never experienced it. She’s behind him and she’s sad and her little sister, they called me ‘Alicia’ and she’s like –let Aliciain, let Aliciain. My friend’s name was [M] and her sister’s name was[R] . He would not let me in and I ran home crying and my Mom went around there, I don't know what my crazy Mom did or said (laughter). She laughs because I call her that because my Mom really took up for us. All parents normally do, butif I got into a situation, my Mom always sent me away and she handled it, and I don't know what my crazy Mother did but all Iknow is after I saw [M] again I wasn’t allowed to speak to her. Her parents, if they saw me coming they would pull her away. She would just be looking like –oh, I can't talk to you. We’d be in school and we couldn't talk. It was just bad

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: I went high school at H. D. Woodson senior high school, and I attended ABI (American Business Institute) out of New York when I was living in New York when they first started with computers. I started off with that back in about ’87 or ’88. I fooled around with that for a little bit but didn't stay with it, wish I had because look at computers now (laughter).

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I was the only white child in an all-African-American school in Lillington called Shawtown. For the first four years of my school year, of me going to school with all-blacks. I didn't see no color! Played, you know what I’m sayin’, spent the night, girlfriends over, I'm over their house; I didn't see any color. So when I got with one in a relationship, I still didn't see color. I don’t see color today. I felt like a black gentleman or a man treated me better than a white man did

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: Went to school and still in Durham. I went to school, graduated high school, and I did go to Atlanta, Georgia after I graduated to go to a one-year business college. I left Durham and stayed gone a year. Because of an incident that happened when I was in Atlanta, that brought me back to Durham and I’ve been here ever since. I just turned 60 on the 19th of July, so I'm a Durhamite.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: No, no. Even my brother, my brother was recently in the hospital, he was in ICU because he said they said he had a lung infection. I told my brother, I said—do they know you HIV positive? He told me—I’m not HIV positive. And I know he is! Because I remember when he was first diagnosed and sick in the hospital.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: At first I didn’t tell nobody, but when I was at the hospital I had a cousin coming to see me in the hospital and she kept telling me—oh, you know our cousin (because I had a cousin in the ‘80s who had died when the virus first came out, she had died); she came to see me in the hospital, she didn’t know what was wrong with me or nothing. She said—you know our cousin was right down the hall right here, down in that room. Anyway, she went and told everybody that I was sick with the virus.

list.subject: Carol
list.extract: I had a sister die, she had the virus; I had a niece die of the virus. The first one died was my cousin, that was in the early-‘80s. Then I had a sister die. But my sister, she died from other complications. She didn’t die from the virus. But my niece, she died from the virus because I guess when she got her results she didn’t let nobody know it, she was keeping it to herself. I think stress and the virus killed her. And I have a brother right now living with the virus.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: The first person that I disclosed to was my mom. As soon as I found out I had HIV, they said they would do the test and they did it. When it came back that it was positive again, I called my mom and said, “Mom, guess what? I'm positive. You positive? What are you talking about? I said I'm HIV positive. Oh, okay. You just gotta take care of yourself, that’ll be the lifestyle that you live, you gotta take care of yourself you know? Try not to get sick. Because I had a brother that died of AIDS and now a lot of people are living, people aren't dying like they were back then.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: Still to today, my son went to his death and didn’t know that I’m HIV-positive. My other two children don’t know that I’m HIV-positive; my mother doesn’t know, no one knows. My brothers don’t know. And I lost two brothers from HIV. And I got one sitting right now in UIC that got sores all over him and everything else. He’s getting ready probably to pass…soon. But he doesn’t know I have HIV.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I started smoking weed probably when I was 14. By the time I was smoking weed and drinking. My favorite stepsister was shooting drugs and I found out she was also turning dates. I needed to know what it was about this drug that made her go out there and do this. She said no, and I told her – if you don’t, somebody else will. I realize today that that was a really funky position for me to put my sister in, but she gave me some... unfortunately my sister and I became users together. We both ended up with HIV; she’s dead now. She went back out in the streets after getting sober and didn't make it back.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: [MY SON HAS] given me two more grandchildren and they’re fine and his wife is still fine. It goes on like that. Yes, little close encounters like that kind of wake you up. Once all the drugging and the alcohol, I finally got rid of all of that, you know WIHS and the clinic and the people you meet, you learn something from people everyday.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: As soon as I turned 18. I graduated high school and then I left. To the streets really, there was nowhere, I was in the park and I met my kid’s father and had two kids by him.

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: My thing was – when detox is over, what am I going to do and where am I going to go? After that weekend that I was supposed to get out, they held me an extra day because I told them – where am I going from here? So they held me an extra day. [A] talked to the social service department in the Women and Infant Transmission Study because that’s how I got plugged into Downstate. They were running this program for pregnant women that were positive at that time. They had a study going on; she asked me if I wanted to be part of it and well, a smart person would think – okay, this where you’re going to get most of your information firsthand and sooner than later if I join this, I’ll get to learn a lot more about what’s going on a lot quicker than I would anyplace else.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: I moved out of here in Brooklyn with my boyfriend in like 2000. And he got incarcerated and I had got incarcerated. So when I came home I had nowhere to go. I was in the shelter system for about five years. I just recently got my apartment two years ago ... on Crook Avenue, a CAMBA building.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: And I'm like – if I go to school they going to take me back to my mom’s house and I’d then just leave and come back here. And I did that for about two weeks, and I got tired of being escorted out of the school in handcuffs, it was, you know…so I left their house because in order to stay in their house I needed to go to school.
