So by this time I'm in the streets and getting high and really didn't know why, you know? Didn't know why things happened to me, didn't know why I was doing stuff. And it’s just been recently that I'm starting to put it all together.

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Well, when you're that age you learn to pretend like everything is okay. Like you had a perfect family. But what really went wrong, I did horribly in school. You know, because I was like, you know, constantly on my mind, afraid to go home. I ran away a lot, and then at the age of 13 I was in a school for bad girls, I was in the Audy Home. ...That’s a place in Chicago for children who are supposed to be, you know it’s just like the Department of Corrections but this is only for children. Bad, bad children. I wasn’t bad at all, I was just you know acting out. I didn't consider running away being bad, I just wanted, I just didn't want to be at home. And so they took me away, they put me in the Audy Home.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: I just felt so comfortable with him. I always felt I belonged to be with him. No matter what happened, and believe me, a lot of things went bad, I always felt that man loved me. And I love him, he’s the love of my life. I can’t be with him, I haven’t seen him in two years, I can’t have nothing to do with him anymore. I had to draw lines up. Because he won’t stop with the drinking and things happened, I live with my family, I have to be there for my family and I can’t have the two intermingling. And of course everybody hates him because they know he gave me HIV eventually, which is wild, because I maybe had sex with my husband maybe twice in one year. Not because I didn’t love him, because I love and find him attractive, but I had my own issues, physical, or whatever, menopause, so I just couldn’t bear the pain. But twice in one year…and I got HIV. I got very sick and my friend said – I’m going to take you down to Cook County Hospital, my friend Donny, and he said you better have that tested because he knew my husband had HIV already like eight years, and that’s pretty much when I separated from my husband. I told him to stay with his mother. I was homeless, sleeping in a garage. I ended up homeless and broke. I wanted my husband to try to get into rehab or something, and his family…forget that. They’re all losers.

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: My daughter got a hold of my diary…my therapy since I was old enough to write has been to write my thoughts down on a piece of paper in a notebook, my mama taught me that, she did the day she died. So I write my thoughts down. I was living with my daughter when my husband died, I had nowhere to go; I lost my home, I lost the vehicles, I lost everything in my home down to my clothes. Me and my dog is all I have. So I’ve been living with her for almost two years; April the 1st of this year I moved in my own place. She, being nosy or whatever, she read my diary. And in my diary it said I’d been diagnosed since 2000 with hepatitis C, nothing about HIV. She treats me like I am a disease. She’ll hug me, she’ll kiss me right here. There’s the grandkids come and stay with me, and I cook. If I have something left over and they're still hungry on my plate and I offer to put it on their plate, she has a fit! To where – now you know that’s unacceptable! They can't eat after you and they can’t drink after you! I said – why not? “You know why!” “No I don’t, please tell me why!” I want her to come out and tell me that she knows. But I'm thinking that she knows it’s hepatitis C, when everybody, all my friends and my doctors and case managers tell me that they believe that she knows I have HIV.

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I was told at, [diagnosed] I was at this place called Durham Center Access. I had gone there because I was homeless, I didn't have anyplace to stay, and they happened to be doing HIV testing and I had no idea I was HIV positive. It didn't take them long to let me know that I was positive. I was a little stunned but I mean, it didn't make me crazy or anything. I just knew I needed to find out what I needed to do at that point. That’s when I asked them what I needed to do and they told me I needed to start going to the health department, the EI Clinic, that I could get some medication and get some help there. So that’s what I did. Since I found out I was HIV positive, I have no problems at all, I am doing very well. It doesn’t bother me. You know what I'm saying? And I had hepatitis C, I'm rid of that now, I got in a Duke study and got the free medicine and all that. I'm real grateful.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I met someone and I knew he was a drug dealer and I went out with him and I never thought nothing of it. And I wasn’t diagnosed until I left Beacon and came to Queens because I was checked in Beacon and I was fine. So when you switch to another state you got go to a new clinic...The doctor said — can I do an HIV test? I said yes, you can, because I’m fine. ’91. When she came back and told me I was HIV— because back in the days I thought you were just dying. I didn’t read up, I should have, and I started to cry and I told her —  ‘now what? You don’t want to touch me?’ Oh God, that doctor hugged me so hard.

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: I don’t know how to tell [D] because I’m...I don’t want him to think because you’re HIV you’re going to die. I had to correct a lady one time in a clinic because she said —  do you have AIDS? And I said no ma’am, I have the virus. Why did I get so mad? I had to recently see my doctor because I was getting scared because if I have an ear-ache, I’m already thinking...see I’m losing weight, a lot of weight and I asked her if I’m going downhill. And she said Cookie — your T-cell count is undetected, your viral load is sky high. You ain’t going to die from that. [VIRAL LOAD IS UNDETECTABLE AND YOUR T-CELLS ARE HIGH] She said so high, so it woke me up. I gotta get out of this funk. I really have to get out of it. I just take medication and now I’m drinking protein.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: Well, throughout the years I was always a stable, positive woman. I never was aware, never went into any type of community, I was very naïve when it came to HIV and AIDS. I was married to a man that gave me three children and everything went well, but him and I were divorced; this is my first husband. Then I met this second man and this second man actually had the virus. A very good man, now don’t get me wrong. He didn’t drink, he didn’t smoke, he was a hard-working guy. But he was a single guy that lived with his parents and apparently he used to get sexual favors from women and in one of them favors that he got from somewhere out there, it gave him HIV and then I found out by getting sick and losing weight and constant diarrhea. I went to get tested and that’s when I found out. This was in 1989, so I’ve been positive going on almost 30 years.

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: I empower other women to stay on track in Star Health Center. I’ve been with them since 1992 and I worked myself up getting knowledgeable with HIV and took trainings and so on, certificates throughout the years. What I do now is I empower others, let them know that they're not alone. And I can share and I can relate because I'm walking their shoes.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Jeanette
list.extract: Because if you don’t take your medicine you won't be okay, period point blank. And it took a long time for them to even recognize women in anything when it comes to this disease, and then to focus on what works for us. Because what works for us is not working for men. You understand? Because I had two children before they even told me – ask me about being HIV positive or taking an HIV test. But they test them other two children I had and they never told me one way or the other with them, but I know that they're not, because time goes on. But I’ll be here for you baby.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: Well when I learned, at first I didn’t know nothing about it, I just didn’t know, I didn’t think about it. And I thought I’d probably be dead by now.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: Well, when I first was diagnosed I didn’t have no education about it so I didn’t know by using the drugs could constantly...I was messing myself up even more. My CD4 count and making myself out there more to expose myself to more things and more complications to me. And when I got arrested in 2009 they gave me a choice of a two-year program or four and a half years to nine in jail. I took the two-year program. I went to Queens to J-CAP, graduated with flying colors, been clean ever since.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: In my opinion… I think when there's the list of things, the reasons or ways to get HIV, I can check every one of them. So I don’t really know. But I'm sure if I wasn’t using I might not have been with a few of those guys, you know? I don't know. I think it was heroin use, IV drug using. I think that was…but a few of the people that I did have sex with also used heroin and also had HIV. But I didn't really know that they had HIV until I started getting clean and I started really getting educated about it.

list.subject: Yolanda
list.extract: Okay, when my daughter found out, it was one day because I was using, I started using really heavy when, after I became HIV. One day on the elevator and we were arguing you know? I said you know what? I hope I die, I’m HIV positive! I hope I die! And my daughter just sunk and fell on the floor, crying. Just seeing the way she reacted (crying) but after that she was in college so she learned a lot about HIV. So now it’s not an issue anymore, you know? She showed me DVDs about HIV and what it started from, the progress. And my younger son, he’s still, he’s in denial about it; he won’t talk about it. I won’t bother him with that now. Once I asked him and he said – mom please, I don’t want to talk about that. My oldest son, he’s okay with it. He did a lot of research on HIV, so they’re okay with it.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I ended up in the penitentiary with my youngest daughter with a friend, my second diagnosis in five years, still not knowing what it is that I have. Got out of the penitentiary and there was a DCFS worker waiting for me at the gate. And he told me that if I thought I wanted my kids back I probably wouldn't get them back because I had HIV. But he brought me to the wrong place, he took me to the Fantus Clinic at Stroger Hospital. And that was his mistake, taking me to the Fantus Clinic because not only did they educate me about HIV, they educated me about my rights concerning HIV and you know, that nobody could take my child simply because…there were people trying to.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: This was ’85.  And the doctor came in and started asking me about my life and my habits.  And he came back and he goes – your baby has HIV so I'm pretty sure you have it, too. He walked away and I let him.  It was just like everything else in my life, nobody explained it to me, nobody told me anything.  So after a week or so in the hospital they let my daughter come home, she was better.  Her immune system had kicked in, kicked mine out, she is not positive.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I did my volunteer work, I did the MATEC training you know. Because nobody wanted to be with the AIDS patients in Cook County Hospital. So what’d they do? They trained the AIDS patients to go sit with the AIDS patients. Because we knew that there’s nothing, we knew we needed comfort, so we took these classes and we went and comforted our people.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I never forget, I walked up one day and there was this guy, he just had the sheet wrapped around him and he was just rocking. He was like – I’ve been here for five days, nobody’s talked to me, they barely want to touch me. I'm like – we can talk, I'm here, I ain't going nowhere. And for me, that was my epiphany. To see him just wrapped up, just waiting to die. Because the nurses only came when they had to. So from that point on I started running my mouth and talking and…

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: I didn't know anything [about AIDS when I was diagnosed]! All I know was that it was like a deadly…I did know this, it was a virus and it was a deadly virus. And I did know that it was a gay man’s disease. But I really didn't care at that time, you know? I didn't really care because I was just still out there, you know, in the street. All I cared about was getting my fix and then oh – I’ll get treated tomorrow. But when I got to the Fantus Clinic I started learning about it through group, you know. I started listening to what my doctor was saying and I didn't even know that if your T-cell count fall below, back then it was 200, then you had the AIDS.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: I talked to anyone, you know, and I learned mainly from gay, gay men about this disease. What I did was I started working as a Certified Nurse Assistant, so mostly all my patients back then had AIDS. They had Kaposi’s sarcoma, you know. It was all kind of, it was a gay man’s disease back then. But what they didn't know was that I was diagnosed with HIV, they said AIDS. I was adhering to my medications. I took control of what I was supposed to do.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: When I had him I was never given prenatal care and then on top of that I was shooting drugs, I was drinking, I'm surprised he came out a perfect baby like he did. But the thing was, when he came out he had drugs in his system….So when I got to the hospital he was gone. But before they even did all that, they released me and kept him because they had to let him detox. Before they even did all that they came in my room, the doctor, fully gowned I mean from head to toe looking like astronauts and told me I had AIDS. They didn't say nothing about HIV positive, and did I want to talk to a chaplain? And you know if you have to talk to a chaplain, that means, you know, you don’t have long to live. It could be today or tomorrow. That’s because they didn't really know that much about HIV or AIDS you know?

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: Seeing when I first walked in the door it was just unbelievable because you saw people from all walks of life, the ones who was living on the streets, the ones who prostituting, the ones who was shooting up, and you're looking at – hmm, what am I doing here, I do not fit in. And the ones who work the streets. And as I got to doing and talking to the ladies I found out that I really wasn’t a whole lot different from them, even though my lifestyle was different. We’re all women and we all were affected.

list.subject: Racheal
list.extract: I wasn’t surprised that I tested positive because of the lifestyle I had lived, but I was still hurt. It wasn’t like it was a shock because of the lifestyle I had lived. But it still was a painful moment to me. And she let me sit down there and she said you can go ahead and cry. And the first thing I thought was – it’s a death sentence, I’m dying…not knowing what I know about HIV now, I thought I was going to die, and that’s been seven years ago. Now I’m here, I’m living here, I’m undetectable, my T-cells are great. I’m as healthy as a horse.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract: Because here I am, a white single female, heterosexual, having contracted it through my ex-husband, so where does that leave me? So that’s why I’m very in favor of getting the knowledge out there to the young ones, because for every…I think statistically, for every one person who knows that they are HIV, there’s 100 who don’t know. It’s important. But I think in general the public knows it… because every once in a while the news will report— it’s no longer a death sentence and all that, but it’s a lot more complicated than that.

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract: I started doing some research, and that’s when I found out about an organization called TPAN on the north side. It was an organization that was headed up by a gay group and... wonderful guys. So after work, I would drive up to the North Side.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract: it has recently come to the doctor’s attention that this is something new that they know nothing about but yet people are starting to show up with these symptoms and with this particular blood work

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Um, yes, because the percentage that they gave me of the child not being positive was so low that it was an influence yes, go get rid of this baby because it was what they were telling me it was more than 50% chance that the child would be positive. Which we know nowadays no, that’s not true, but back then I didn't know any better. I had zero to no knowledge about this and they had zero to no knowledge and all that I saw that the people that had AIDS and were HIV positive were dying. In the streets dying, that was all around me, everybody was dying. Nobody was living from it.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: Not at all. And that’s the thing. People say HIV like that is the worst thing in the world to have. But if a doctor came in and said Angela, I have just diagnosed you with cancer, I would break down. I would rather them tell me I'm HIV positive then tell me that I have cancer. People look at this disease as the dirtiest, the wickedest, the nastiest thing to have in this world and it’s crazy. There's many idiots out here don’t understand what HIV and AIDS are.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well there was a time…When I first realized what I had, I didn't want to get better. I did not want to get better, but I knew my son was trying to have a child and I asked God – if said you just let me live long enough to see my grandbaby, then whatever comes, comes. And that helped me get through a lot of it. And my sisters kept telling me – you can do this, you can do this. I was like everybody else; I was dumb. I thought it was a death sentence. When I got to working with Dr. Kozel and everything, she would talk to me and she didn't think I was going to make it, but she kept my hopes up. So I had to pull myself out of that to be able to make myself go on. And my sisters would come over and help me and make sure I had my medicine because like I said, I couldn't remember nothing; I couldn't remember when to take medicine, what day, what it looked like.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: I felt dirty, I just felt…and I could never understand…what my problem is is trying to understand this whole situation is – you’ve got every kind of disease out there. But this disease, they want to blackball you from everything. That’s something I never understood. You can get herpes, gonorrhea, syphilis, all that stuff can kill you. But yet they're putting it on us…and why?

list.subject: Cookie
list.extract: The difference I’m trying to make is to realize that I am HIV. There’s a lot of things that you can do to lift up your spirit. I always take my medication like clockwork. Maybe not the same time because some-times I don’t eat during...but I take it every single day. And I want to be able to live with it. I really think I’ve been so in denial, that’s why I let my body go so bad. I just didn’t...but now I have that spunk, like somebody lit a fire under my butt because I really, really want to live. I’m not embarrassed anymore. I’ll go talk and speak, but I got to  learn also how to tell my 15-year-old and I don’t even think I want to. Because [D] feels I’m all he has. His mother’s his other mother; I’m his mom. I’m his light, his God, I’m everything to [D]. Little does he know that that’s what he means to me. And sometimes I feel like I should let him know, give him the awareness because every time I look at him...maybe in groups or something where there’s other children that he can meet, because one-on-one from me I wouldn’t want to just tell him, no. I want him to see that other kids are coping with their parents with it. But I still really, I don’t know about [D], I feel like I’ll hurt him.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Loretta
list.extract: I love the Lord and I’m a child of God. And I know that all that I’m going through and experiencing, it’s only a matter of time. And I’m sitting here talking about I’m scared of this and scared of that and I shouldn’t be a coward, just hit me with something...when she says she’s not afraid. My grandmother tell me that all the time. What you scared of girl? You shouldn’t be scared.

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: Felt like somebody took the floor from under me. There was noth-ing I could step on, I was just whew, like getting on an elevator and going down!

list.subject: Roslyn
list.extract: When I moved back from Long Island to Brooklyn, when I got my apartment in Brooklyn I had set two short goals – first to get my skates, and get a sewing machine. I was back in Brooklyn for about a month and it came like that (snap) and that made me feel good. I started back skating and I didn’t miss a beat.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: Normally it’s just the people from WIHS that really know, okay. And my husband knew.... I live like, I don’t even know how to say, like ashamed of myself. I’m very clean, my house is immaculate, if I get cut I won’t let nobody help me, nobody even come near where I bled if it went on my floor. You see what I’m saying? My bathroom’s so immaculate you wouldn’t believe it.This is the way I am because of me having this HIV. And I’m so afraid. What happens if something happens and they catch it, how do I live with myself without telling my own children?

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Yes, I started seeking counseling [about the molestation]. And then like I said, I started going to groups. I found out that other people had worse issues than I did, you know! It didn't make me feel good but it helped to know that I wasn’t out there alone. And then some of these things that suppressed me or made me very depressed, it can happen to anybody, it can happen to the best of people.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: I was diagnosed in June 1992, June the 4th. At the same time I was diagnosed, two or three days later, my nephew got killed….All the emotion and everything running around, but when this was diagnosed with me, I was mad as hell. I was mad as hell because I felt that God had traded…but when things happen to people, they think of all crazy kinda stuff. That’s a human. You think – why did this happen to you? You might be a good person, you might be a bad person. But I was mad as hell.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: Well there was a time…When I first realized what I had, I didn't want to get better. I did not want to get better, but I knew my son was trying to have a child and I asked God – if said you just let me live long enough to see my grandbaby, then whatever comes, comes. And that helped me get through a lot of it. And my sisters kept telling me – you can do this, you can do this. I was like everybody else; I was dumb. I thought it was a death sentence. When I got to working with Dr. Kozel and everything, she would talk to me and she didn't think I was going to make it, but she kept my hopes up. So I had to pull myself out of that to be able to make myself go on. And my sisters would come over and help me and make sure I had my medicine because like I said, I couldn't remember nothing; I couldn't remember when to take medicine, what day, what it looked like.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract:
Here’s the other thing. So because I grew up seeing how men treated women, I treated men the same way they treated us. So I always had more than one. 
 So that brings me to how I got HIV. I think I was going through another depressive episode, wasn’t on medication, I was like in nursing school, probably using sex as my drug of choice at the time, had like four partners. So then when I found out I had HIV I didn't even know which one it came from, although I pretty much had a sneaking suspicion; I narrowed it down to like two of the four. I was like, It’s definitely one of these two clowns over here

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: So, there was that, and then when I got to this study, the people here are so great, you never feel judged. It’s like a warm, fuzzy, sunshiny place to come to for me. You always feel, you know, they always make you feel like a person (crying)... And they don't want anything from you (crying)… So it’s not like they're charging you to make you feel like a person (crying). And you know they provide a lot of needed things, in my case of course it was the physicals and pap smears, but you know, moral support, helping to make sure that I don’t fall into the cracks, which I normally would have done by now in this situation. And there was a time where I was like…I couldn't get the medication because I made too much money (crying) but I didn't have insurance. And I was too depressed to care! (crying)

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: Or not even that but because well I guess maybe I’ve learned how to hide it so long and put the game face on that everybody, that nobody sees the vulnerability (crying) and I get tired. Having to put your game face on all the time…it’s tiring. It’s exhausting really. But you know how people ask – how’re you doing? And we all know it’s a rhetorical question in the first place. And you get, especially older people they say – oh, I can't complain. If I did, ain't nobody listening anyway or nobody cares anyway. And that’s pretty much how it is. So that’s why I put my game face on because I don’t have energy to expend on…that I said hi and smiled and they didn't say hi back (laughter). I don’t have energy for that. I just have just enough energy to get through whatever. I’d say, people would describe me as confident, so I’ll agree with that because I'm confident in the sense that despite my deficits, if could dig my way out from under a couple of them like the fog…from I don't know if it’s menopausal fog or if it’s from the depression or the medication hell, I don't know. But if I could dig my way out of this damn fog, I could probably do some stuff! So, I would say I'm confident, I would agree with that.I would say that I don't know, I would say I love myself only because I know technically I really don’t have self-esteem issues, but then again there are days where I just don’t care whether I live or die, and it’s not because I hate myself or because I feel that I don’t deserve to live (crying) but just because I'm tired. I'm just tired.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: Actually, my mom died when I was 20 or 21 and I had had my two girls, which were a year and six months apart, so they was babies when my mom passed. I have two other brothers and a sister and my mom had insurance and stuff; I was well off. She left me everything in the house, the house and stuff like that, my brothers and stuff we didn't argue about stuff like that. I had like $97,000 and so I did some positive stuff with that. If my mom was living today, I’d probably be at home with my mom. And I probably wouldn't be, wouldn’t have gotten into that state of destruction, you understand? I think when she died that was it. That was like releasing me, just to go crazy as hell and so I did. I did, I did. I went crazy, just crazy. Just crazy

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: I was out walking on the block or in the hood or whatever, and this guy pulled up, I'm thinking it’s just another regular trick, you know? And he asked me my name and I said yes, that’s me. He said – would you mind if I talked to you for a minute? And he showed me his badge from the health department. And I knew it couldn't have been nothing good, you know? It’s the man from the health department, you know? It’s something! So we talked and he told me they were looking for me because somebody gave them my name that I had slept with and they had tested positive for HIV. And at that moment, at that time right then, my world just completely collapsed. Just completely collapsed. It just, um I can't even think of the word for it. I didn't understand, I didn't understand right then at that moment – why me? But as time has went on – why not me? You know? Why not me, I put myself in that predicament. I did things I shouldn’t have done and this is the result of my self-will.

list.subject: Velvet
list.extract:
Velvet: I can relate to that.  And you know what?  If you have never done any drugs and have never experienced the life of using drugs, a person that never have the experience the life of using drugs,, if they would get on drugs they wouldn't know how to handle it.  
Claristine: They wouldn't. 
Velvet: You guys are strong, I'm talking about extra strong to be able to live that life.  If you're not a warrior, that’s like using drugs and being on the street just is like being in the Army.  You got to be a soldier, you got to.  Soldiers are strong, strong-minded people.
Claristine And it take God. 
Velvet It take God.

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: Well now I'm a really a homebody, I don’t do much, I don't know many people here, I came from up north, I came down here in 2009. Off and on with my daughter, I go home, I come back, I go home and come back. And they move around so much within these few years. So, I haven't really settled in no place for a long time. Not that I want many friends because to me it’s just trouble. I don’t go anywhere, I don’t club…I babysit whenever they need me and I just stay close to the house. But I know we going to get to this, but my main concern now is I want my space. I want my space. I want to be free and freedom to me means having my own place, my own space again. I need that. I feel like I'm suffocating you know?

list.subject: Gloria
list.extract: I felt pain. I felt betrayed, I wanted to actually kill him, which I tried. I changed my mind and I took a turn to the better and I started seeking help. There were no medications then. After a while there came a medicine by the name of Hivid, it was the very first one with AZT. And so I took the initiative to take care of myself. But before I did that I went to crack. I threw him out. I went to crack, I went to heroin, I went to prostitution. You name it; I did it all. But I lifted myself up spiritually and I accepted the Lord in 1993.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Loretta
list.extract: I love the Lord and I’m a child of God. And I know that all that I’m going through and experiencing, it’s only a matter of time. And I’m sitting here talking about I’m scared of this and scared of that and I shouldn’t be a coward, just hit me with something...when she says she’s not afraid. My grandmother tell me that all the time. What you scared of girl? You shouldn’t be scared.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: I have faith that there will be a cure, I have faith that I’m going to be living here a long time. I have faith in God. My spirituality is very high on my list because if I don’t have that spirit...my fiancée tells me I’m a very free spirit. Yes I want my spirit to always be free, but with a little caution added to it, you understand what I’m saying? I don’t want to be just free, free Willy, and I can be like that. I’ll be like come on Roz, come on Sue...that’s just how my spirit is. But I want to keep that in place but like I said with a little caution. Because not everybody’s going to be nice, good to you. Um, it means that for me, I’m going to find somebody like yourself that’s a free spirit, you know what I’m saying? And it’s not all bad being a free spirit, you just gotta be careful who you’re being that free spirit with. My free spirit got me homeless you know what I’m saying, I have absolutely nothing. I have life; I thank God every day for that. But I’m going to get everything back tenfold; God going to see to that.

list.subject: Roxy
list.extract: I don’t’ curse. Oh boy I used to be crazy with cursing and fighting, oh my goodness, I used to fight, blind and fighting and threatening people, just being that typical drunk. And not…because I left the house with pressed clothes and looking a certain way, because I was always raised that way but I was just always using something, so it would always wind up being like that Roxy. That person that was always in trouble, like that kid that was always in trouble. I don’t even know what happened but I just thank God that it did. Maybe that last prayer that I prayed, that I just needed help. But I always felt like I was just maintaining, I had a right to drink, I had a right to…as long as I was taking care of my kids I considered myself doing the right thing because I kept my kids and never had to go into a shelter. So I always felt like I was just one step above all the other people that used.

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: Because I believe in God and I think that that’s what’s helped me through a lot of everything that’s happened in my life is going to church and praying to God and learning that God is there no matter what...for me.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: I’m like okay, I got to questioning my faith and like okay, you been to church all these years, apparently you’ve got all this or whatever and so you still around for something. I started doing a little bit of research, I’m real good with computers and I started doing a little bit of research, and I heard about the Radiation Center, which was, they had a women’s group in there, a women’s support group. So I started going to the women’s support group at Cook County Hospital, okay?

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: Yes, and I’ve been standing ever since. Never had a desire…I say I’ve been delivered from the disease of addiction. I'm not recovered or recovering, I’ve been delivered. It’s been taken away, you know what I mean? I’ve learned how to live this super life a new way. You know what I mean? I got busy about my business, got busy about making my kids a priority and in the interim when I got Madison out of the system, the judge was like – don’t you have two other children in the system? When a parent gets themselves together, it’s not for one, so they re-investigated return home for the other two. So I had to go through a lot of stuff.

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: So God was allowing me to get my mind right. (crying) (inaudible) I was about to take, and I was ready then. Treatment opened up, because I was scared, I didn't want no more and I wanted to give my son a chance! And I stayed in Maryville for two years, I went to Haymarket, I stayed there for 18 months and I was scared to leave because I just didn't want to have no more. I moved into a program where they monitor us, you know? They subsidized my rent, then I had just got active into, after that I begin engaged in my medical care, wanted now to take care of my HIV. I began to educate myself about what it is that I had.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Katherine
list.extract: I mean the pain, the emotional pain was far worse than the physical pain. and I just asked God to just – stop. Just stop (crying) the pain. And that’s when I asked him to help me to come in, and God whatever it is that I have to do I will do it, whatever they tell me to do, whatever…I'm going to do it. And when I feel like using I'm going to pray to you, you say that you are God…I need you to show me that you are God. ... And I delivered Madison and I'm telling you when I asked God for help, things just started happening. I had already had two children in the system, Jada and Jaylen, and they were already terminated from parental rights. And it was the lady from DCFS came and she was like – well, I'm going to let you take your baby but you have to get into treatment.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

themes.text: What the state does to you
themes.key: what the state does to you

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Because most of the African-American churches, I don't know how it is now, but I knew then – you were ousted, people would cringe because they didn't know, understand it. You don’t get HIV from touching someone, you don’t get HIV from going to bathroom, you know? But I have heard a lot of people complain about you know they came out in church and then people felt differently of them. And so that’s when I stopped going to church.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: Knowing that I could survive in the midst of the storm, knowing that everything I’ve went through was experience. Not only that, but it’s to make me better. We go through challenges in life and if we can deal with it, we come out ahead. Looking at how I was able to see my brothers, then being pimps, and watching the womens get beat and watching the pimps come up to the school and pull the girls from the school and I'm like – oh that’s not gonna be me, that’s not gonna happen to me! And seeing the drugs and everything and still being able to say that that’s not me, even though I had a lot of pressure. But I felt that my strength was within and I believed in God, and my family didn't go to church or anything, I went to church every Sunday but no one else went. I'm like – I can do this, God got my back, my faith. And it was my faith, even at an early age, looking at all the traumas and trials I’ve been through and being able to say – man, I was there but it didn't happen to me, I didn't get into this.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: It was to the point where they were going to put me on the street. It was either straighten up and fly right, and I hit my rock bottom, finally. I got busted buying drugs, and I’m sitting in the cell waiting to go to court and I’m thinking – this is the second time. And I’m thinking – what if I get a little time or something, because you ain't gonna get off maybe like you did the first time, and I thought, what if something happens to my mother because she’s already up in age and had a number of strokes and stuff. So I said to myself – well, you know what? You need to do something differently, so that doesn’t end up happening. And the only answer was I needed to get the strength to stop doing that stuff. So what I did was I just slowly backed off of it. I lied through my teeth and said I wasn’t doing it, but it was the weirdest thing, I looked at it like dieting. If I could get $200, you could bet I had 20 rocks in my pocket and would smoke them in a day. And I just backed up. I slowed down. Just like you cut your food portions, I cut and I cut and I backed up and I backed up. And I prayed to God for strength, or to the higher power, because I didn’t necessarily believe in a God but in the possibility of a higher power, and I prayed for the inner strength, and somehow I had it. I went to a couple of meetings. I couldn’t go to a lot of meetings, I could barely walk. I was as big as a house, 338 pounds, I could hardly walk from the bus stop…

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: I was diagnosed in June 1992, June the 4th. At the same time I was diagnosed, two or three days later, my nephew got killed….All the emotion and everything running around, but when this was diagnosed with me, I was mad as hell. I was mad as hell because I felt that God had traded…but when things happen to people, they think of all crazy kinda stuff. That’s a human. You think – why did this happen to you? You might be a good person, you might be a bad person. But I was mad as hell.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh, my prayers, I made this prayer when I got clean. I said –God, if I ever use any illegal drugs I want you to take me out right now (laughter) because that was the worst two-year stint of my life. It was only two years but it was the worse. I think living with HIV was better than being on drugs...Um, drugs control your mind. They control your mind, your character, it control your moods, it controls everything. Your bank account, it controls you…your whole ability to thinking. And I had no control over my life for those two years. It was like – I was losing me. And really and truly HIV was an easier task than being on drugs. If I didn't have my mom I probably would still be out there, really in a bad situation in the streets. I never got to the point of doing things for drugs because I had family that tried that kept me off the streets, or tried to keep me off the streets. So I was good on that level but (sigh) I still did a lot of things that I'm not proud of back then, yes.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I want my future to look…I want there to become a cure, a real cure. I know that the medicines are keeping us alive but I want one day to take that test and say – it’s not there anymore! That’s what I want my future to be. I don't want to have to put expiration dates on my life, like my first goal was to see my kids graduate from high school. Now this goal I'm making is to see my grandkids grown. I don't want to have to have praying for expiration dates. I want to be praying that God give man knowledge of a cure, a real cure, and not just a Band-aid that you putting over by taking the medication.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: No. Actually when I first got my results my younger brother came with me. And back in those days it was a death sentence so it took him to get my mind right, I mean really. Back then it was just coming out and to find out that you were HIV positive meant that you would be dead in a month or two. So my brother was there with me and he was very supportive...In 1989, 1990, yeah something around there...(sigh) It was the beginning to an end, that’s what I thought. It was like okay, I have two kids, my mom is sickly, what am I going to do? In my mind I was like oh my God I'm dying. And then I had no God at that time, I wasn’t into church, so to me I had nothing to turn to but my kids. I wanted to live for them. Everything around me wanted to be alive for them. (tears)

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I love my children! They are my inspiration, they are why I'm here today because I fought for life to raise them. And it’s funny because I remember saying one day – God, if you just let me see my kids graduate from high school and see them grown where they can take care of theyself, I’ll be happy. Woo, that time came and I was like okay God, let me (laughter) rephrase this please. Let me live longer. But then I was just praying for life just to raise them, just to see them grow. Now I'm praying for life to see my grandkids. You know, my grandkids are growing up, they're the apple of my life, back then all I could think of is – God, if you just get me through, just let me see them grown I’ll be so grateful. Now I’m like uh-oh, that time happened, what am I going to do now?

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: It was up to me to take matters in my own hands or leave it alone and live my life. I planned on taking matters in my own hands. I wanted to kill him, I made a vow with myself that I would, and even though going through counseling eventually I just started to lie – like oh I'm not going to hurt anybody, oh I'm better now. Because I definitely had to get counseling. What I did was I planned – I'm going to find this man and kill him so he won't do this to anybody else. I’ll deal with the jail time. I even got a will prepared for myself so my kids would be taken care of. It just never happened and I'm thankful that it never did. I didn't see him until I had forgiven myself and forgiven him. I did that in 2004. I went to a church encounter for women and gosh, I just laid everything down, all my anger, all my hurts from childhood all the way up…I had to forgive me for making different choices that put me in harm’s way, forgive people for hurting me. I just had to get it off of my chest.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: On New Year’s Eve 2006 we were getting testing done at our church in Maryland. My pastor Tony Lee, A Community of Hope Church. We did HIV testing. And I came back positive along with one of my sons who tested with me. We had to go to Johns Hopkins to get retested and prior to that weekend, I just prayed a lot and just asked to reverse everything on me so my son wouldn't be positive, because he was getting ready to go away to college. I just didn't want him to have to live his life like that...He came back negative. And I came back positive, I remember clearly because the doctor was like – well Miss, your son came back negative but you came back positive still. I was just happy and jumping up and down, yay! He’s like – but I'm telling you, you're still positive. I said that’s okay, my son is negative, I can handle it. I’ve been through abuse, been through addiction, been through sexual abuse. I can handle this.

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: I got sick and tired of being sick and tired. I went to a church on Easter and the Holy Spirit called me and they thought I was losing my mind in church when actually I guess God was cleansing me. And I just stopped. That day I just lost the desire to do the drug, lost the desire for the drug.

list.subject: Tonya
list.extract: My life has been really, really just ripped apart but I know God don’t make no mistakes on what he doing but…he put so much on you that sometime you just can't take it (crying). And so you figure if you just get high, you get drunk or whatever it’ll go away – but it don’t. (crying) You just put it down deep inside your body and then when you have to talk about it and help somebody else, it’s painful.

list.subject: Velvet
list.extract: I prayed that night I said God…because I wanted to leave, I wanted to go back, and I wanted to get high, but out there I couldn't, it was too far for me to walk. So I just um, it took me a long time to go to sleep because that was on my mind, I could see it in my sleep, I wake up, I could see it. So finally I got to sleep and I had prayed, I said – Lord, just let me make it, let me get to tomorrow morning…and I know everything’s going to be all right. So I made it to that next day. And I knew then that I wasn’t going to use anymore.

list.subject: Marie
list.extract: My goal is to get another home and build from there and make it my home for life. I don’t want to be moved around.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: One goal is I want to finish my GED and get my KSAC,  ‘cause I want   to counsel in HIV and educational HIV and STDs.

list.subject: Debra
list.extract: I never forget, I walked up one day and there was this guy, he just had the sheet wrapped around him and he was just rocking. He was like – I’ve been here for five days, nobody’s talked to me, they barely want to touch me. I'm like – we can talk, I'm here, I ain't going nowhere. And for me, that was my epiphany. To see him just wrapped up, just waiting to die. Because the nurses only came when they had to. So from that point on I started running my mouth and talking and…

list.subject: Marilyn
list.extract: Life after diagnosis has changed, for the better. It may have taken me many years after 1989 to get my life back in order. I eventually got back on track. The want and need to go back to school is what my desire was and that’s what I did. I did not let my HIV status stop me nor did I let people stop me.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: someone brought up to me about participating in the study, and I always thought – well, if I could give something back and it would help other women along the way that come along after me, that was something I wanted to do.

list.subject: Rosemary
list.extract:
[B]ecause I’m still undetectable and not on any medication, there was a brief sub-study through WIHS where they took a fresh sample of my blood and they sent it to New York to analyze down to the gene level, and hopefully use the information from that, as well
 as the others they’ve collected to put towards developing a vaccine.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I want my future to look…I want there to become a cure, a real cure. I know that the medicines are keeping us alive but I want one day to take that test and say – it’s not there anymore! That’s what I want my future to be. I don't want to have to put expiration dates on my life, like my first goal was to see my kids graduate from high school. Now this goal I'm making is to see my grandkids grown. I don't want to have to have praying for expiration dates. I want to be praying that God give man knowledge of a cure, a real cure, and not just a Band-aid that you putting over by taking the medication.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: That’s another reason why I advocate, because there are people who are not like that. There are women who won't speak up for themselves; not because they don't want to, because they can't. They don't know what to say, how to say it. So they need somebody there for them. I don’t mind being that person. I had to do it for myself, although I had support to encourage me and empower me to do it for myself. Now it’s a no-brainer for me, I just automatically do it. So when I made that decision to take the medication I even remember sitting on the edge of my sofa, holding this pill and looking at it and I'm like – hmm, when I swallow you it’s going to be for the rest of my life.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: I'm grateful for…I wouldn't change the diagnosis. People say would you go back? Go back for what? There’s too much to go back to. Honestly I’ve met more people, I’ve been able to do a whole lot as an advocate and a woman living with HIV. I’ve been able to help other women, connect with other women, network with other women, come up with ideas so we can help make an impact on our community and dispel myths and stop stigmas. It’s just been great. Even doing the research studies, I always say yes, I never say no. There are a lot of people who are afraid of research, even if it is questioning. Because just fear, lack of knowing, years ago it was always said – what goes on in the house stays in the house, don’t tell people your business. But a lot of these things help other people and that’s what I'm about, helping other people. If I have to be a part of it, I care. That’s it because I’ll keep talking (laughter).

list.subject: Angel
list.extract: I would love to hit the Power Ball so I could help people that are living with this disease; help the homeless; help the children; help the people that are abused. I just want to help. Prayer helps, but you need financial. I'm ready to hit that Power Ball so I can really get out here and help.

list.subject: Claristine
list.extract: I would like… to leave a legacy for women. I would like to do everything I could to help HIV women, help women on the street, that’s why I'm trying to get this house for women, and the name of it is The House of Refuge Women’s Center.

list.subject: FB
list.extract: I don’t ever want to make my day feel like I'm living with HIV. I don’t never live like that. I don’t never put it in my head that that’s what I'm living with or that’s what I'm living for, because I'm not! I'm living for myself. In the next two years I'm going to be older, I know I'm going to be older. But I really don’t see myself anywhere else but where I'm at today. You know?

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: I can remember times when I was out there tricking. If a guy told me…and I always carried condoms…but if a guy told me I’ll give you $10 extra if you let me take off the condom…naturally I said yes, okay, because that’s more money. I'm trying to get me some drugs! So yes, take it off. So I took it off and that could have been the person that gave it to me. But at the time being on those drugs it didn't even matter I just wanted that money. That’s why I'm so glad to be off the drugs. If I could get anybody, if I could just get to one person and let them know that drugs is not the answer. Because of the different things that you can get doing drugs, if I could just reach one person to the point where they would stop doing what they're doing, I feel like my job was done. People need help out there today, because it’s still a lot of girls out there doing what I was doing. And things haven't gotten any better; if anything, they’ve gotten worse. If I could just reach one person I would be very happy.

list.subject: Peaches
list.extract: I didn’t really have too much of a childhood until I came up here when I was 10. When I was down South I was like a grownup person because I had to clean, it was very abusive, from place to place. My mother was here; she left me down South so I was like back and forth with my father’s people and then my mother’s people. But my father’s people was the best ones but my mother’s family we didn’t get to see that much, especially after my father had passed. He passed when I was very young. He the one that showed me love, we were very close.

list.subject: Redell
list.extract: I grew up in Harlem, Lincoln Projects with my mother and my three sisters until they went down South. I was molested from age three until 14. By my mother’s husband. I got pregnant at 13 and my mother made me have an abortion. Then after that, I... by the age of 15 I was selling my body until about, hmm, 29. Started using drugs, heavy drugs at 17, crack cocaine. I’ve been clean since 2009 now, October 2009, seven years and some change.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract: Basically I am 50 years old, I am from a family of seven children, I have one brother who is deceased now and I still have six sisters. I’m the baby of the bunch as they usually say, the black sheep and all that good stuff (laughter). Basically you know growing up for us was, it was real nice because my mom and dad were both from Mississippi and so they were kinda old fashioned and they didn’t believe in SOB kids, which I’m quite sure you know what that means, I wanna be a little discreet here. They didn’t believe in children out of wedlock at all, okay? And they didn’t believe in us dating or even thinking about having a boyfriend to bring to the house and introduce to them until we were 16 years old. But of course me being the baby and a spoiled brat of the six girls, I was sneakin’ around anyway....

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: I just always wanted to be around black people. Because in Montreal where I was raised it was en Français and the Haitians, we didn’t consider them our people. When I was little, I would say – when I grow up I’m gonna move to the States and be around a lot of my people. And when I came here (1969) people treated me so bad.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: I’m Latina. I was born in Indiana, we stayed mostly with my grandparents, we all stayed there, my grandfather and his brothers were the type that they built their own places and my mom met my dad there in Indiana and he was of Puerto Rican descent, so Mexican and Puerto Rican. I remember... well, it was nice having all family around—aunts, uncles, other cousins, coming to see grandma and grandpa. And then whenever grandpa wanted help out in the fields because he would do all that stuff, I remember as a young kid, he’d take whatever hands and feet were available to stand and pull, you know? We’d do all kinds of stuff out in the fields helping grandpa. And I thought it was exciting because they used to bring home live meals, take it to the garage and do what had to be done. I thought that was normal.

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: We came in ’67 because my sister was a baby at the time that we came here. I remember Martin Luther King and Jesse Jackson, the riot, we was in the car because our house was on fire so just…it was a crazy time and I didn't understand it. ...But now that I look back I'm like – history was being made, and even though I was a part of it and I didn't understand. Like – they burnt the house down! Where we going to go? And people said – don’t leave out the house.

list.subject: Racheal
list.extract: ...there were six children from five different fathers. But we were mostly raised by my mom. I'm the oldest out of six – three girls, three boys. I was born in Mississippi, I don’t remember much about that. From there we moved to Memphis, TN and I briefly remember living in Memphis, that’s where my older brother and sister, second sister was born. We lived there until I was seven then we moved to Chicago when I was seven.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract:
I come from a family of eight, well there was 10 of us in all but eight of us lived….I'm the sixth. I had to think because you know my mother married when she very young, very young and she had a baby very young. It was all good time but I also growed up in that Jim Crow law if you know what Jim Crow…I'm from the South and that’s where the Jim Crow laws started but there were eight of us, I gots part of that Jim Crow law because you had different things for black and whites, whatever. I'm part of that. 
 My father wanted the best, the best for us, go to school every day, but they had a third and fourth grade education, my parent did. But I always told my parent, we came out okay, they couldn't teach us how to read or anything like that, help us with our homework, but we always said we made it.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: When I first came here I had…my first job, I think I was 19. 19 years old….I was working on an assembly line up North. But I had a little problem there. I wouldn’t say it was my problem, but I think it was the other guy’s problem because he called me the N word....And I slapped his face and then I got fired. He wasn’t funny, he didn’t have the right to call me that in the first place. But I was called that word when I was in the South, but this was close to close. That boy’s like a six foot man, white man called me that. And I didn’t like it and I slapped his face and I got fired. But that was 40 years ago.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: I was born in Brooklyn, NY and I moved to North Carolina maybe 23 years ago.  I'm 46 years old and I work for the Post Office.  My mom died and the person that I was infected from HIV, he died, and I just needed a different scene, I just needed to get away with my kids, and North Carolina was it, felt like a safer place to go.  I had nobody else to stay in New York for as far as my mom and my fiancée.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: I'm originally from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. I’ve lived there all my life. I now live in North Carolina; I moved to North Carolina in 1997. I am the mother of two children and three grandchildren. I'm the oldest girl. There are a total of five, six, seven of us, now six, one has passed on. But I'm the oldest girl, I'm the big sister, I'm the one that everybody goes to when they have problems (laughter).

list.subject: Wanda
list.extract: Well now I'm a really a homebody, I don’t do much, I don't know many people here, I came from up north, I came down here in 2009. Off and on with my daughter, I go home, I come back, I go home and come back. And they move around so much within these few years. So, I haven't really settled in no place for a long time. Not that I want many friends because to me it’s just trouble. I don’t go anywhere, I don’t club…I babysit whenever they need me and I just stay close to the house. But I know we going to get to this, but my main concern now is I want my space. I want my space. I want to be free and freedom to me means having my own place, my own space again. I need that. I feel like I'm suffocating you know?

list.subject: Bobbie
list.extract: I like them [THE WIHS STAFF] because they came to be—Joan, Dr. Sha, Sylvia, Anna— they have all came to be like a family.

list.subject: Cordelia
list.extract:
And that’s how WIHS was born.... And it got bigger and bigger and branched out and they, it was such an inspiration to me because the Core Center for one, they have groups there, different support groups. So I could come to the Core Center and I could go to a Recovery Group, I can go to a Women of Dignity Group, I can go to an HIV Support Group, I can do all of that at the Core Center. And I could see my primary doctor. And WIHS, before they got this wonderful office, they still have some of their people that come back and forth that’s at the Core Center, but then they created this wonderful office. So for one, WIHS took a lot of weight off of our primary care doctors because WIHS does so much for us, from the Pap smear to the…so when I go to see my primary care doctor, she’s like—okay Cordelia, what you need? Some paperwork filled out or refills sent down? And let me check your heart and look in your ears, okay, have a good day (laughter). And for a while I was like dang, that’s not fair, she don’t have to do nothing! Here it is research got to do all this different stuff. I’m like okay, you get the care where you can get it or
when you can get it, from whoever you can get it from.

list.subject: Marta
list.extract: It’s like the salmon, you know you’ve got to come back to it. And how odd that I say the salmon because my ma used to work at Cook County when we were young and we used to literally live down Harrison Street, by Harrison and Racine, made my communion, went to a school that’s no longer there, all of that there. And it’s weird that I end up working here and then being involved in [THE WIHS] study.

list.subject: Mary B
list.extract: someone brought up to me about participating in the study, and I always thought – well, if I could give something back and it would help other women along the way that come along after me, that was something I wanted to do.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: I’ve met a lot of women who I have a lot in common with. It don’t matter where we’re from. It don’t matter if you were born on the South side, the North side, Cicero, whatever. We all have a lot in common. From the beginning to probably how a lot of us were raised or we ended up recently. And how we deal with what’s going on with us. It saddens me when I think of women that their families aren’t supportive. Because I’ve been blessed since I’ve been sick, my family has been great to me.

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: Then I got introduced to WIHS through the Core Center. And WIHS is just great, they’re great to us. I get tests that I need to actually have anyway and all the Paps and that, I need that because I had problems with my cervix in the past, so I need that. I get what I need – medical attention. They’re very friendly and very nice to us, generous with us, you know generous with us, personable. It’s been a great experience being in WIHS. I love this project, I’m glad to do it. I’m glad to share my experiences, if anybody has an interest.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Sherri
list.extract: They ask a lot of good questions about different things in your life – do you have access to the proper healthcare? Do you have access to medicine? People need to know somebody cares and finds that out. Relationships. We were in a project about relationships, disclosure, I got a little certificate a couple years back.

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: So, there was that, and then when I got to this study, the people here are so great, you never feel judged. It’s like a warm, fuzzy, sunshiny place to come to for me. You always feel, you know, they always make you feel like a person (crying)... And they don't want anything from you (crying)… So it’s not like they're charging you to make you feel like a person (crying). And you know they provide a lot of needed things, in my case of course it was the physicals and pap smears, but you know, moral support, helping to make sure that I don’t fall into the cracks, which I normally would have done by now in this situation. And there was a time where I was like…I couldn't get the medication because I made too much money (crying) but I didn't have insurance. And I was too depressed to care! (crying)

list.subject: Tamie
list.extract: I'm a (crying) good person, because of WIHS and people like you and ID Clinic, I'm living with a disease. I have a disease; the disease don’t have me anymore. It’s a part of me but it ain't got me by no means. I’ve been undetected for five years and I was diagnosed in 2010. So I think I did pretty good.

themes.text: Taking charge of health and wellness
themes.key: taking charge of health and wellness

list.subject: Vonnie
list.extract: The WIHS Study is one of them [support systems]. Also there's another group that I'm with at CARE, Inc. called the PAW Group, which stands for Positive Active Women (Wanda: where is that?) in Durham. (Wanda: Ya’ll got everything in Durham) It’s a support group of women who have, well, you don’t have to have HIV to be in, but a lot of the women in that group are HIV positive. The ‘Positive’ doesn’t mean that you're positive for HIV, it’s just that you're doing positive things in your life

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: I just always wanted to be around black people. Because in Montreal where I was raised it was en Français and the Haitians, we didn’t consider them our people. When I was little, I would say – when I grow up I’m gonna move to the States and be around a lot of my people. And when I came here (1969) people treated me so bad.

list.subject: Dolores
list.extract: My stepdad was a miner, my mother was a housewife, back then they didn’t work. When I was six years old I had to go live with my sister because I took epileptic seizures. And when people would raise their voice, I would get behind the stove…I was always nervous and shy. And people would come to the house, and my mother was very blunt, and they would go (gasping), and they would do that as a smartness but I didn’t know they’d go oh, that’s the little chocolate one you adopted?

list.subject: Mary C
list.extract: We came in ’67 because my sister was a baby at the time that we came here. I remember Martin Luther King and Jesse Jackson, the riot, we was in the car because our house was on fire so just…it was a crazy time and I didn't understand it. ...But now that I look back I'm like – history was being made, and even though I was a part of it and I didn't understand. Like – they burnt the house down! Where we going to go? And people said – don’t leave out the house.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract:
I come from a family of eight, well there was 10 of us in all but eight of us lived….I'm the sixth. I had to think because you know my mother married when she very young, very young and she had a baby very young. It was all good time but I also growed up in that Jim Crow law if you know what Jim Crow…I'm from the South and that’s where the Jim Crow laws started but there were eight of us, I gots part of that Jim Crow law because you had different things for black and whites, whatever. I'm part of that. 
 My father wanted the best, the best for us, go to school every day, but they had a third and fourth grade education, my parent did. But I always told my parent, we came out okay, they couldn't teach us how to read or anything like that, help us with our homework, but we always said we made it.

list.subject: Sweet Pea
list.extract: When I first came here I had…my first job, I think I was 19. 19 years old….I was working on an assembly line up North. But I had a little problem there. I wouldn’t say it was my problem, but I think it was the other guy’s problem because he called me the N word....And I slapped his face and then I got fired. He wasn’t funny, he didn’t have the right to call me that in the first place. But I was called that word when I was in the South, but this was close to close. That boy’s like a six foot man, white man called me that. And I didn’t like it and I slapped his face and I got fired. But that was 40 years ago.

list.subject: Adele
list.extract: Oh yes, a lot, I have. I went to a woman’s clinic down here in North Carolina and I was having female problems and the doctor said to me…you might want to go to a clinic that deals with people like you. And I didn't understand what he meant. You know, I was like – what do you mean by that? At first I was like do you mean black people? And he was like oh, come on. You know what I mean. We’re not equipped to handle your situation. So that really…and this was like maybe 10 years ago, so it’s not that knowledge wasn’t out there and he didn't know, that’s just the way he felt. He didn't want to deal with me. He didn't want to treat me.

list.subject: Alicia
list.extract: Going through, coming up in school, I went to a school that was mixed, so I didn't see color. I knew people were different but it wasn’t like – oh you're white, I can't be with you. Oh you're Asian I can't be with you. I just wanted to be cool with everybody until as a kid, you see that there are differences because you get older people who are showing you that prejudice and trying to teach you that prejudice. I didn't have a difference between races until I was like in the second grade, having a best friend who was white and got invited to her house and when I went, her dad was like – what are you doing here (when he opened the door). I'm like – I'm here for the taco party! “We don’t allow niggers”...I'm a kid and I'm just like –what the what! I knew that word from watching Roots andthings like that, but never experienced it. She’s behind him and she’s sad and her little sister, they called me ‘Alicia’ and she’s like –let Aliciain, let Aliciain. My friend’s name was [M] and her sister’s name was[R] . He would not let me in and I ran home crying and my Mom went around there, I don't know what my crazy Mom did or said (laughter). She laughs because I call her that because my Mom really took up for us. All parents normally do, butif I got into a situation, my Mom always sent me away and she handled it, and I don't know what my crazy Mother did but all Iknow is after I saw [M] again I wasn’t allowed to speak to her. Her parents, if they saw me coming they would pull her away. She would just be looking like –oh, I can't talk to you. We’d be in school and we couldn't talk. It was just bad

list.subject: Sonja
list.extract: Let's see, we lived in New York until I was eight years old. In New York, I just remember that there were all different kinds of people – you know, Hispanics, Jews, everybody all there together – I don't remember there being racism and people calling you out on your name, because of your color or because of the language that you spoke or anything like that.
